An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the corporate limits of the city and upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, based upon gross receipts of the business or practitioner in combination with the profitability ratio for the type of business, profession, or occupation as measured by nationwide averages derived from statistics, classifications, or other information published by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget, the U.S. Internal Revenue Service, or successor agencies of the United States. Each type of business shall be assigned to a profit class based on the profitability ratio for that business type. The occupation tax class table ranges below are based on the 2012 North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code of the business. The occupation tax rate levied will be based on the profit class of the dominant line of business as defined by the NAICS. A listing of businesses and their assigned tax classes along with a list of the NAICS codes applicable to each business is available for inspection in the city clerk's office during regular business hours. 
(b)  Occupation tax schedule. The tax rate determined by profitability ratios in combination with gross receipts for each business, trade, profession, or occupation shall be as follows and will be developed and updated from time to time by the city administrator: 

 
(c)  Other restrictions and regulations. 
(1)  No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one occupation tax for each of its locations. 
(2)  No occupation tax will be required upon more than 100 percent of a business's gross receipts. 
(3)  No occupation tax will be required on gross receipts on which such tax has been levied in other localities or states when proof of payment is provided to the city. 
(4)  An occupation tax shall be required from real estate brokers, agents, or companies whose offices are located outside the city and who sell property inside the city. 
(5)  An occupation tax shall not be levied on the businesses that this article applies in any other manner except as described in this article. 
(6)  Out-of-state businesses with no location in Georgia shall be assessed occupation taxes based on the gross receipts of the business as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7 (see the definition of "gross receipts," in section 14-23(2)) which are reasonably attributed to sales or services in the state. 
(7)  There shall be a maximum tax liability of $15,000.00 per business. 
(8)  Occupation tax certificates issued hereunder shall not be transferrable. A transfer of ownership shall be considered as a termination of such business or occupation and the establishment of a new business; therefore, a new occupation tax certificate shall be required for the new owner of the business. 
(9)  No occupation tax, regulatory fee, or administrative fee may be assessed on any state or local authority, nonprofit organization, or vendor operating under a contract with a tax-exempt agricultural fair. 
(10)  All persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities exempt from paying the occupation tax shall obtain an occupation tax exemption certificate. 
(11)  The city shall not require the payment of a fee by whatever name in any amount by a business or practitioner for the cost of ascertaining whether such a business or practitioner has paid an occupation tax to another local government. 
(Code 1966, § 14-5; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-27. - Paying occupation tax of business with no location in the state. 
Registration and assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the business's largest dollar volume of business in the state is in the city, and the business or practitioner: 
(1)  Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(2)  Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction to the city. 
(Code 1966, § 14-6; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-28. - Each line of business to be identified on occupation tax certificate. 
The occupation tax certificate of each business operated within the city shall identify the line or lines of business that the business conducts. Each business shall register its line of business with the city clerk, and have that line of business noted upon the occupational tax certificate within 90 days of the commencement of such business within the city. 
(Code 1966, § 14-7; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 98-14, § 2, 6-8-1998; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-29. - Number of businesses considered to be operating in the city. 
Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location in the city, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of occupation tax. 
(Code 1966, § 14-8; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-30. - Professionals as classified in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c). 
Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (22) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on gross receipts combined with profitability ratios as set forth in section 14-26; 
(2)  A fee of $400.00 per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner paying according to this subsection shall not be required to provide information to the local government relating to the gross receipts of the business or practitioner. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business that qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework; or 
(3)  This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done by March 1. 
(Code 1966, § 14-9; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-31. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for a government. 
Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
(Code 1966, § 14-10; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-32. - Gross receipts of businesses with multiple intrastate or interstate locations. 
For those businesses that have multiple locations inside and outside of the city where the gross receipts can be allocated to each location, the gross receipts used to determine the occupational tax assessed will be those gross receipts attributed to each city location. In the case where the dollar amount of gross receipts attributed locally cannot be determined in those businesses with multiple locations, the total gross receipts will be divided by the total number of locations in the city and elsewhere and allotted to those locations. Upon request, the business or practitioner with a location or office situated in more than one jurisdiction shall provide to the city the following: 
(1)  Financial information necessary to allocate the gross receipts of the business or practitioner; and 
(2)  Information relating to the allocation of the business' or practitioner's gross receipts by other local governments. 
Provided, however, that no person shall be required to disclose information to the city which is deemed to be a privileged communication pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 24-9-21, 24-9-24, or 24-9-40. Where the business has locations outside the city and taxation is levied for a criteria other than gross receipts in the other local governments, the city shall not assess more than the allotted share of gross receipts for the local operation. 
(Code 1966, § 14-11; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 98-14, § 3, 6-8-1998; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-33. - When tax due and payable; delinquency of tax. 
Each occupation tax shall be for the calendar year unless otherwise specified. Said occupation tax shall be due and payable January 1 of each year and shall, if not paid by April 1 of each year, be subject to a ten-percent penalty for delinquency and shall accrue interest at the rate of 1.5 percent per month until said tax, penalties and interest are paid in full, as set forth in section 14-24. On any new profession, trade, business or occupation begun in the city in 1998 or succeeding years thereafter, the registration and tax shall be due and payable immediately upon beginning the business, and shall be subject to a ten-percent penalty for delinquency if not paid within 90 days of the commencement of such business, and interest shall accrue at the rate of 1.5 percent per month until said tax, penalties and interest are paid in full, as set forth in section 14-24. 
(Code 1966, § 14-12; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 95-16, § 6, 12-11-1995; Ord. No. 97-07, § 1, 6-9-1997; Ord. No. 98-14, § 4, 6-8-1998; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-34. - Evidence of state registration required; display. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed by the secretary of state pursuant to title 43 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (O.C.G.A. § 43-1-1 et seq.) shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city's registration may be issued. 
(b)  Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
(Code 1966, § 14-13; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-35. - Evidence of qualification required. 
(a)  Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificate of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city business registration, show evidence that such requirements have been met. 
(b)  Any business or practitioner of a profession doing business within the city shall be required to provide to the city any information, as and when requested by the city administrator, with regard to the site of any location or office of such business or profession or payment of occupation taxes or regulatory fees to other local taxing jurisdictions. Failure to so provide the information as requested by the city administrator shall subject such business and practitioner of a profession to the penalties provided herein. 
(Code 1966, § 14-14; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 95-16, § 7, 12-11-1995; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-36. - Liability of officers and agents; failure to pay. 
All persons subject to the occupational tax levied pursuant to this article shall be required to pay the tax for said business as described in this article, and in default thereof, the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such business shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to pay the tax. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise pay the tax herein provided for within 90 days of commencing the same; and any person who fails to pay the tax prior to the delinquency date for the payment of such tax shall be subject to the penalties provided herein. 
(Code 1966, § 14-15; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 98-14, § 5, 6-8-1998; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-37. - Business not covered by this article. 
The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by local law: 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission and the department of public safety. 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. title 46, ch. 3. 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq. 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355 (e.g., businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls). 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(Code 1966, § 14-17; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-38. - Occupation tax inapplicable. 
An occupation tax shall not apply to the gross receipts of any part of a business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the laws of the state or of the United States. 
(Code 1966, § 14-18; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-39. - Time period for taxation. 
(a)  All occupation taxes levied under this article are levied on the amount of business to be transacted during the current calendar year. However, for convenience of both the city and the taxpayer, each business subject to the occupation tax levied herein, on or before the dates hereinafter set forth, file with the city administrator the return hereinafter specifically provided for, showing the gross receipts of that business during the preceding calendar year. This return shall be used as the basis for making estimated payments on the occupation tax for the current calendar year. The actual and final amount of tax levied for business transacted in the current calendar year shall be paid in accordance with the final return to be made after the end of the year, in accordance with the procedures set forth herein. 
(b)  The owner, proprietor, manager, or executive officer of the business subject to said occupation tax of the current calendar year shall, at the end of the preceding year, and on or before March 1 of the current calendar year, file with the city administrator, on a form furnished by said city administrator, a signed return setting forth the amount of gross receipts of such business for the entire preceding calendar year. This return will be used to determine the final tax for the calendar year just completed and as an estimate of the gross receipts and occupation tax for the current year. 
(c)  Where a business subject to the occupation tax for the calendar year has been conducted for only a part of the preceding year, the amount of gross receipts for such part shall be reported in said return. Said return shall also show a figure putting the receipts for such part of a year on an annual basis with the part-year receipts bearing the same ratio to the whole-year gross receipts as the part year bears to the whole year. Said figure shall be used as the estimate of the gross receipts of the business for the current calendar year in establishing the business tax liability. 
(Code 1966, § 14-19; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-40. - Filing of return; overpaid or underpaid taxes. 
(a)  On or before March 1 of each year, the owner, proprietor, manager, or executive officer of the business liable for said occupation tax levied for the year shall file with the city administrator, on a form furnished by the city administrator, a signed return setting forth the actual amount of the gross receipts of such business during the preceding calendar year. 
(b)  If the amount of the occupation tax for the preceding year, based on the return provided for in this section and on the rate of said tax provided for in this article, is less than the amount of occupation tax theretofore paid by said business, based on the estimate filed pursuant to section 14-39, the difference in said amount shall be due and payable by the taxpayer to the city on March 1 of the current year and delinquent if not paid on or before said date. 
(c)  If the amount of the occupation tax for the preceding year, based on the return provided for in this section and on the rate of said tax provided for in this article, exceeds the amount of occupation tax theretofore paid by said business, based on the estimate filed pursuant to section 14-19, the difference in said amount shall be refundable by the city to the taxpayer; or, if said business continues to be conducted in the city during the current year, such difference in amount may be credited by the city on the amount of occupation tax to be paid to the city by said business for the current year. This election is to be taken by the city. 
(d)  Refunds. Requests for refunds based on changes in the gross receipts of the taxpayer shall be allowed only for the license year next preceding the time of the request for such refund. No refund or proration shall be made of any regulatory fee or administrative fee and no refund or proration shall be allowed for a taxpayer who shall cease doing business or remove the business from the city. 
(Code 1966, § 14-20; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-41. - Payment of occupation tax by newly established businesses. 
In the case of a business subject to occupation tax for a calendar year which was not conducted for any period of time in the city in the preceding year, the owner, proprietor, manager or executive officer of the business liable for the occupation tax shall estimate the gross volume of revenue from the commencing date to the end of the calendar year and such tax shall be paid as provided in this article. Such tax shall be due upon the commencement of the business, and if not paid within 90 days of the commencement thereby shall be subject to a ten-percent penalty for delinquency and interest at a 1.5 percent per month until said tax, penalties and interest are paid in full. 
(Code 1966, § 14-21; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 98-14, § 7, 6-8-1998; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-42. - Returns confidential. 
Except in the case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the occupation tax hereby levied, it shall be unlawful for any officer, employee, or agent of the city, or any other person to divulge or make known in any manner the amount of gross receipts or any particulars set forth or disclosed in any occupation tax return required under this article. All contents of said return shall be confidential and open only to officials, employees, or agents of the city using said returns for the purpose of this occupation tax levy and the collection of the tax. Independent auditors or bookkeepers employed by the city shall be classified as "employees" for purposes herein. Nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit the publication by city officials of statistics, so classified as to prevent the identification of particular reports or returns and items thereof; or the inspection of the records by duly qualified employees of the tax departments of the state, the United States, and other local governments. 
(Code 1966, § 14-22; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-43. - Inspection of books and records. 
In any case, the city, through its officers, agents, employees or representatives, may inspect the books, state tax returns, or other appropriate documentation of the business for which returns are made. The city shall have the right to inspect the books, state tax returns, or records for the business of which the return was made in the city, and upon the demand of the city such books, state tax returns or records shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of the city within 30 days; provided, however, that no person shall be required to disclose information to the city which is deemed to be a privileged communication pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 24-9-21, 24-9-24, or 24-9-40. Failure of the submission of such books, state tax returns or records within thirty (30) days shall be grounds for the imposition of a ten-percent penalty against such person. Adequate records shall be kept in the city for examination by the city and its officers at their discretion. If after examination of the books, state tax returns or records it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of under reporting, a penalty of ten percent of the deficiency and an additional 1.5 percent of the deficiency for each month or fraction thereof that the deficiency was past due and unpaid shall be assessed. 
(Code 1966, § 14-23; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 98-14, § 8, 6-8-1998; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-44. - Effect of failure to comply with requirements. 
Any person or his manager, agent, or employee who is required to make occupational tax returns, and who fails to make said returns within the time and in the manner herein provided, or who refuses to amend such returns so as to set forth the truth, or who makes false returns or who fails to produce the occupation tax certificate when requested to do so by the city; and any person or his manager, agent, or employee who refuses to permit an inspection of books in his charge, except as provided herein, when the officer, agent, employee, or representative of the city requests such inspection, during business hours, for the purpose of determining the accuracy of the returns herein provided for, shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 14-24. 
(Code 1966, § 14-24; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 97-07, § 3, 6-9-1997; Ord. No. 98-14, § 9, 6-8-1998; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-45. - Lien taken for delinquent occupation tax. 
In addition to other remedies herein provided for the collection of the occupation tax herein levied, the city administrator, upon any tax or installment of said tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of said tax against the persons, partnership, or corporation liable for said tax, which said execution shall bear interest at the highest rate allowable under law from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover any property in the county of the person, partnership, or corporation liable for said tax, all as provided by the city's Charter and the laws of the state. The occupation tax lien shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the city administrator upon the property of defendant in execution located in said jurisdiction, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of said execution, with interest and costs. All other related proceedings shall be as provided by the city's Charter and ordinances and the laws of the state. The defendant in said execution shall have rights of defense by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, as provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by the proper authority upon an execution issued by the city administrator against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due him as though he had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. 
(Code 1966, § 14-25; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-46. - Enforcement of provisions. 
It is hereby made the duty of the city administrator, or his designee, to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed; and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the municipal court. It is hereby made the further duty of the city administrator and his designees to inspect all certificates issued by the city, as often as in their judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the certificate held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
(Code 1966, § 14-26; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-47. - Option to establish exemption or reduction. 
In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-10(f), the city council may, by subsequent ordinance or resolution, provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax or a credit against occupation tax owed to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or for attracting, encouraging or maintaining selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax or credits against occupation tax owned shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reasons shall be set forth in the minutes of the council. 
(Code 1966, § 14-27; Ord. No. 94-08, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 95-16, § 8, 12-11-1995; Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-48. - Proration of occupation tax fee. 
When any person or business commences business on or after July 1 in any year, the occupation tax for the remaining portion of the ear shall be 50 percent of the tax imposed for the entire year, except that (1) the city is authorized to levy the occupation tax at the customary rate on the gross receipts of the business or practitioner from the commencement of the business, (2) the administrative fee and regulatory fee, if any, shall not be reduced, and (3) a practitioner of a profession or occupation who elects as his or her occupation tax the amount described in paragraph (2) of section 14-30 shall receive no reduction in such amount. 
(Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-49. - Business or landlord required to provide names and addresses of tenant businesses. 
Every person required to obtain an occupation tax certificate or a renewal of an occupation tax certificate under the provisions of this Code who leases or rents space to another business or businesses operating within the city shall submit a list of such businesses, upon request of the city administrator, or his designee, to the city as referenced in section 14-42 of the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-50. - Application and forms. 
(a)  The application for an occupation tax certificate, returns, NAICS codes, business class tables, notices, forms and other documents and papers necessary to the implementation and enforcement of this chapter shall be on such forms and in such manner as may be prepared and directed by the city administrator, or his designee. 
(b)  Such forms shall include the NAICS code of the business, its taxable gross revenues for the preceding 12 calendar months, the number of employees of the business, the State of Georgia sales tax identification number for the business pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-20.1, the federal work authorization user identification number (E-VERIFY) of the business, federal employment eligibility verification system user number (SAVE) and any such other information as may be required and deemed necessary by the city administrator, or his designee. If a business or practitioner does not know how many employees will be employed by the business or practitioner during the current calendar year, then the business or practitioner shall estimate the number of employees in its business. 
(Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Sec. 14-51. - Display of occupation tax certificate. 
All occupation tax certificates issued under this article shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business of the person to whom the certificate is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2013-33, 12-9-2013) 
Secs. 14-52—14-67. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENTS 

Sec. 14-68. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Amusement center proprietor means any establishment where three or more coin-operated amusement machines are maintained which occupy less than 25 percent of the available floor space. As used herein, the terms "proprietor" and "amusement center proprietor," but not "arcade room proprietor" and "amusement center proprietor" shall be synonymous unless specifically provided otherwise. 
Arcade room means any establishment where more than three coin-operated amusement machines are maintained which occupy more than 25 percent of the available floor space. 
Arcade room proprietor means any proprietor of an arcade room as both terms are defined herein. As used herein, the terms "proprietor" and "arcade room proprietor" shall be synonymous unless specifically provided otherwise. 
Available floor space includes all that space necessary for the placement, operation and use of the machines licensed hereunder and shall not be solely limited to the space occupied by the machines themselves. 
Coin-operated amusement machine means any machine or device operated by means of the insertion of a coin, token, or similar object for the purpose of receiving the temporary services of said machine for recreation or a game of skill and for the playing of which a fee is charged. The term does not include vending machines in which are not incorporated recreation features, nor does the term include any coin-operated mechanical musical devices or kiddie rides. 
Proprietor means any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association or club who, as the owner or lessee, has under his or its control any establishment, place or premises in or at which a coin-operated amusement machine is placed or kept for use or play, or on exhibition for the purpose of use or play by the general public. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-21; Ord. No. 94-08, § 10, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 95-04, § 1, 2-13-1995) 
Sec. 14-69. - Permit required. 
No person shall engage in the business of an arcade room, without first having obtained the proper permit from the city and paid the proper regulatory fee therefor. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-22; Ord. No. 94-08, § 10, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-70. - Arcade room proprietor's regulatory fee. 
The regulatory fee for each arcade room proprietor shall be such fee as established from time to time by resolution of the mayor and city council. Said regulatory fee shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year and shall be delinquent if not paid by March 1 of each year. All arcade room proprietors' regulatory fees shall be payable annually in advance. In no case shall any portion of said regulatory fee be refunded to the arcade room proprietor. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-23; Ord. No. 94-08, § 10, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-71. - Application for permit; posting, transfer of permit. 
(a)  Application for permits hereunder shall be filed in writing with the city clerk, on forms to be provided by the city, and shall specify: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant, and if a firm, corporation, partnership or association, the principal officers thereof and their addresses. 
(2)  Proprietors shall list the address of the premises where the permitted machine or machines are to be operated, together with the character of the business as carried on at such place. 
(3)  Proprietors shall list the number of machines to be maintained on the premises. 
(4)  The name and address of the owner of the machine, if other than the proprietor. This information shall not be released to the general public without the consent of the permit holder. 
(5)  Whether or not the person having management of or supervision over the applicant's business have been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense, and the punishment assessed therefor. 
(b)  The proper regulatory fee shall accompany such application. The permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the establishment of the permit holder. Such permit shall be nonassignable and nontransferable, and in the case of a proprietor, shall apply only to the premises for which such permit is issued. In addition, each machine shall have placed upon it by the permit holder a sticker showing the permit number of its proprietor. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-24; Ord. No. 94-08, § 10, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-72. - Character qualifications. 
No permit shall be issued to or renewed for any person who has, or employs a person who has, within five years of issuance or renewal, been convicted of, or pled guilty or nolo contendere to, any felony involving any federal or state offense or any federal or state misdemeanor involving drug-related offenses or offenses involving moral turpitude; and the permit holder will submit the identity of all owners and employees to the city on a continuing basis as changes occur. This information is to be forwarded to the city police department, for the purpose of allowing a complete check in order that these character qualifications be fulfilled, prior to the issuance or renewal of any permit issued hereunder. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-25; Ord. No. 94-08, § 10, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-73. - Increasing number of devices. 
In case a proprietor regulated under the provisions of this article desires, after the expiration of any portion of any permit year, to increase the number of machines to be used or played, or exhibited for use or play in his establishment, so that he then has three or more machines, he shall surrender his permit to the city clerk who shall issue a new arcade room proprietor permit upon payment of the proper regulatory fee therefor with any applicable credit for the previously paid regulatory fee. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-26; Ord. No. 94-08, § 10, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-74. - Revocation of permit. 
In the event that it comes to the attention of the mayor and council that any coin-operated amusement device has created a nuisance to the surrounding community or has violated any provision of this article, the following procedure will be followed: 
(1)  The city administrator shall issue a notice of objection that shall include the address of the location and the specific reasons the machine or machines in question are alleged to be a nuisance or alleged to violate any provision of this article. The city administrator will then notify the proprietor that a notice of objection has been filed and will set a date for a hearing before the mayor and council on this matter. Extensions and necessary investigations will be granted and conducted at the discretion of the city administrator. 
(2)  At the time of the hearing, any resident, the proprietor and the city administrator may be heard. After this hearing, the mayor and council shall issue a "notice of decision" which will call for the dismissal of the objection, removal of the machines or such other remedy as they deem appropriate under the circumstances that are consistent with the purpose of this article. 
(3)  The decision of the mayor and council shall be in writing and shall state the reasons for their decision and shall be based upon the merits of the case. 
(4)  The decision of the mayor and council shall be final, but may be appealed to the appropriate court within 30 days. 
(5)  The decision of the mayor and council shall be binding upon the proprietor of the machine under the consideration. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-27; Ord. No. 94-08, § 10, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-75. - Operating regulations. 
(a)  Generally. All businesses permitted hereunder shall be subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  Devices to be kept in plain view; gambling devices prohibited. All such machines shall at all times be kept and placed in plain view of and open and accessible to any person who may frequent or be in any place of business where such machines are kept or used. However, no machine shall be placed within five feet of any public entrance or exit. Nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize or permit any gambling device of any nature whatsoever. 
(2)  Inspection. The chief of police shall inspect or cause the inspection of any place or building in which in any such machine or machines are operated or set up for operation and to inspect, investigate and test such machines as needed. 
(3)  Attendant required. It shall be unlawful for any proprietor to open his business to the public unless an attendant is present. Said attendant shall be of sufficient mental and physical capacity so as to be able to provide aid to patrons if needed or desired. Said attendant shall not be less than 18 years of age. 
(4)  Refunds and adjustments. Refunds and adjustments to all customers shall be the responsibility of the proprietor of the machine in question. 
(5)  Loitering. As used in this section, the term "loitering" shall mean remaining idle in essentially one location and shall include the concepts of spending time idly, loafing, or walking about aimlessly, and shall include the colloquial expression "hanging around." It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter within the immediate vicinity of any machine or business premises regulated hereunder, or for any person, firm or corporation permitted to operate an arcade room to permit loitering on or in the immediate vicinity of any machine or business premises regulated hereunder in such a manner as to: 
a.  Create or cause to be created a danger of a breach of the peace; 
b.  Create or cause to be created any disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person; 
c.  Obstruct the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles; 
d.  Obstruct, molest, or interfere with any person lawfully in any public place. 
(6)  Proper attire. All proprietors shall require shirts and shoes be worn at all times by any person frequenting their premises. 
(7)  Pool tables. No proprietor, except amusement center proprietors, shall maintain pool tables or bumper pool tables on the premises. 
(8)  Alcoholic beverages. No proprietor, except those licensed to sell alcoholic beverages, shall allow alcoholic beverages to be brought onto their premises by any person. 
(9)  Restricted hours. No coin-operated amusement device shall be operated in any establishment licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following morning. 
(b)  Violation. Violation of any of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall be sufficient grounds for revocation of the permit issued hereunder. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-28; Ord. No. 94-08, § 10, 10-24-1994; Ord. No. 95-04, § 2, 2-13-1995) 
Secs. 14-76—14-93. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FESTIVALS 

Sec. 14-94. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  The aesthetic quality and economic value of both commercial and residential areas surrounding festivals as well as the economy of the city are adversely affected by the unregulated operation of festivals. 
(b)  Lives and property are endangered by traffic created by festivals which are unregulated and uncontrolled and by vehicles for which no provisions for parking and safe ingress and egress have been made by festival operators. 
(c)  Festivals create difficulty in police supervision because of large crowds and the transient nature of participants. 
(d)  The ordinance from which this article is derived is adopted in order to promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the citizens of the city, and of the general public by regulating the location, design, operation and maintenance of festivals. 
(e)  This article establishes the minimum standards for festivals located within the city limits. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-75; Ord. No. 96-08, § 1, 5-13-1996) 
Sec. 14-95. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Festival means a specific outdoor public celebration or gathering for which a license or permit has been issued by the city which involves the use either of public parks or public streets and which includes entertainment, dancing, music, dramatic productions, art exhibition, parades, or the sale of merchandise, food or beverages, or any combination of the foregoing; and which of necessity requires for its successful execution the provision and coordination of municipal services to a degree significantly over and above that which the city routinely provides under ordinary everyday circumstances. The term "festival" does not include events that are solely parades, footraces or political demonstrations unless such parade, footrace or political demonstration is proposed as an integral part of a larger festival. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-76; Ord. No. 96-08, § 1, 5-13-1996) 
Sec. 14-96. - Festival permits. 
(a)  Application review. Applicants who wish to conduct a festival must submit an application to the city clerk on forms provided for that purpose. The city administrator will review each application to determine compliance with this article and other relevant city, county, state, and/or federal laws and issue the festival permit to the applicant upon confirmation of compliance. The city administrator may, at his discretion, or shall, upon written request of the applicant, refer the festival permit application to the mayor and city council for review. 
(b)  Standards of review. 
(1)  A festival permit applied for hereunder or renewal thereof shall be denied where the application or investigation show any of the following to exist: 
a.  The location of the festival is not properly zoned; 
b.  The applicant has failed to obtain an occupation tax registration and failed to pay the taxes due in connection therewith; 
c.  The applicant has failed to pay any fee required under this article or has otherwise failed to comply with any of the provisions of this article. 
(2)  A festival permit applied for hereunder or renewal thereof may be denied where the application or investigation show any of the following to exist: 
a.  The applicant is of bad moral character or has a bad reputation in the community or does not have sufficient mental capacity to conduct the festival for which application is made; 
b.  The applicant has had any license issued under the police powers of any county or other governmental entity previously suspended or revoked; 
c.  The applicant, as a previous holder of a license as a festival promoter, operator, owner or vendor, has violated any law, including this article, relating to such business, within a ten-year period immediately preceding the date of the initial application or renewal application; 
d.  The applicant has supplied false information either upon his application or in any communication with any official of the city relative to his application; 
e.  The application, during the 12-month period next preceding the filing of his application, has engaged in any deceptive business practices; 
f.  A permit hereunder may be denied to any person, partnership or corporation for pecuniary gain where any individual having an interest either as owner, partner, or stockholder owning at least 25 percent of the stock of the corporation, such interest being direct or indirect, beneficial or absolute, or his spouse or manager of the operation, shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendere within ten years immediately prior to the filing of said application for any felony or misdemeanor of any state or of the United States or any municipal or county ordinance except traffic violations. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or plea of guilty or nolo contendere, or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime; 
g.  In addition to the above and in determining whether or not any festival permit applied for shall be granted, the following shall be considered in the public interest and welfare: 
1.  If the applicant is a previous holder of a festival permit, the manner in which he conducted the festival thereunder, and particularly as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such festival; 
2.  The location for which the festival permit is sought as to traffic congestion, general character of the neighborhood and the effect such an establishment would have on the adjacent and surrounding property values; 
3.  If it appears that the applicant's spouse or another person is using the applicant as a guise or "dummy" to obtain a festival permit. 
(c)  Investigation of application. 
(1)  The city administrator or his designee is hereby authorized and directed to make such inspections and conduct such investigations as are necessary to determine satisfactory compliance with the requirements for issuance of a festival permit contained in this article. 
(2)  All applications for a festival permit shall be investigated by the city police department. Said department shall report its recommendations to the city administrator. The applicant for a festival permit shall be fingerprinted and shall supply such other information as the police department deems necessary to complete its investigation. 
(d)  Issuance of festival permit. 
(1)  No festival permit issued hereunder shall be transferable to any other person or to any other location. 
(2)  Each festival permit issued hereunder shall be for one location only. Festival operators shall be required to obtain a separate festival permit, paying a separate administrative and regulatory fee, for each festival location. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-77; Ord. No. 96-08, § 1, 5-13-1996) 
Sec. 14-97. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  Generally. Condition of soil, groundwater level, drainage and topography shall not create hazards to the property or the health or safety of the occupants. The site shall not be exposed to objectionable smoke, noise, odors or other adverse influences, and no portion subject to unpredictable and/or sudden flooding, subsidence or erosion shall be used for any purpose that would expose persons or property to hazards. 
(b)  Soil and ground cover. Exposed ground surfaces shall be paved, or covered with stone screenings or other solid materials or protected with a vegetative growth that is capable of preventing soil erosion and of eliminating objectionable dust and/or mud. 
(c)  Site drainage requirements. The ground surface shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe, efficient manner in order to eliminate water pockets, low areas or bogs. 
(d)  Traffic. 
(1)  All festivals shall provide safe and convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets or roads or highways only at curb cuts or locations approved by the city. 
(2)  Access to festivals shall be designed to minimize congestion and hazards at the entrance or exit and allow free movement of traffic on adjacent streets. 
(3)  The festival operator shall provide private traffic control personnel sufficient to ensure free movement of other local traffic in the area without the assistance of the police department. 
(e)  Walks. All festivals shall provide safe, convenient, durable, all-season, dust free, pedestrian access of adequate width for intended use. Sudden changes in alignment and gradient shall be avoided. 
(f)  Refuse handling. The storage, collection and disposal of refuse in the festival shall be so conducted as to create no health hazards, rodent harborage, insect breeding areas, accident or fire hazards or air pollution. 
(g)  Insect and rodent control. 
(1)  Extermination. Grounds, buildings and structures shall be maintained free of insect and rodent harborage and infestation. Extermination methods and other measures to control insects and rodents shall conform with the requirements of the county health authority. 
(2)  Accumulation of debris. Festivals shall be maintained free of accumulations of debris that may provide rodent harborage or breeding places for flies, mosquitoes and other pests. 
(3)  Storage areas. Storage areas shall be so maintained as to prevent rodent harborage; lumber, pipe and other building materials shall be stored at least one foot above ground. 
(4)  Exterior openings. Where the potential for insect and rodent infestation exists, all exterior openings in or beneath any structure shall be appropriately screened with wire mesh or other suitable materials. 
(h)  Growth of weeds, etc., to be controlled. The growth of brush, weeds and grass shall be controlled to prevent harborage of ticks, chiggers and other noxious insects. The growth of grass or other acceptable ground cover shall be maintained at a height of less than nine inches at all times during the year. Festivals shall be so maintained as to prevent the growth of ragweed, poison ivy, poison oak, poison sumac and other noxious weeds considered detrimental to health. Open areas shall be maintained free of heavy undergrowth of any description. 
(i)  Hours of operation. No festival shall be open to the public before 8:00 a.m. or remain open after dusk. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-78; Ord. No. 96-08, § 1, 5-13-1996) 
Sec. 14-98. - Inspections and enforcement. 
(a)  The city administrator or his designee is hereby authorized and directed to make such inspections and conduct such investigations as are necessary to determine satisfactory compliance with this article. 
(b)  The city administrator or his designee shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to enforcement of this article. 
(c)  The city administrator or his designee may request inspections by and verifications of compliance from the county or state department of public health relating to any of the rules and regulations of such health department. The representative of the department of health shall notify the city administrator or his designee of any violations of this article and requirements for corrections. Representatives of the department of public health shall have the same powers of entry and inspection as provided for the city administrator or his designee. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-79) 
Sec. 14-99. - Revocation of festival permit. 
(a)  Any festival permit issued hereunder may be revoked, suspended or placed on probation if any of the following conditions are found to exist: 
(1)  Violation of any provision of this article; 
(2)  Violation of any ordinance of the city or any local, state or federal laws; 
(3)  The permittee supplies false information to the city either during or following application for a festival permit, regardless of when the city shall have become aware of the same; 
(4)  If any reason exists which would have been grounds for denial of the original or renewal festival permit. 
(b)  Should any of the conditions described in subsection (a) of this section be in existence, the city administrator or his designee shall give written notice to the permittee or owner that unless such conditions are corrected within 30 days of its receipt of the notice, the festival permit may be revoked, suspended or placed on probation. 
(c)  In the event the permittee fails to correct such conditions within 30 days from its receipt of notice, the city administrator shall conduct a hearing. The permittee shall be provided written notice of such hearing and its time, place and purpose and a statement of the charges upon which the festival permit may be revoked, suspended or placed on probation. 
(d)  In the event the city administrator revokes the permittee's festival permit and upon notice of the same to the permittee, the permittee shall immediately cease operation of the festival. 
(e)  In the event the city administrator suspends the permittee's festival permit and upon notice of the same to the permittee, the permittee shall immediately cease operation and/or construction of the festival for the period of suspension. 
(f)  In the event the city administrator places the permittee named in the festival permit on probation and upon notice of the same to the permittee, the permittee shall comply with all of the terms of such probation. 
(g)  Appeal. In the event the city administrator revokes or suspends a festival permit or places a permit holder on probation, the permittee shall have the right to an appeal before the mayor and city council. Such notice of appeal must be filed in writing with the city administrator within five days from the receipt of the notice of revocation, suspension or probation. If an appeal is not filed in a timely manner as outlined above, the appeal shall be deemed to be waived. Upon receipt of an appeal, the mayor shall set a date for the appeal hearing. Such hearing shall be no later than 15 calendar days from the receipt of the request for the hearing. The mayor may, at his discretion, extend the time for the commencement of the hearing. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-80; Ord. No. 96-08, § 1, 5-13-1996) 
Secs. 14-100—14-126. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS 

Sec. 14-127. - Imposed. 
The city has levied an annual business license tax upon each financial institution located within the city at a rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts, as defined and allocated under this article, of said financial institution. The minimum annual amount of such tax upon any depository financial institution shall be $1,000.00. 
(Code 1966, § 14-71; Ord. No. 94-08, § 5, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-128. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Financial institution, banks, savings and loan associations, parent bank, branch bank, or bank office means those same terms as defined in the Financial Institutions Code of Georgia at O.C.G.A. § 7-1-1 et seq. 
Gross receipts. 
(1)  The term "gross receipts" means the total amount of revenue generated from the sources itemized in subsections (2) and (3) of this definition during the calendar year immediately preceding the date on which the tax authorized by this article shall be due. Before determining gross receipts there shall be deducted: 
a.  An amount equal to the amount of interest paid on all liabilities for the period; 
b.  An amount equal to income derived from the authorized activities of any domestic international banking facility operating pursuant to the Domestic International Banking Facility Act, O.C.G.A. § 7-1-730 et seq.; 
c.  An amount equal to any income arising from the conduct of a banking business with persons or entities located outside of the United States, its territories or possessions; 
d.  An amount equal to a depository financial institution's gross income which is taxed under the tax laws of a state other than this state; and 
e.  To the extent that any deductions are made pursuant to subsections (1)b, c and d of this definition, any deductions taken under subsection (1)a of this definition shall be reduced by the same proportion that the deductions in subsections (1)b, c and d of this definition bear to the gross receipts of the depository financial institution as calculated before making any deductions pursuant to subsections (1)a through d of this definition. 
(2)  The items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to banks are as follows: 
a.  Interest and fees on loans less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold and serviced for others; 
b.  Interest on balances with other depository financial institutions; 
c.  Interest on federal or correspondent funds sold and securities purchased under agreement to resell; 
d.  Interest on other bonds, notes and debentures, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; 
e.  Dividends on stock; 
f.  Income from direct lease financing; 
g.  Income from fiduciary activities; 
h.  Service charges on deposit accounts; 
i.  Other service charges, commissions and fees; and 
j.  Other income. 
(3)  The items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to savings and loan associations are as follows: 
a.  Interest on mortgage loans less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold and serviced for others; 
b.  Interest on mortgages, participations or mortgage-backed securities; 
c.  Interest on real estate sold on contract; 
d.  Discounts on mortgage loans purchased; 
e.  Interest on other loans, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; 
f.  Interest and dividends on investments and deposits; 
g.  Loan fees; 
h.  Loan servicing fees; 
i.  Other fees and charges; 
j.  Gross income from real estate-owned operations; 
k.  Net income from office building operations; 
l.  Gross income from real estate held for investment; 
m.  Net income from service corporations and subsidiaries; 
n.  Miscellaneous operating income; 
o.  Profit on sale of real estate owned, investment securities, loans and other assets; and 
p.  Miscellaneous non-operating income. 
(Code 1966, § 14-72; Ord. No. 94-08, § 5, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-129. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any provisions of this article shall, upon conviction before the judge of the municipal court of city, be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1966, § 14-76; Ord. No. 94-08, § 5, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-130. - Filing of tax return. 
Each depository financial institution located within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city by March 1 of each year following the year in which gross receipts are measured. Said return shall be filed in the manner and on the form prescribed by the commissioner of the state department of revenue based on the allocation method set forth in section 14-74. The return shall provide the information necessary to determine the portion of the taxpayer's total gross receipts to be allocated to each taxing jurisdiction in which such institution has a place of business. The information contained in said returns shall be the basis for the city's assessment and collection of said tax. 
(Code 1966, § 14-73; Ord. No. 94-08, § 5, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-131. - Allocation of gross receipts of financial institutions with multi-jurisdictional locations. 
(a)  A total gross receipts generated in the state by a depository financial institution shall be allocated among separate taxing jurisdictions as follows: If a depository financial institution shall have an office or a place of business in taxing jurisdictions outside of the city, the amount of gross receipts taxable by each taxing jurisdiction shall be the amount of gross receipts attributable to such offices or places of business as of December 31 of the year in which gross receipts are measured. 
(b)  In determining the amount of gross receipts attributable to each location, 20 percent of the gross receipts shall be attributable to the parent bank. The remaining 80 percent of gross receipts shall be attributable to branch banks and bank offices; pro rata according to the number of such branch banks and bank offices, with none of the gross receipts attributable to bank facilities or other outlets not considered to be a parent bank, branch bank, or bank office. If there are fewer than five branch banks or bank offices in addition to the parent bank, the amount of gross receipts attributable to each such parent bank, branch bank or bank office shall be determined by dividing the total gross receipts by the aggregate number of such outlets. For purposes of this distribution formula only, the term "bank" also means a savings and loan association. 
(Code 1966, § 14-74; Ord. No. 94-08, § 5, 10-24-1994) 
Sec. 14-132. - Lien taken for delinquent business license tax. 
In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of the business license tax herein levied, the city administrator, upon any tax or installment of said tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of said tax against the persons, partnership, or corporation liable for said tax, which said execution shall bear interest at the highest rate allowable under law from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover any property in the county of the person, partnership, or corporation liable for said tax, all as provided by the city's Charter and the laws of the state. The business license tax lien shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the city administrator upon the property of defendant in execution located in said jurisdiction, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of said execution, with interest and costs. All other related proceedings shall be as provided by the city's Charter and ordinances and the laws of the state. The defendant in said execution shall have rights of defense by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, as provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by the proper authority upon an execution issued by the city administrator against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due him as though he had never defaulted in the payment of taxes. 
(Code 1966, § 14-75; Ord. No. 94-08, § 5, 10-24-1994) 
Secs. 14-133—14-162. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FLEA MARKETS 

Sec. 14-163. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Flea market means and includes any business, whether operated as an individual concern or operated as a unit within a larger organization, structure or facility which derives 25 percent of its gross receipts from the sale, trade or barter of used or previously owned personal property, other than operable motor vehicles. In this connection, therefore, all businesses in the city which meet the definition contained herein shall be subject to the provisions of this article dealing with flea markets, whether the same be generally known as jewelry stores, coin shops, salvage operations, clothing stores or by any other name or names; provided, however, nothing contained herein shall apply to any purchase where the retail value of the merchandise or goods is $10.00 or less. The term "flea market" is interchangeable with and applicable to "swap meet," "indoor swap meet," or other similar terms regardless of whether these events are held inside a building or outside in the open. The primary characteristic is that these activities involve a series of sales sufficient in number, scope, and character to constitute a regular course of business. 
Flea market operator means a person who owns or has charge, care or control of the flea market. 
Flea market vendor means a person who engages in the retail sale of personal property at a flea market. 
(Code 1966, §§ 10A-1, 14A-86; Ord. No. 88-7, § I, 11-28-1988; Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 5-28-1996) 
Sec. 14-164. - Promoters and vendors; license required; revocation. 
(a)  Flea market promoters. All persons before beginning the business of operating and promoting a flea market shall first file an application with the city manager for a license to conduct such business. Such application shall be made on a form presented by the city manager and shall contain such information as, in the opinion of the city manager, is necessary to properly regulate the business. 
(b)  Flea market vendors. All persons, before beginning the business of selling, buying, trading or bartering in a flea market, shall first file an application with the city manager for a license to conduct such business. Such application shall be made on a form presented by the city manager and shall contain such information as, in the opinion of the city manager, is necessary to properly regulate the business. 
(c)  Investigation of applications. The chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made into the information contained in the applications described above (promoters and vendors) and into the background, character and reputation of applicants as the chief deems advisable. After such investigation, the chief shall file a written report with the city manager, whose duty it shall be to make a decision on the issuance of the license. 
(d)  Revocation of license. The city manager shall revoke the license of any flea market promoter when, in the sole discretion of the city manager, such revocation is necessary to prevent the purchase, sale, barter or trade of stolen property or to prevent the purchase, sale, barter or trade of property with minors; and provided the promoter has been previously warned of such activity and has not taken action to prevent a recurrence. The city manager shall have the duty to revoke the license of any vendor when, in the discretion of the city manager, such revocation is necessary to prevent the activity described above concerning stolen property or minors; and the failure to keep and provide accurate records shall be prima facie evidence of a vendor dealing in stolen property or with minors or both. 
(Code 1966, § 10A-2; Ord. No. 88-7, § I, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 14-165. - Precautions to be taken. 
(a)  Records; identification. All vendors in flea markets and all other businesses similarly situated which meet the definition of section 14-163 shall keep accurate records of all transactions of $10.00 or more where cash, credit or merchandise is bought or traded for by those vendors. The record of each transaction shall be made on a form prescribed by the city manager and furnished by the vendor. The form shall be dated and require an accurate description of the personal property, including identifying marks, numbers and manufacturers and shall include personal identification as to name, address, sex, race, height, weight and date of birth, and shall include either a legible thumbprint or information showing that the vendor was shown positive identification by the seller or trader of the property. A valid driver's license with photo or identification of like quality shall be required, and such identification shall be all that is acceptable as positive identification. The city manager may from time to time describe identification other than driver's licenses that may be accepted as positive identification and which, in his opinion, is of like quality. 
(b)  Forms to be supplied to law enforcement officers. Each business covered by subsection (a) of this subsection shall provide law enforcement officers with the forms completed since the last previous request for the same. 
(c)  Dealing with minors prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any flea market vendor or other business owner similarly situated, its agents or employees to purchase or trade for any merchandise or property with minors. The burden to ascertain age shall be upon the vendor or business. 
(Code 1966, § 10A-3; Ord. No. 88-7, § I, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 14-166. - Holding period for certain merchandise. 
Any person operating under a flea market promoter's or a flea market vendor's license who takes any used or previously owned merchandise by purchase, trade or barter, shall hold such merchandise for at least 15 days before disposing of the same by sale, trade, barter, transfer or shipment. Such merchandise shall be kept readily available for inspection by law enforcement officers of the city. Nothing contained in this section shall apply to the merchandise having a retail value of $10.00 or less. 
(Code 1966, § 10A-4; Ord. No. 88-7, § I, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 14-167. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  The aesthetic quality and economic value of both commercial and residential areas surrounding the flea markets as well as the economy of the city are adversely affected by the unregulated operation of flea markets. 
(b)  Lives and property are endangered by traffic created by flea markets which are unregulated and uncontrolled and by vehicles for which no provisions for parking and safe ingress and egress have been made by flea market operators. 
(c)  Flea markets create difficulty in police supervision because of lack of any control over the number, identification and types of vendors and merchandise sold, and may become targets for sale or dealing in stolen merchandise. 
(d)  The ordinance from which this article is derived is adopted in order to promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the citizens of the city, and of the general public by regulating the location, design, operation and maintenance of flea markets. 
(e)  This article establishes the minimum standards for flea markets located within the city limits. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-85; Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 5-28-1996) 
Sec. 14-168. - Flea market permits. 
(a)  Application review. Applicants who wish to conduct a flea market must submit an application to the city clerk on forms provided for that purpose. The city administrator will review each application to determine compliance with this article and other relevant city, county, state, and/or federal laws and issue the flea market permit to the applicant upon confirmation of compliance. The city administrator may, at his discretion, or shall upon written request of the applicant, refer the flea market permit application to the mayor and city council for review. 
(b)  Standards of review. 
(1)  A flea market permit applied for hereunder or renewal thereof shall be denied where the application or investigation show any of the following to exist: 
a.  The location of the flea market is not properly zoned; 
b.  The applicant has failed to obtain an occupation tax registration and failed to pay the taxes due in connection therewith; 
c.  The applicant has failed to pay any fee required under this article or has otherwise failed to comply with any of the provisions of this article. 
(2)  A flea market permit applied for hereunder or renewal thereof may be denied where the application or investigation show any of the following to exist: 
a.  The applicant is of bad moral character or has a bad reputation in the community or does not have sufficient mental capacity to conduct the flea market for which application is made; 
b.  The applicant has had any license issued under the police powers of any county or other governmental entity previously suspended or revoked; 
c.  The applicant, as a previous holder or of a license as a flea market promoter, operator, owner or vendor, has violated any law, including this article, relating to such business, within a ten-year period immediately preceding the date of the initial application or renewal application; 
d.  The applicant has supplied false information either upon his application or in any communication with any official of the city relative to his application; 
e.  The application, during the 12-month period next preceding the filing of his application, has engaged in any deceptive business practices; 
f.  A permit hereunder may be denied to any person, partnership or corporation for pecuniary gain where any individual having an interest either as owner, partner, stockholder owning at least 25 percent of the stock of the corporation, such interest being direct or indirect, beneficial or absolute, or his spouse or manager of the operation, shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendere within ten years immediately prior to the filing of said application for any felony or misdemeanor of any state or of the United States or any municipal or county ordinance except traffic violations. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or plea of guilty or nolo contendere, or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime; 
g.  In addition to the requirements of this section and in determining whether or not any flea market permit applied for shall be granted, the following shall be considered in the public interest and welfare: 
1.  If the applicant is a previous holder of a flea market permit, the manner in which he conducted the flea market thereunder, and particularly as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such flea market; 
2.  The location for which the flea market permit is sought as to traffic congestion, general character of the neighborhood and the effect such an establishment would have on the adjacent and surrounding property values; 
3.  If it appears that the applicant's spouse or another person is using the applicant as a guise or dummy to obtain a flea market permit. 
(3)  Nonprofit flea market sales. To provide for community-based fundraising efforts and similar events, nonprofit organizations may apply to the mayor and city council for the following special considerations. Such applications should be made in writing to the mayor and city council: 
a.  City council may waive a portion of all of the required fees for events sponsored by nonprofit groups if they demonstrate that the event benefits a local nonprofit organization that serves residents of the city. 
b.  City council may grant a permit to a nonprofit organization in an O & I zoning district if the group demonstrates that the flea market will not adversely impact the surrounding property owners. In considering such a request for a nonprofit flea market in an O & I zone, the council shall evaluate the impact of the event using the standards governing the exercise of zoning powers as stated in the city's zoning ordinance set forth in chapter 80. 
(c)  Investigation of application. 
(1)  The city administrator or his designee is hereby authorized and directed to make such inspections and conduct such investigations as are necessary to determine satisfactory compliance with the requirements for issuance of a flea market permit contained in this article. 
(2)  All applications for a flea market permit shall be investigated by the police department. Said department shall report its recommendations to the city administrator. The applicant for a flea market permit shall be fingerprinted and shall supply such other information as the police department deems necessary to complete its investigation. 
(d)  Issuance of flea market permit. 
(1)  No flea market permit issued hereunder shall be transferable to any other person or to any other location. 
(2)  Each flea market permit issued hereunder shall be for one location only. Flea market operators shall be required to obtain a separate flea market permit, paying a separate administrative and regulatory fee, for each flea market location. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-87; Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 5-28-1996) 
Sec. 14-169. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  Generally. Condition of soil, groundwater level, drainage and topography shall not create hazards to the property or the health or safety of the occupants. The site shall not be exposed to objectionable smoke, noise, odors or other adverse influences, and no portion subject to unpredictable and/or sudden flooding, subsidence or erosion shall be used for any purpose that would expose persons or property to hazards. 
(b)  Soil and ground cover. Exposed ground surfaces shall be paved, or covered with stone screenings or other solid materials or protected with a vegetative growth that is capable of preventing soil erosion and of eliminating objectionable dust and/or mud. 
(c)  Site drainage requirements. The ground surface shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe, efficient manner in order to eliminate water pockets, low areas or bogs. 
(d)  Traffic. 
(1)  All flea markets shall provide safe and convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets or roads or highways only at curb cuts or locations approved by the city. 
(2)  Access to flea markets shall be designed to minimize congestion and hazards at the entrance or exit and allow free movement of traffic on adjacent streets. 
(3)  The flea market operator shall ensure free movement of other local traffic in the area without the assistance of the police department. If necessary, the operator shall provide private traffic control personnel sufficient to ensure compliance with this requirement. 
(e)  Walks. All flea markets shall provide safe, convenient, durable, all-season, dust free, pedestrian access of adequate width for intended use. Sudden changes in alignment and gradient shall be avoided. 
(f)  Refuse handling. The storage, collection and disposal of refuse in the flea market shall be so conducted as to create no health hazards, rodent harborage, insect breeding areas, accident or fire hazards or air pollution. 
(g)  Insect and rodent control. 
(1)  Extermination. Grounds, buildings and structures shall be maintained free of insect and rodent harborage and infestation. Extermination methods and other measures to control insects and rodents shall conform with the requirements of the county health authority. 
(2)  Accumulation of debris. Flea markets shall be maintained free of accumulations of debris that may provide rodent harborage or breeding places for flies, mosquitoes and other pests. 
(3)  Storage areas. Storage areas shall be so maintained as to prevent rodent harborage; lumber, pipe and other building materials shall be stored at least one foot above ground. 
(4)  Exterior openings. Where the potential for insect and rodent infestation exists, all exterior openings in or beneath any structure shall be appropriately screened with wire mesh or other suitable materials. 
(h)  Growth of weeds, etc., to be controlled. The growth of brush, weeds and grass shall be controlled to prevent harborage of ticks, chiggers and other noxious insects. The growth of grass or other acceptable ground cover shall be maintained at a height of less than nine inches at all times during the year. Flea markets shall be so maintained as to prevent the growth of ragweed, poison ivy, poison oak, poison sumac and other noxious weeds considered detrimental to health. Open areas shall be maintained free of heavy undergrowth of any description. 
(Code 1966, § 14A-88; Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 5-28-1996) 
Sec. 14-170. - Maintaining permanent records. 
(a)  Requirements. 
(1)  Every flea market operator shall maintain a permanent record book updated each day the flea market is open to the public for business. The record shall contain in ink and in legible English: 
a.  The date of business operation; 
b.  The name, age and address of the person, corporation or entity of each flea market vendor in operation on that date, a description of the general appearance of any such person, and the distinctive number from such person's driver's license or other similar identification card;
