(b)  The numbers shall be so placed as to be plainly visible from the street and sidewalk, and if the residence, building or structure is too far from the street and sidewalk for the numbers to be plainly visible on said building, then the number shall be placed on a permanent post or elsewhere near the street and sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 2002-3, § 1(20-77), 4-8-2002) 
Secs. 50-63—50-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC ASSEMBLY 

Sec. 50-110. - Erection of tents for events, gatherings. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to place, locate, install or erect any tent within the corporate limits of the city except as hereinafter provided. For the purpose of this section, the term "tent" shall be construed to mean any temporary or portable structure or shelter made of canvas or other fabric including plastic stretched over poles or supported by air. 
(b)  Any person, company or corporation desiring to locate a tent within the corporate limits of the city shall first make application to the city administrator setting forth the site location, identifying the location of a permanent structure and restroom facilities, the number of attendees anticipated at the event for which the tent is to be used, the location of parking areas and number of parking spaces to be utilized for the event, the size and type of tent to be used including the interior contents and components, and the length of time the tent will be on site. In addition, there shall be a permit fee in the amount established by the city council paid by the applicant on filling. 
(c)  Any tent permitted for installation or erection shall be subject to the requirements set forth in the city's building and zoning regulations. 
(d)  A tent may be installed or erected on: 
(1)  Lots for which there are permanent restroom facilities readily available. No portable restroom facilities will be allowed. 
(2)  Lots for which adequate off-street parking is available to accommodate the anticipated attendees. 
(3)  Lots for which adequate permanent facilities are readily available to provide shelter during a threat of dangerous or inclement weather. 
(e)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the following tents: 
(1)  Camping tents designed for sleeping. 
(2)  Funeral home tents used for temporary cover from the elements during a grave side funeral service. 
(f)  The maximum length of time a tent may be installed on any lot shall be one week per calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 98-19, § 1, 8-8-1998) 
Sec. 50-111. - Passing through streets; permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause to assemble in or upon any street in the city, any congregation of people of 25 or more in number, or cause to induce such congregation of people to pass along, upon, or through any street of the city to a common place called destination, without first obtaining from the city administrator a written permit for such purpose. Application for such permit shall be made in writing, plainly setting forth the character and purpose of the assembly or congregation of people, the time and place at which they desire to assemble, the streets upon which they desire to pass, and their destination. When such application is made, it shall be the duty of the city administrator to inquire into the character and purpose of the assembly or congregation of people, the character of those who desire to meet in, or to pass upon the streets of said city, as herein referred to; and if those desiring to meet or pass upon the streets in the manner herein referred to be of good character and the purpose of the meeting and the use of the streets to be orderly, the city administrator is authorized to grant such permit. Any and all persons who shall assemble in or congregate upon or pass along or upon any public street of said city, as herein referred to, without a permit having been granted for such purpose, shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. 
(Code 1941, § 1223; Code 1966, § 16-2) 
Chapter 53 - TAXATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 53-1—53-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAXES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 53-19—53-39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION 

Sec. 53-40. - Applicability; amount. 
There is herein provided a homestead exemption of $10,000.00 from all city ad valorem taxes for each resident of the city who is 65 years of age or over or who is disabled, if the owner's adjusted gross income does not exceed the sum of $15,800.00 or if the owner's adjusted gross income, together with the adjusted gross income of the owner's spouse, does not exceed the sum of $31,600.00. The value of the residence in excess of the above-exempted amount shall remain subject to taxation. The homestead exemption provided for in this section shall not apply to any ad valorem taxes levied to pay interest on and retire bonded indebtedness. 
(Code 1966, § 22.10; Ord. No. 91-08, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 00-14, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Sec. 53-41. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Adjusted gross income shall have the same meaning as defined in the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1986, 26 USC 1 et seq., as amended from time to time, except that for the purposes of this section, the term "adjusted gross income" shall not include that portion of income or benefits received as retirement, survivor or disability benefits under the Federal Social Security Act or under any other public or private retirement, disability or pension system. 
(Code 1966, § 22.10; Ord. No. 91-08, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 00-14, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Sec. 53-42. - Certificate required. 
In order to qualify for the exemption provided for in this division as being "disabled," the person claiming such exemption shall be required to obtain a certificate from not more than three physicians licensed to practice medicine under O.C.G.A., title 43, ch. 34, relative to medical practitioners, as now or hereafter amended, certifying that in the opinion of the physician such person is mentally or physically incapacitated to the extent that such person is unable to be gainfully employed and that such incapacity is likely to be permanent. 
(Code 1966, § 22.10; Ord. No. 91-08, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 00-14, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Sec. 53-43. - Affidavit required. 
A person shall not receive the homestead exemption granted by this division unless the person or person's agent files an affidavit with the city clerk, or his designee, giving the person's age, or if disabled, the certificate, and the amount of income which the person and the person's spouse received during the last taxable year for income tax purposes, and such additional information relative to receiving such exemption as will enable the city clerk, or his designee, to make a determination as to whether such owner is entitled to such exemption. The city clerk, or his designee, shall provide sufficient forms for this purpose. 
(Code 1966, § 22.10; Ord. No. 91-08, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 00-14, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Sec. 53-44. - Processing of application. 
Applications for homestead exemption provided for in this division shall be processed in the same manner as other applications for homestead exemptions, and the provisions of the law applicable to the processing of homestead exemptions, as the same now exist or may hereafter be amended, shall apply thereto. 
(Code 1966, § 22.10; Ord. No. 91-08, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 00-14, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Sec. 53-45. - Filing of application. 
All applications for homestead exemptions for the current year must be filed with the city clerk, or his designee, on or before April 1 of the year in which the exemption is to be applied. Any person who shall become 65 years of age by April 1 of the year in which the exemption would apply will be eligible to apply for the exemption within the time period set forth in this division. 
(Code 1966, § 22.10; Ord. No. 91-08, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 00-14, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Sec. 53-46. - Continuing exemption. 
After a person has filed the proper affidavit and certificate or certificates, it shall not be necessary to make application and file said affidavit and certificate thereafter for any year and the exemption shall continue to be allowed to such person. It shall be the duty of any such person, however, to notify the city clerk, or his designee, in the event such person becomes ineligible for any reason to receive the homestead exemption granted by this division. 
(Code 1966, § 22.10; Ord. No. 91-08, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 00-14, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Sec. 53-47. - Exemption cumulative. 
The homestead exemption granted by this division shall be cumulative of any other homestead exemptions applicable to the city ad valorem taxes. 
(Code 1966, § 22.10; Ord. No. 91-08, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 00-14, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
Secs. 53-48—53-67. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FREEPORT EXEMPTION 

Sec. 53-68. - Authority for exemption. 
O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.2 authorizes and establishes a procedure for the exemption of certain tangible personal property, commonly known as the freeport exemption, from ad valorem taxation. 
(Code 1966, § 22.11; Ord. No. 91-09, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 95-01, § 1, 1-9-1995) 
Sec. 53-69. - Exemption granted. 
There is hereby exempted all three types of tangible personal property described in this division from ad valorem taxation, including all such taxes levied for educational purposes and for state purposes, at the rate of 100 percent of the value of said property as defined in the aforementioned provision of the state constitution and state law. 
(Code 1966, § 22.11; Ord. No. 91-09, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 95-01, § 1, 1-9-1995) 
Sec. 53-70. - Tangible personal property exempted. 
The exemption provided for in this division shall apply to the following types of tangible personal property: 
(1)  Inventory of goods in the process of manufacture or production which shall include all partly finished goods and raw materials held for direct use or consumption in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business in the state. The exemption provided for herein shall apply only to tangible personal property that is substantially modified, altered or changed in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing, processing or production operations in the state. 
(2)  Inventory of finished goods manufactured or produced within the state in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business when held by the original manufacturer or producer of such finished goods. The exemption provided for herein shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is produced or manufactured. 
(3)  Inventory of finished goods which, on January 1, are stored in a warehouse, dock or wharf, whether public or private, and which are designated for shipment to a final destination outside the state and inventory of finished goods which are shipped into the state from outside the state and stored for transshipment to a final destination outside the state. The exemption provided for herein shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is stored in the state. All property that is claimed to be exempt under the provisions of this subsection shall be designated as being "in transit" upon the official books and records of the warehouse, dock, wharf, whether public or private, where such property is being stored. Such official books and records shall contain a full, true, and accurate inventory of all such property, including the date of the receipt of the property, the date of the withdrawal of the property, the point of origin of the property, and the point of final destination of the same, if known. The official books and records of any such warehouse, dock, or wharf, whether public or private, pertaining to any such "in transit" property, shall be at all times open to the inspection of all taxing authorities of the state and of any political subdivisions of the state. 
(Code 1966, § 22.11; Ord. No. 91-09, § 1, 10-14-1991; Ord. No. 95-01, § 1, 1-9-1995) 
Secs. 53-71—53-98. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LODGING EXCISE TAXES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority for local governments to impose excise taxes on lodging, including campgrounds, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51. 

Sec. 53-99. - Application of section. 
An excise tax is to be charged within the city upon the furnishing for value to the public of any room, lodging, or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the city for operating within the city a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. The tax must not be applied to rooms furnished for one or more days to state or local government officials and employees traveling on official business or to rooms furnished to persons due to the destruction of their home or residence by fire or other casualty. 
(Code 1966, § 22.9; Ord. No. 85-5, § 1, 8-26-1985; Ord. No. 2006-70, § A, 10-23-2006) 
Sec. 53-100. - Territorial limits. 
The tax herein shall apply to all portions of land lying within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 22.9; Ord. No. 85-5, § 1, 8-26-1985; Ord. No. 2006-70, § A, 10-23-2006) 
Sec. 53-101. - Amount of tax; due date. 
The tax is to be levied and collected at the rate of three percent of the charge to the public for the furnishing of rooms, lodgings, or accommodations. The tax collections are to be remitted to the city clerk on a quarterly basis within 30 days following the end of each quarter. The person responsible for collection of the tax shall remit to the city clerk the tax collected during the previous quarter less a three percent collection fee. If remittance of the tax collected is not made within 30 days following the end of the quarter, the person responsible for collecting the tax shall not be allowed to retain the statutory collection fee. 
(Code 1966, § 22.9; Ord. No. 85-5, § 1, 8-26-1985; Ord. No. 2006-70, § A, 10-23-2006) 
Sec. 53-102. - Penalty for delinquent taxes. 
There is hereby imposed a penalty upon the person responsible for collection of the tax, if the tax is not remitted within 30 days following the end of each quarter. The penalty for failure to comply with this article shall be assessed in the amount of ten percent of the tax determined to be due and payable under the provisions of this article for the first 30 days or fraction thereof a delinquency and an additional one percent of the tax determined to be due for each additional month or fraction thereof of delinquency. 
(Code 1966, § 22.9; Ord. No. 85-5, § 1, 8-26-1985; Ord. No. 2006-70, § A, 10-23-2006) 
Sec. 53-103. - Disposition of proceeds. 
The proceeds of this tax shall be used in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(1). 
(Code 1966, § 22.9; Ord. No. 85-5, § 1, 8-26-1985; Ord. No. 2006-70, § A, 10-23-2006) 
Sec. 53-104. - Recordkeeping; records inspection. 
In order to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and to collect all of the tax imposed, all owners or operators are hereby required to keep a record of all sales and charges for rooms and lodging and the taxes collected. The records shall be open for inspection by any duly authorized agent of the city at all reasonable hours during the day. 
(Code 1966, § 22.9; Ord. No. 85-5, § 1, 8-26-1985; Ord. No. 2006-70, § A, 10-23-2006) 
Chapter 56 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 56-1—56-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING 

Sec. 56-19. - When lights required; reflectors. 
Whenever a vehicle is parked on a street during the time between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise, or at any other time when there is not sufficient light to render clearly any vehicle on the street from a distance of 200 feet, there shall be displayed at least one light on each end of such vehicle. Where red glass reflectors are installed on the rear of vehicles, the same may be used without turning on red taillights. Reflectors must be of not less than two inches in diameter. 
(Code 1941, § 1119; Code 1966, § 24-1) 
Sec. 56-20. - Parallel parking; exceptions. 
Except when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs, or traffic signals or orders of a police officer, the driver of a vehicle shall not stop, stand or park such vehicle in any street or roadway other than parallel with the edge of such street or roadway headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curbside wheels of said vehicle within six inches of the edge of the roadway. 
(Code 1941, § 1106; Code 1966, § 24-2) 
Sec. 56-21. - No parking signs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park an automobile or truck or any vehicle propelled by gasoline at any place on any street in the city where there is a yellow curb or a "No Parking" sign. 
(Code 1941, § 1121; Code 1966, § 24-3) 
Sec. 56-22. - Prohibited parking areas. 
When prohibited by this article or other ordinance, no person shall park a vehicle during the hours prohibited at places so indicated by official signs. 
(1)  There shall be no parking on a residential street directly across from another vehicle already parked or within 50 feet of that vehicle; 
(2)  There shall be no on-street parking within any residential cul-de-sac; 
(3)  There shall be no on-street parking within 50 feet of a residential street intersection; and 
(4)  There shall be no parking on a residential street facing in the direction of oncoming traffic. 
(5)  There shall be no parking on a residential street opposite a driveway. 
(Code 1966, § 24-4; Ord. of 4-27-1964; Ord. of 2-13-1967; Ord. No. 68-10, 6-24-1968; Ord. No. 68-14, 9-9-1968; Ord. No. 75-5, 8-25-1975; Ord. No. 88-2, § 2, 7-11-1988; Ord. No. 2004-5, 4-11-2004; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 1, 10-25-2010) 
Sec. 56-23. - Time limitations for parking. 
Where time limitations for parking are imposed by this article or other ordinance, no person shall park a vehicle longer than the hours indicated on official signs posted at such places. 
(Code 1966, § 24-5; Ord. of 4-27-1964; Ord. No. 88-2, § 3, 7-11-1988) 
Sec. 56-24. - Restrictions on parking of vehicles with three or more axles. 
(a)  No motorized vehicle in excess of 7,000 pounds (empty weight), trailer, boat, vehicle not in operating condition or currently licensed, vehicle with more than four wheels, or RV shall be permitted to be parked in front of the main dwelling on a lot in a residential area or neighborhood. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or caused to be parked on any street within the city a truck or trailer which has three or more axles for a period of more than one hour in any one place. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to vehicles making deliveries of goods or merchandise to residents or businesses located in the city or to vehicles temporarily parked for the purpose of loading and unloading household or business goods and furnishings (i.e., moving van type vehicles). 
(Ord. No. 98-08, § 1, 3-10-1998) 
Sec. 56-25. - Impounding of vehicles. 
(a)  Any vehicle parked in the restricted area described in this article for a period of time in excess of two hours, shall be impounded, moved from the street and stored, subject to being claimed by the owner who may obtain said vehicle by the payment of the towing and storage charges. Any officer of the city authorized to enforce traffic regulations and ordinances in the city is hereby authorized to impound said vehicles remaining in said parking area for more than two hours, and to store the same in some off-street parking area, either indoors or out-of-doors. 
(b)  The charges for towing and storage provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall constitute a lien upon the vehicle so impounded in favor of the city, and shall be enforced in the same manner as the collection of taxes. 
(Code 1966, § 24-7; Ord. of 4-27-1964; Ord. No. 93-21, § 2, 11-22-1993) 
Sec. 56-26. - Temporary and emergency parking restrictions. 
Temporary or emergency no parking restrictions may be established and posted by order of the city engineer, fire chief, or police chief. Violations of such restrictions shall be subject to the enforcement and impoundment provisions of section 56-25. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, 5-10-2010) 
Sec. 56-27. - Parking on narrow streets. 
(a)  Placement of signs. The city engineer, at the direction of the city council, shall erect signs prohibiting parking upon any street where it is determined that the width of the roadway may not permit free and unobstructed passage of a vehicle unless such parking is prohibited. 
(b)  Effect of signs. When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized in this section, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of any such sign. 
(c)  [Specific streets. ] Pursuant to the provisions of this code section, parking on the following streets shall be prohibited: 
Belmont Terrace; 
Bluegrass View; 
Horseshoe Lane; 
Trotters Circle; 
Apian Way; 
Horseman Run; 
Jules Trace; 
Seneca Road. 
Fairview Drive, west side, between Estes Street and Barton Street. 
(Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 10-25-2010; Ord. No. 2010-11, § 1, 11-8-2010; Ord. No. 2013-32, § 1, 11-25-2013) 
Sec. 56-28. - Commercial vehicles. 
(a)  No more than one commercial vehicle may be parked on a residential lot overnight (11:00 p.m.—7:00 a.m. eastern standard time or eastern daylight savings time, as appropriate) except in furtherance of a temporary and city permitted construction project upon the residential lot. 
(b)  For the purpose of subsection (a), commercial vehicle shall mean a vehicle that carries or contains commercial or industrial equipment or trade tools on the exterior of the vehicle, including, but not limited to, ladders, power equipment, earth moving equipment, and lawn equipment; or a vehicle on which is painted, drawn, or attached a sign advertising a commercial business or trade, excluding license plates and bumper stickers. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, vehicle means motorized equipment, or nonmotorized equipment designed to be pulled by motorized equipment, designed to travel with persons or cargo upon land, air, or water. Vehicle shall include, without being limited to, cars, automobiles, trucks, trailers, boats, airplanes, motorcycles, golf carts, campers, recreation vehicles and buses. A trailer designed to carry one boat, or up to two motorcycles, or up to two personal watercraft, when loaded, as designed, with one boat, or up to two motorcycles, or up to two personal watercraft, shall be counted as one vehicle for the purpose of this section. Whenever a trailer, designed to be pulled by a car, automobile, or truck, is hitched to a car, automobile, or truck for travel on public roads, the hitched trailer and the car, automobile, or truck shall be considered one vehicle. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided at subsections (a) and (e), or except when being utilized in a temporary, city permitted construction project on the lot in question, it shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle defined below to park overnight as defined at subsection (a) above, and it shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of the residential zone lot in question to knowingly allow to be parked overnight, upon a residential zoned lot, any vehicle meeting any one of the following classifications: 
(1)  A commercial vehicle exceeding 30 feet in length (for purposes of this length restriction, a trailer hitched to a car, motor vehicle, or truck shall be measured as a separate vehicle); 
(2)  A commercial vehicle whose gross vehicle weight rating exceeds 18,000 pounds; 
(3)  A commercial vehicle which sits upon more than two axles; 
(4)  A commercial vehicle which sits, or is designed to sit, upon more than six wheels; 
(5)  A trailer of a tractor trailer or a semi-trailer; 
(6)  Dump truck, wrecker truck, tow truck, auto transportation truck, freight truck, logging truck, dirt-sand-gravel hauling truck, bull dozer, bucket truck, cement truck, crane, forklift, backhoe, track hoe, articulated truck, compactor roller, excavator, front-end loader, motor grader, buses, including school buses. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of a commercial vehicle to park said vehicle overnight (between 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. eastern standard time or eastern daylight savings time, as appropriate) on any public street within the city unless the street is posted with a sign, authorized by the city's police chief, which sign allows or authorizes parking of vehicles overnight. 
(Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 10-25-2010) 
Sec. 56-29. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Where parking has been prohibited under subsection 56-27(c) and it is determined that exceptional circumstances exist warranting consideration of special, temporary parking needs, application for a special use parking permit shall be made to the chief of police, or his designee. 
(b)  Said applications may be submitted only by residents of properties that have addresses on the streets specified in subsection 56-27(c). 
(Ord. No. 2010-12, § 1, 11-22-2010) 
Sec. 56-30. - Limitations on special permit parking. 
(a)  A motor vehicle which displays a valid residential parking permit issued under section 56-29 shall be allowed to stand or park in the residential permit parking area for which the permit has been issued without being limited by the restrictions established in subsection 56-27(c). 
(b)  Such permit does not authorize a motor vehicle to stand or park in any place where or during any time when the stopping, standing, or parking of a motor vehicle is otherwise prohibited by this article, is designated for other uses, or inhibits movement of emergency vehicles. 
(c)  Permit shall be limited to not more than a 24-hour period. 
(d)  Not more than four permits may be issued to the same address within a calendar month. 
(Ord. No. 2010-12, 11-22-2010) 
Secs. 56-31—56-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC SIGNS AND SIGNALS 

Sec. 56-54. - Traffic control devices. 
(a)  The police chief, or his designee, upon approval by resolution of the mayor and council, is authorized to designate and maintain with appropriate control signs, markings and devices after engineering and traffic investigations: 
(1)  Speed zones; 
(2)  Truck routes and streets to be designated specifically to prohibit various classes of trucks; 
(3)  One-way streets and other directional control devices; 
(4)  Freight loading zones and regulations; 
(5)  Parking and no parking zones and regulations thereon; 
(6)  Stop, yield and other right-of-way signs; and 
(7)  Stop signals and other traffic signals. 
(b)  The police chief, or his designee, is authorized to issue written orders designating appropriate traffic control signs, markings and devices after engineering and traffic investigations: 
(1)  Pedestrian crosswalks; 
(2)  Other safety zones for pedestrians; 
(3)  Traffic lanes; and 
(4)  Any other sign, marking or zone necessary for orderly and safe conditions on the streets of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 24-10; Ord. No. 88-2, § 1, 7-11-1988) 
Sec. 56-55. - Schedule of rules and regulations. 
The police chief shall maintain or cause to be recorded a current schedule of all traffic rules, regulations and orders under this article, which records shall be available for inspection by the public. For items listed in section 56-54(a), this schedule, and any amendments thereto, shall become effective only upon approval thereof by ordinance of the mayor and council; and this schedule is hereby incorporated herein and copies thereof shall be available for public inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1966, § 24-10; Ord. No. 88-2, § 1, 7-11-1988) 
Sec. 56-56. - Specifications for traffic control devices. 
All traffic control signs, signals, devices and markings shall conform to specifications in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices adopted by the state transportation board. All signs and signals required hereunder for a particular purpose shall, so far as practicable, be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this Code shall be official traffic control devices of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 24-10; Ord. No. 88-2, § 1, 7-11-1988) 
Sec. 56-57. - Violation by operators of vehicles or pedestrians prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle or any pedestrian to violate or disobey the instructions of any official traffic sign or signal placed in accordance with the provisions of this article, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(Code 1966, § 24-19) 
Secs. 56-58—56-87. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 56-88. - Adoption of state laws. 
The Georgia Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq., are hereby adopted as the traffic code of the city, except those sections which conflict with any sections contained in this Code. 
(Code 1966, § 24-45; Ord. No. 79-4, 9-10-1979) 
Secs. 56-89, 56-90. - Reserved.

Former § 56-89 pertained to prohibited truck routes and derived from Code 1966, § 24-57; Ord. No. 87-2, § 6-8-1987; Ord. No. 92-10, § 1, 10-12-1992. Sec. 56-91. - Speed zones. 
The following speed zones have been established by the city based on an engineering and traffic investigation as prescribed by law: 
(1)  State routes. 
State Route 14 from the south city limits - 150 feet north of Bohannon Road - to Cemetary Street, a distance of 0.60 mile to be zoned for 45 mph. 
State Route 14 from Cemetary Street to Barton Drive, a distance of 0.97 mile to be zoned for 35 mph. 
State Route 14 from Barton Drive to the north city limits - 0.04 mile north of State Route 138, a distance of 0.52 mile to be zoned for 45 mph. 
State Route 74 from the south city limits - 170 feet south of Milam/Landrum Road - to Plantation Road, a distance of 1.10 miles to be zoned for 55 mph. 
State Route 74 from Plantation Road to the exit ramp to S.R. 14, a distance of 1.50 miles to be zoned for 50 mph. 
State Route 92 from the south city limits - 0.25 mile south of Valleybrook Drive - to Poplar Street, a distance of 0.58 mile to be zoned for 45 mph. 
State Route 92 from Poplar Street (M.L. 3.56) to Golightly Street (M.L. 4.46), a distance of 0.90 mile to be zoned for 35 mph. 
State Route 92 from Golightly Street to S.R. 138, a distance of 0.90 mile to be zoned for 45 mph. 
State Route 92 from S.R. 138 to the north city limits at Koweta Road, a distance of 0.66 mile to be zoned for 55 mph. 
State Route 138 from the east city limits - 0.05 mile east of Jonesboro Road - to S.R. 92, a distance of 1.80 miles to be zoned for 55 mph. 
(2)  Signs to be erected by the state department of transportation. 
Azalea Drive from East Campbellton Street to Fayetteville Road, a distance of 0.40 mile to be zoned for 25 mph. 
Bay Street from Senoia Road to a point 0.15 mile north of Clay Street, a distance of 1.00 mile to be zoned for 25 mph. 
Bay Street/Jonesboro Road from a point 0.15 mile north of Clay Street to State Route 138, a distance of 0.56 mile to be zoned for 30 mph.

East Broad Street from Senoia Road to McClarin Road, a distance of 0.75 mile to be zoned for 35 mph. 
Elder Street from State Route 14 to State Route 92, a distance of 0.85 mile to be zoned for 25 mph. 
Fairview Street from Shaw Street to Elder Street, a distance of 0.31 mile to be zoned for 25 mph. 
Fayetteville Road from East Broad Street to Goodson Road, a distance of 1.60 miles to be zoned for 35 mph. 
Howell Avenue from Senoia Road to State Route 74, a distance of 0.33 mile to be zoned for 30 mph. 
Malone Street from Rivertown Road to Washington Street, a distance of 0.30 mile to be zoned for 25 mph. 
Mary Erna Drive from Rivertown Road to Waterboy Road, a distance of 0.60 mile to be zoned for 25 mph. 
McClarin Road from East Broad Street to a point 0.32 mile south of Bohannon Road, a distance of 0.32 mile to be zoned for 45 mph. 
Pine Street from Fayetteville Road to State Route 92, a distance of 0.30 mile to be zoned for 25 mph.

(Code 1966, § 24-59; Ord. No. 90-02, 2-27-1990; Ord. No. 96-03-A, 3-12-1996; Ord. No. 97-02, 1-3-1997) 
State Law reference— Authority for local authorities to establish speed limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. 
Sec. 56-92. - Truck defined; exceptions. 
For purposes of this article, the term "truck" means any motor vehicle having more than two axles; provided, however, the restrictions contained in this article shall not apply to the following motor vehicles, which may have more than two axles: recreational vehicles; municipal emergency vehicles; municipal service vehicles; vehicles being used pursuant to a contract with the city for the provision of municipal services; and buses. 
(Ord. No. 2014-07, § 3, 4-14-2014) 
Sec. 56-93. - Truck routes designated. 
The following streets, roads, drives, and avenues, or portions thereof, as designated below, shall constitute the exclusive truck routes in the city: 
(1)  Interstate 85. 
(2)  US 29/Roosevelt Hwy/State Route 14/W. Broad Street. 
(3)  State Route 74/Senoia Road (Fulton Industrial Boulevard to Fayette County Line) 
4)  Fairburn Industrial Boulevard. 
5)  State Route 92/Campbellton-Fairburn Road. 
(6)  State Route 138 / Bev Engram Parkway. 
(7)  Spence Road/State Route 92 (I-85 south to the city limits). 
(8)  Oakley Industrial Boulevard. 
(9)  Bohannon Road (McLarin to Oakley Industrial Boulevard). 
(10)  Fayetteville Road (I-85 South to the city limits). 
(11)  McLarin Road. 
(12)  Laser Industrial. 
(13)  East Broad Street (Word Street south to McLarin). 
(14)  Impreglon Way. 
(15)  Howell Avenue. 
(16)  Roberts Street. 
(17)  Gullatt Road (US29 to Cleckler). 
(18)  Terminus Drive. 
(19)  Coates Drive. 
(20)  Graham Road. 
(21)  Stalwart Drive. 
(22)  Whitewater Place. 
(23)  Word Street (from E. Broad to Green). 
(Ord. No. 2014-07, § 3, 4-14-2014) 
Sec. 56-94. - Truck travel restricted to truck routes; exceptions. 
It shall be unlawful for a person or business entity to operate or park a truck on any city street, road, drive, or avenue which is not designated as a truck route pursuant to section 56-93 of this article, except under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Any truck may travel via the most direct route possible from a truck route location in the city for the exclusive purpose of local pick up, delivery, repair, or other necessary business, subject to verification of such purpose by destination papers. 
(2)  Any truck owned or operated by a business may travel the most direct route possible from a truck route to the place of said business in the city, provided that this exception shall not apply in cases where businesses are located in districts zoned for residential use. 
(3)  Pursuant to section 56-95 of this article, owners or operators of trucks may be issued a special permit by the police chief, or police chief's designee, allowing off-route travel under special circumstances. 
(4)  Trucks otherwise authorized by a contract with the city to provide municipal services, including, without being limited to, solid waste and yard waste pick up, may operate on non truck route designated streets, roads, drives and avenues. 
(Ord. No. 2014-07, § 3, 4-14-2014) 
Sec. 56-95. - Travel off truck routes; special permit required. 
The city police chief, or police chiefs designee, may, upon application in writing and for good cause shown, issue a special permit, in writing, authorizing the owner or operator of a truck to operate and/or park such specified vehicle on any street, road, drive, or avenue in the city other than those routes listed in section 56-93, provided, further, that said permit may contain such conditions, restrictions, and limitations as are deemed necessary by the police chief or police chiefs designee to protect the public health, safety, and welfare. The fee for such permit shall be $50.00 per truck. Permits may be issued for any period of time not to exceed 30 days. The fee shall be collected by the city as a condition of the issuance of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2014-07, § 3, 4-14-2014) 
Sec. 56-96. - Special permit; grounds for revocation; notice. 
The police chief, or police chiefs designee, may revoke any special permit granted pursuant to this article upon reasonable cause being shown that the holder of the permit has violated the provisions of the permit, or that the public health, safety or welfare is endangered by the continuation of the permit. The holder of the permit shall be given notice of such revocation in writing by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(Ord. No. 2014-07, § 3, 4-14-2014) 
Sec. 56-97. - Appeal from administrative decision. 
Any applicant for or holder of a special permit pursuant to this article, or any resident of the city who is personally and specially affected by the granting, denial, or revocation of such a permit, may appeal the administrative decision of the police chief, or police chiefs designee, to the city administrator. Such appeal must be made in writing within ten days of the administrative decision. All parties to the appeal will be given not less than ten days advance written notice of the date, time and place of the hearing of such appeal. The city administrator's decision on such an appeal shall be in writing and shall be the final decision of the city. Appeals from the city administrator's decision shall be by writ of certiorari to the superior court. 
(Ord. No. 2014-07, § 3, 4-14-2014) 
Sec. 56-98. - Penalties. 
The operator, owner or lessee of any truck in violation of any provision of this article shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, or up to 60 days in jail, or both. 
(Ord. No. 2014-07, § 3, 4-14-2014) 
Secs. 56-99—56-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VEHICLE EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 56-111. - Overloading; seating of passengers. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive the same when such vehicle is so loaded, or when there are in the front seat of such vehicle such number of persons as to interfere with the operator's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle or obstruct the view of the driver to the front or sides of the vehicle. 
(Code 1941, § 1117; Code 1966, § 24-69) 
Sec. 56-112. - Interfering with view of driver. 
It shall be unlawful for any passenger to ride in any vehicle in such a position as to interfere with the driver's view ahead or to the sides or to interfere with the operator's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle. 
(Code 1941, § 1118; Code 1966, § 24-70) 
Secs. 56-113—56-137. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BICYCLES, ROLLER SKATES AND SKATEBOARDS 

Sec. 56-138. - Traffic ordinances apply to persons riding bicycles. 
Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this chapter, except as to special regulations in this Code and except as to those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Ord. No. 2002-3, § 1(20-86), 4-8-2002) 
Sec. 56-139. - Riding on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a district zoned as business. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle on any sidewalk located within the area designated as the downtown tax district. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to roller skate or ride a skateboard on the public streets or on any sidewalk located within the area designated as the downtown tax district. 
(Ord. No. 2002-3, § 1(20-88), 4-8-2002) 
Chapter 59 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 59-1. - Departments consolidated. 
The city water department, sewer department, electric department and stormwater utility department have been consolidated in order to provide economy of operation. The consolidated department shall be known as the city water, sewer, electric and stormwater utility department, and it will also include the city's cable system and sanitation services. 
(Ord. No. 2005-11, § 2(25-12), 5-16-2005) 
Sec. 59-2. - Separate water and electric connections required. 
Each building in which persons work, reside or congregate shall be served by one or more water and electric meters. No water or electric meter may serve more than one building except that: 
(1)  Master water and electric meters may serve two or more separate buildings subject to approval of the mayor and council; provided that properties served by the master meter have the same owner, the owner accepts responsibility for the bill and any other related fees and the owner pays for the water and electric meters necessary to properly serve his property. 
(2)  Master meters may be used to serve individual units within a single building subject to approval of the mayor and council; provided that units served by the master meter have the same owner, the owner accepts responsibility for the bill and any other related fees, and the owner pays for the water and electric meters necessary to properly serve the units. 
(Code 1966, § 25-2; Ord. No. 88-4, § 2, 8-8-1988) 
Sec. 59-3. - Transfer or sale of building connected to master meter. 
If any property sharing service by a master meter is transferred or sold, the new owner shall immediately connect his property to a separate water and electric meter and pay the appropriate fees. 
(Code 1966, § 25-2; Ord. No. 88-4, § 2, 8-8-1988) 
Secs. 59-4—59-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROHIBITED ACTS 

Sec. 59-25. - Unauthorized receipt of utility services. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who, after being notified by representatives of the city that any utility service will be discontinued to such person, nevertheless continues to use or receive such service after it has been discontinued. Each day that the offending party continues to use or receive such unauthorized utility service shall be deemed a new offense of this section. As used in this section, the term "utility service" shall include, but not be limited to, electrical, cable, water, or sewer services provided by the city, its agents, or its franchisees. 
(Code 1941, § 1225; Code 1966, § 25-4) 
Sec. 59-26. - Tampering with meters. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to open or in anywise tamper with any utility meter or meter box along the lines in the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent or in any way interfere with a meter that prevents the meter from properly registering the quantity of utility services supplied. In the absence of evidence to the contrary, the person who interferes with the meter and the person who with knowledge of such violation receives the benefit of such utility service without proper charge as a result of the improper action shall be presumed to be responsible for the act of tampering or diversion. 
(Code 1941, § 1228; Code 1966, § 25-3; Ord. No. 73-1, 1-8-1973; Ord. No. 98-10, § 1, 3-23-1998) 
Sec. 59-27. - Unlawful to break or injure water mains, fireplugs, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to break, injure or in any way damage or interfere with any water main, pump, fireplug, filter plant, sewer or disposal plant or any of their appurtenances in the city or within the jurisdiction thereof. 
(Code 1941, § 1225; Code 1966, § 25-4) 
Sec. 59-28. - Outdoor watering of landscape. 
(a)  Restriction on outdoor water of landscape. Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: 
(1)  Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; 
(2)  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or storm water in compliance with applicable local ordinances and state guidelines; 
(3)  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; 
(4)  Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed waste water; 
(5)  Watering personal food gardens; 
(6)  Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; 
(7)  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soakers hoses; 
(8)  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
(9)  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
(10)  Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
(11)  Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
(12)  Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or 
(13)  Hydroseeding. 
(b)  Enforcement. 
(1)  No person shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in ordinance. 
(2)  The code enforcement officer shall be the enforcement authority for this section. The city administrator may also authorize other departments as may be deemed necessary to support enforcement. 
(3)  Criminal and alternative penalties. Any violation of this section may also be enforced by a citation or accusation returnable to the municipal court or by any other legal means as set forth in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, (§§ 59-28-1, 59-28-2), 4-25-2011) 
Secs. 59-29—59-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BILLING AND COLLECTIONS 

Sec. 59-58. - Electrical and water rates and meter deposits. 
The rates for electricity and water and the amount of meter deposit to be charged consumers shall be as prescribed by the mayor and city council upon a schedule to be maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1966, § 25-1) 
Sec. 59-59. - Monthly billings; failure to pay. 
Bills to customers for electricity, water, sewer, stormwater, cable and internet, and sanitation service charges shall be mailed out on such day of each month as may be determined desirable by the city. Payments must be received at the water and sewer department office of the city, and a failure to receive bills or notices shall not prevent such bills from becoming delinquent nor relieve the customer from payment. The failure of customers to pay electricity, water, sewer, electricity, stormwater, cable or internet service, and sanitation charges duly imposed shall result in the automatic imposition of the penalties of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2005-11, § 3(25-12(a), (d)), 5-16-2005) 
Sec. 59-60. - Late charges; disconnection. 
Nonpayment after the due date will be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the delinquent account as a late charge penalty. Accounts delinquent after the due date are subject to disconnection after notice provided in the city's service rules and regulations. No service shall be reconnected until the customer's delinquent bill, including the late charge penalty and disconnection charges, have been paid in full. Reconnect fees shall be as established by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2005-11, § 3(25-12(b), (c)), 5-16-2005) 
Sec. 59-61. - Application of payments. 
With respect to payments received by the city for utility services, such payments shall be applied to any charges owed in the following priority: 
(1)  Water. 
(2)  Sewer. 
(3)  Stormwater. 
(4)  Cable. 
(5)  Internet. 
(6)  Electricity. 
(7)  Sanitation. 
(Ord. No. 2005-11, § 3(25-12(f)), 5-16-2005) 
Sec. 59-62. - Complaints; adjustments. 
(a)  If the customer believes the amount of his bill to be in error, he shall present his claim in accordance with the city's service rules and regulations before the bill becomes delinquent. Such claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as heretofore provided. The customer may pay such bill under protest and said payment shall not prejudice his claim. 
(b)  The city will make a special water meter reading at the request of a customer for the fee as established by the city council; provided, however, that if such special reading discloses that the meter was overread, no charge will be made. 
(c)  Water meters will be tested at the request of the customer upon payment to the city of the actual costs of conducting the test; provided, however, that if the meter is found to over-register beyond three percent of the correct volume, no charge will be made. 
(d)  If the seal of a meter is broken by other than the city's representative or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the customer shall pay an amount estimated from the record of his previous bills and/or from other proper data. 
(Ord. No. 2005-11, § 4, 5-16-2005) 
Secs. 59-63—59-82. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER SERVICE 

Sec. 59-83. - Water conservation plan. 
(a)  Adopted. There is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference herein the city's water conservation plan, which shall control the delivery and usage of water during periods of emergency. A copy of this plan shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk where it shall be available for public inspection. 
(b)  Authority to implement. The mayor is authorized to implement the relevant provisions of the water conservation plan as he deems necessary in his best judgment and in accordance or with the standards provided in the plan. Upon the mayor's declaring any provision of the water conservation plan to be in effect, notice of such shall immediately be posted in a conspicuous place at city hall. 
(c)  Penalty for violation. Any person violating the provisions of the water conservation plan as implemented by action of the mayor shall be guilty of a violation of this section. Upon conviction thereof, the penalty for the first offense shall be $100.00, and the penalty for the second offense shall be $500.00. Any person convicted of a third offense against the water conservation plan shall be subject to a penalty of not more than $500.00. Upon notice to the city that any person has been convicted for a third offense against the plan, the city may, after giving 24 hours' written notice thereof, terminate water service to such person. 
(Code 1966, § 25-10; Ord. No. 88-1-A, § 1, 7-11-1988) 
Secs. 59-84—59-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRIC SERVICE 

Sec. 59-110. - Application for electrical service; minimum deposits. 
(a)  Application for electrical service shall be made with the city clerk, who shall require a minimum deposit for each consumer in the amount established by the city council. 
(b)  The application for service must be accompanied by a copy of an executed lease or purchaser's closing statement as well as acceptable proof of identification (e.g., driver's license). 
(Ord. No. 98-15, § 1(25-1A(1)—(3)), 6-22-1998) 
Sec. 59-111. - Adjustment of deposit amount. 
Original deposit amounts may be adjusted by the city clerk, if necessary and advisable, after six months of actual service. 
(Ord. No. 98-15, § 1(25-1A(4)—(7)), 6-22-1998) 
Sec. 59-112. - Alternatives to certain cash deposits. 
For all accounts where the deposit required is $500.00 or more, the customer may, in lieu of a cash deposit, file with the city any of the following, provided that any request for a change of an instrument authorized under this section must be accompanied by a transaction and processing fee in the amount established by the city council: 
(1)  A payment bond secured by a licensed security bonding company which has first been approved by the city, and which includes a cancellation clause which gives the city 60 days notice prior to cancellation; or 
(2)  A certificate of deposit assigned to the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-15, § 1(25-1A(8)), 6-22-1998) 
Secs. 59-113—59-137. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SEWER SERVICE 

Sec. 59-138. - Rates. 
There is hereby assessed and levied upon each parcel of real property in the city on which is located a water pipe used for the purpose of channeling water purchased from the city and on which is also located a water pipe line or sewer line connected onto the sewer system of the city, and the owner of the same, a monthly charge for the use and maintenance of the sewer system of the city in an amount established by the city council. The amount of each of said monthly charges shall be payable in cash, and shall constitute a lien upon the real estate. 
(Code 1966, § 25-9; Ord. No. 68-6, 5-13-1968) 
Sec. 59-139. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
BOD 5 (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system carrying sewage that receives discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building's sewer. 
Building sewer (sometimes called house lateral) means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
Chemical oxygen demand (COD): A measure of the oxygen reducing capabilities of wastewater due to chemical reactions. Wastewater with inorganic material (such as chemicals from household cleaners and detergents) can cause chemical reactions that absorb oxygen. If large quantities of these chemicals enter wastewater, chemical reactions occur which consume large amounts of oxygen. If the oxygen level in the water drops too much, fish and other aquatic life may not survive. POTWs can only treat small quantities of COD in wastewater. If COD levels become too high, the wastewater may pass through the POTW only partially treated thus endangering aquatic life in water. 
Commercial-industrial wastes: Any and all other wastes not being domestic wastes but not limited to the wastes from commercial, laboratory and industrial processes, wastes from domestic operations or certain trade operations such as sand, grit, waste petroleum products from automotive service stations, and the like, animal wastes, straw and related items from dairy or other farming operations. 
Commercial use shall apply to any property that is zoned in the city or county for a commercial use or regardless of zoning, is put to a commercial use. 
Customer means the occupant of the property, if no occupant, then the user, if no user, then the owner. 
Department means the city's consolidated utility department. 
Director means the director of the city's consolidated utility department. 
Domestic wastes or wastewaters: (i) Wastewater from normal residential activities including, but not limited to, wastewater from kitchen, bath, and laundry facilities; (ii) Wastewater from the personal sanitary conveniences (toilets, showers, bathtubs, fountains, non-commercial sinks and similar structures) of commercial, industrial or institutional buildings, provided that the wastewater exhibits characteristics that are similar to those of wastewater from normal residential activities; and (iii) Specifically excluded is wastewater from commercial, industrial or institutional laundries or food preparation facilities. 
Existing food service establishment: Any food service establishment, which is not a new food establishment. 
Fat, oil and grease (FOG): A semi-solid, viscous liquid organic polar compound derived from animal and/or plant sources that contain multiple carbon chain triglyceride molecules. These substances are detectable and measurable using analytical test procedures established in 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 136, as may be amended. 
Food service establishment: A commercial facility engaged in preparing and/or serving food for consumption by the public, such as a restaurant, commercial kitchen, caterer, hotel, school, hospital, prison, correctional facility, and care institution. For the purpose of this program, a FSE may or may not be regulated by the county health department. 
Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food and from handling, storage and sale of produce. 
Grease: Grease includes the accumulation of oils, fats, cellulose, starch, proteins, and wax. 
Grease interceptor: A tank that serves one or more fixtures and is remotely located. Such grease interceptors include, but are not limited to tanks that capture wastewater from dishwashers, floor drains, pot and pan sinks and trenches. For purposes of this manual, a grease Interceptor is an outside, underground, multi-compartment tank that reduces the amount of FOG in wastewater prior to discharging into the wastewater treatment system. 
Grease Management (FOG Control Program) Policies and Procedures Manual: The Grease Management (FOG Control Program) Policies And Procedures Manual most recently adopted by the city council or as otherwise amended under section 59-144(p) is the standard operating procedures for control of the discharge of fats, oil and grease into the city wastewater collection system. 
Grease renderer: An organization that will pick-up the collected recyclable grease from the food service operations at little or no charge. The material will then be used in reprocessing for animal feed, tallow, and soap production and in composting. 
Grease trap: A device designed to retain grease from one to a maximum of four fixtures. A grease trap is not appropriate for use on heated water (e.g., dishwasher) or in-line to a waste disposal unit (e.g., garbage disposal and grinders). For purposes of this manual, a grease trap is a small, indoor device. 
Industrial user: A source of discharge, which introduces pollutants into the publicly-owned treatment works from any non-domestic source. 
Liquid waste hauler: Any person, firm, corporation or other entity that collects, pumps, transports and/or disposes of liquid wastes. 
Local limit: A maximum pollutant level placed on wastewater discharged to the city sewer. These local limits are listed in the sewer use ordinance or a permit issued directly to the source that are required to meet all local limits. Cities and towns may impose special local limits on food providers for pollutants such as oil and grease, BOD, and TSS. 
National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES): The national system for the issuance of permits under Section 402 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972. 
Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
New food service establishment: Any food service establishment for which (1) a contract for construction or significant reconstruction has not been entered into prior to the effective date of this article; or (2) new tenant build-out in a pre-existing building which has not commenced prior to the effective date of this article. Generally, significant reconstruction will be presumed to have taken place where the capital cost of the new construction exceeds $50,000.00. 
Non-significant industrial user control mechanism: A written authorization to discharge issued to other than significant industrial users as a pollution prevention measure to minimize pollutant loading by industrial users. 
Oil: Any one or a combination of mineral, vegetable, and synthetic substances and animal and vegetable fats that are used in a variety of processes. 
Outside the city means any water or sewer connection within or without the city where any part of the water is consumed outside the city or any portion of the sewage discharged into the city's system is from or has its point of origin from outside the city limits. 
pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter solution. 
POTW means publicly owned treatment works. 
Program participants include all food service establishments (FSE), multi-family residential complexes and any commercial establishments where it has been determined by the city that the installation of one or more systems is required to prevent the discharge of fats, oils and/or grease into the sewer system in quantities that may adversely affect the operation of the sewer system. 
Properly shredded garbage means the waste from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers with no particle greater than one-quarter inch in any dimension. 
Public sewer means a sewer that is controlled by the city. 
Residential use shall apply to any property that is zoned in the city or county for a residential use, unless the property is being put to a commercial use. 
Sanitary sewer means a pipe or conduit that carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
Sanitary Sewer Overflow (SSO): Overflow of a city sewer often due to a blockage in a line. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency estimates that up to 80 percent of SSOs are caused by oil and grease blockages. Sanitary sewer overflows often result in the release of many thousands of gallons of untreated wastewater. A city will be fined and be subject to many other legal requirements by the State of Georgia if a small quantity of wastewater from an overflow reaches a stream or river. 
Sewage means the water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, institutions and industrial establishments and other places. 
Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
Sewage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
Sewer district means any of the sanitary sewer districts and their extension or extensions and/or any drainage district now existing or subsequently created by the city council. 
Standards and specifications: City of Fairburn Standard Specifications for the Installation of Sanitary Sewer Mains and Services. 
Storm sewer or storm drain means a sewer that carries stormwater and surface water drainage but excludes sewage, commercial-industrial and domestic wastes. 
Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
Total Suspended Solids (TSS): The quantity of solid particles contained in wastewater. Suspended solids from food establishments are a cause for concern for two reasons. Suspended solids are often food particles, which are high in BOD. They may also contribute to blockages in sewer lines or other equipment required to handle the City wastewater e.g. pump stations. 
Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs either continuously or intermittently. 
Wastewater. The liquid and water-carried industrial or domestic wastes and pollutants from dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities and institutions, including hauled liquid waste, and any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present, whether treated or untreated. 
(Code 1966, § 25-21; Ord. No. 76-1, art. I, §§ 1—23, 1-12-1976; Ord. No. 2005-11, § 1, 5-16-2005; Ord. No. 2009-3, § 2, 2-9-2009; Ord. No. 2015-07, §§ 1—3, 7-13-2015) 
Sec. 59-140. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person found to be violating any provision of this article, except section 59-27, shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) of this section, and any person violating section 59-27, shall be guilty of an offense punishable as provided in section 1-15. Each day in which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned by the city by reason of such violation. 
(d)  A failure of the property owner to connect to the sewer service line within the specified time shall authorize the city to discontinue water service to the premises in addition to the penalties otherwise provided for violation of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 25-28; Ord. No. 76-1, art. VIII, §§ 1—4, 1-12-1976) 
Sec. 59-141. - Use of public sewers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. 
(c)  Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)  The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within 90 days after date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within 100 feet (30.5 meters) of the property line and access is available over public land. 
(Code 1966, § 25-22; Ord. No. 76-1, art. II, §§ 1—4, 1-12-1976) 
Sec. 59-142. - Private sewage disposal. 
(a)  Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit from the city. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications, and other information as are deemed necessary by the city. A permit and inspection fee of an amount currently set by the city shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the application is completed to the satisfaction of the city. The city shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the city when the work is ready for final inspection which inspection shall be made within 48 hours (Saturdays and Sundays excluded) of the receipt of notice by a representative of the city. 
(d)  The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division and the county health department. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities unless approval of such method is first obtained from the county health department. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(e)  Within 60 days of the time, a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal filters shall be cleaned of sludge, filled with suitable material and abandoned. 
(f)  The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city, unless arrangements in writing have been made with the city for such operation and maintenance. 
(g)  No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by other authorities having legal jurisdiction. 
(Code 1966, § 25-23; Ord. No. 76-1, art. III, §§ 1—7, 1-12-1976) 
Sec. 59-143. - Building sewers and connections. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenances thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city. 
(b)  There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential and commercial service; and 
(2)  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on forms furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the city. A permit and inspection fee of an amount currently set by the city for a residential or commercial building sewer permit and for an industrial building sewer permit shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(d)  A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(e)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the city, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(f)  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction, the methods used in excavating, placing the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench for building sewers shall all conform to the building code, plumbing code and all other regulations of the city. In cases of conflict and in absence of other provisions, materials and procedures set forth in ASCEWPCF Manual of Practice No. 9 shall govern. All joints of the building sewer shall be tight and waterproof. 
(g)  Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted up by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer at the owners' expense. 
(h)  No person shall make any connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain that in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(i)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code and other applicable rules and regulations of the city. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the city before installation. 
(j)  The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the city before any backfill when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the city or its representatives. 
(k)  All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. Construction shall comply with the provisions of the Federal Occupational, Health and Safety Act, 29 USC 651 et seq. 
(l)  When sewer service is required beyond the existing sewer line, the cost of extending sewer service to the customer's property line at the location of the installation of the stub shall be charged to the customer. A customer requesting service beyond the existing sewer lines shall pay the cost of the line necessary to serve such customer. The city may, at its option, increase the size of the line, and the city will pay for the differences in the cost of the material for increasing the size above that required to serve the customer making such request. 
(Code 1966, § 25-24; Ord. No. 76-1, art. IV, §§ 1—12, 1-12-1976) 
Sec. 59-144. - Regulation of use of the public sewers. 
(a)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any sanitary wastewaters or polluted industrial waters or wastes into any storm sewer. 
(c)  Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the city. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the city, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(d)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewers: 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard in the receiving waters or the sewage treatment plant, including but not limited to cyanides in excess of two mg/l as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer. 
(3)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or a pH higher than 9.5, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works. 
(4)  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(e)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the city that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming an opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the city will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage and other pertinent factors. The substances prohibited are: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit (65 degrees Centigrade). 
(2)  Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease, or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 degrees and 150 degrees Fahrenheit (zero and 65 degrees Centigrade). 
(3)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower (1.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the city. 
(4)  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions, whether neutralized or not. 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, and similar objectionable or toxic substances, or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the city for such materials. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste- or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the city as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters. 
(7)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the city in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(8)  Materials that exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fuller's earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate). 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions). 
c.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works. 
d.  Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting slugs as defined herein. 
(9)  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amendable to treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(f)  If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in subsection (e) of this section, and which may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the city may:
