(1)  Reject the waste; 
(2)  Require deregulation or other control over the quantities and rates of discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing sewer charges under the provisions of subsection (l) of this section; or 
(4)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition to the city, the waters or wastes before discharge to the public sewers. 
(g)  If the city permits: 
(1)  The pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the city, and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances, and laws. 
(2)  A discharger subject to federal regulations set forth in 40 CFR 128 to connect to the public sewers, the discharger shall be required to comply with all pretreatment requirements of that regulation. 
(h)  Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the city, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the city, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(i)  Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(j)  When required by the city, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole, together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the sewer, to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manholes, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(k)  All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with those test procedures for analysis of pollutants which are cited and described in 40 CFR 136 of the Federal Register, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. (The particular analyses involved will determine whether a 24-hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from 24-hour composites of all outfalls whereas pHs are determined from periodic grab samples.) 
(l)  Persons wishing to discharge wastewaters to the city's sanitary sewerage system in amounts exceeding the volume of water purchased from the city, must receive written permission from the city before discharging the excess amounts. The city shall require the installation of additional meters or other devices as may be deemed necessary to establish the volume of wastewater discharged. The corrected metered flow will be used for sewerage billing. All such additional facilities shall be provided by the owner of the premises concerned at no expense to the city. 
(m)  Where it can be shown to the satisfaction of the city that a portion greater than 50 percent of the water purchased as measured by the water meter or meters does not enter the sanitary sewerage system, the city may require or shall permit the installation of additional meters or other devices as may be deemed necessary to establish that portion which does enter the sanitary sewerage system, and the corrected metered flow will be used for sewerage billing. All such additional facilities shall be provided by the owner of the premises concerned or other interested parties at no expense to the city. 
(n)  No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor, by the industrial concern. 
(o)  Where BOD and/or suspended solids in excess of normal concentration are found to be compatible with the sewerage system by the city, the persons discharging such wastes shall be charged and assessed a surcharge in addition to any sewer service charges. Normal concentrations for these constituents are defined as follows: 
(1)  A five-day, 20-degree Centigrade biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) of 250 milligrams per liter as determined by laboratory analysis in accordance with subsection (k) of this section. 
(2)  A suspended solids content of 300 milligrams per liter as determined by laboratory analysis in accordance with subsection (k) of this section. 
The amount of such surcharge shall reflect the cost incurred by the city in handling the excess constituents to include but not be limited to operation and maintenance, administration, depreciation, amortization and other expenses attributable to the sewerage system. 
(p)  All new and existing food service establishments as well as multi-residential complexes and other program participants are required to comply with the City of Fairburn Grease Management (FOG Control Program) Policies and Procedures Manual most recently adopted by the city council. The Grease Management (FOG Control Program) Policies and Procedures Manual may be amended by appropriate city departments from time to time. The purpose of the program is to reduce discharges of fats, oil and grease from program participants into the wastewater collection system in order to reduce and prevent sewer system overflows. All program participants will be periodically inspected by the city to ensure compliance with the program requirements. The city will establish a monthly fee which will be added to program participant's sewer bills to recover the cost of the program. The fee will be included in the city's fee schedule. No fee shall be charged to any FSE that prepares, on average, less than ten full meals per month. An annual commercial waste permit will be required for all pretreatment systems existing and new. The permit fee is based on the type of pretreatment system at the facility. All commercial waste permits shall be issued annually from January 1 thru March 31. An existing facility obtaining a permit after March 31 will be charged a 25 percent penalty fee. A new facility opening after the annual permit period will not pay a penalty unless it has been determined by the city that the facility has been opened for more than 30 days. There will be no prorated fee for a new facility applying for a commercial waste permit after the permitting period. The fee will be included in the city's fee schedule. 
(Code 1966, § 25-25; Ord. No. 76-1, art. V, §§ 1—13, 1-12-1976; Ord. No. 2009-4, § 2, 2-9-2009; Ord. No. 2015-07, § 4, 7-13-2015) 
Sec. 59-145. - Powers and authority of inspectors. 
(a)  The city superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. The superintendent or his representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(b)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the superintendent or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company. 
(c)  The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Code 1966, § 25-27; Ord. No. 76-1, art. VII, §§ 1—3, 1-12-1976) 
Sec. 59-146. - On-site sewage treatment system management. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Absorption field means a configuration of absorption trenches installed in a portion of land and used for the absorption and final treatment of sewage. 
Absorption line means a pipeline of perforated pipe laid in an absorption trench to serve as a conduit for sewage effluent. 
Alternative on-site management system means any approved on-site sewage management system that differs in design or operation from the conventional or chamber septic tank system or privy. 
Approved or approval means compliance with the applicable specifications or criteria developed or accepted by the city administrator. 
Failure means a condition of an on-site sewage system that constitutes a public hazard by inadequate treatment or disposal of sewage. 
Malfunctioning system is an on-site sewage management system that permits sewage to discharge or flow from it into any storm, drain, stream, water body, gutter, street, roadway, or public place, or if sewage discharges from the system to the surface or subsurface of any property so as to create a nuisance or a condition detrimental to health. Substantial backflow from the leaching area (absorption lines) into the tank during a tank pump-out shall also be considered an indication of a malfunctioning system as determined by a registered and certified service person employed by a septic system service company registered with the county. 
On-site sewage management system means a sewage management system other than a publicly owned and maintained sewage treatment system serving one or more buildings, mobile homes, recreational vehicles, residences, or other facilities designed or used for human occupancy or congregation. The term "on-site sewage management system" shall include, without limitation, conventional and chamber septic tank systems, privies, and experimental and alternative on-site management systems that are designed to be physically incapable of a surface discharge of effluent that may be approved by the state division of public health. 
Septic tank means an approved watertight tank designed or used to receive sewage from a building sewer and to effect separation and organic decomposition of sewage solids, and discharging sewage effluent to an absorption field or other management system. 
Sewage means and includes human excreta, all water-carried wastes, and liquid household waste from a residence or commercial and industrial establishments. 
Sewage treatment system is a system that provides primary treatment and disposal, including absorption field components, devices, and appurtenances intended to be used for the disposal of sewage by soil absorption. The system shall be designed to be physically incapable of a surface discharge of effluent. 
(b)  Routine inspection, maintenance, repair, and reporting. 
(1)  The on-site sewage management systems (herein "septic systems") within the city shall be regularly serviced as required in this section. 
(2)  Required servicing of septic systems must include both inspection of the septic system components and pumping of the septic system's tanks. The maximum service interval for required septic system service shall not exceed five years from the date of the last certified inspection and service. 
(3)  Septic tank and absorption field and line inspection, maintenance service, pump-out and repairs shall be conducted by a septic tank contractor and service personnel certified by the state and registered with the county health department. 
(4)  Property owners who install, or inspect and service, their septic tanks shall record their service history on the city's septic tank guide and maintenance record file or suitable alternative. Any qualifying certified service will establish the beginning of the five-year interval. 
(5)  Upon completion of the installation, required inspection, maintenance, and any necessary repair to the septic system, the contractor shall certify that the work was conducted and completed in accordance with the accepted professional standards and practices and that the system is in property working order. 
(6)  No building permit for renovation or modification shall be issued on any existing residential structure that is not in compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Service requirements; extensions. 
(1)  Requests for extensions to any deadline or time period identified within this section should be directed to the city administrator in a timely manner so as not to violate the design of this section. A property owner's intent to petition the city administrator for an extension on an impending deadline will not be deemed an excuse for failure to comply with the timeframes herein. 
(2)  Once a property owner's petition has been taken under consideration by the city administrator, however, no penalty or further violation will accrue until the matter is decided, unless the violation is identified as creating a threat to public health and safety. 
(3)  In the event that the septic system malfunctions during the time that a petition for extension is before the city administrator, the property owner must immediately remedy the septic system malfunction and withdraw the petition from further consideration. 
(d)  Record maintenance. The on-site sewage management system owner shall be responsible for maintaining current records of installation, maintenance, and inspections. 
(e)  Malfunctioning systems. 
(1)  An on-site sewage management system shall be deemed to be a malfunctioning system if sewage is allowed to discharge or flow from it onto the property, into any storm drain, stream, water body, gutter, street, roadway or public place, or if sewage discharges from the system to the surface or subsurface of any property so as to create a nuisance or a condition detrimental to health. Substantial backflow from the leaching area (absorption lines or field lines) into the tank during a tank pump-out shall also be considered an indication of a malfunctioning system as determined by a registered and certified service person employed by a septic system service company registered with the county. 
(2)  In addition, any and all parts of a septic system that are found by a registered and certified service person employed by a septic system service company registered with the county to be damaged, misaligned, or missing (such as, but not limited to, a cracked lid, missing "T," or misaligned outflow line) shall constitute a malfunctioning system. 
(3)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, all property owners with septic systems or other approved on-site sewage management systems shall be responsible for correcting the malfunctioning of such systems within 30 days from receipt of written notification, which notice shall communicate the specifics of the malfunction. Reporting of repairs shall be consistent with subsection (b) of this section. 
(f)  Basis for extensions. Extensions to modify the five-year reporting and servicing requirement as specified in subsection (b) of this section may be granted under the following conditions: 
(1)  The owner of a septic system may required an administrative extension, demonstrating unusual hardship and unique circumstantial basis for approval. If the request indicates that the septic system can be serviced at an interval longer than five years, and the owner certifies the information submitted with the request is accurate, then the extension may be submitted for approval by the city administrator. Extensions are valid for a period of one year, subject to renewal upon requalification. 
(2)  Examples of consideration for an extension may include, but are not limited to: 
a.  Usage significantly less than capacity of system. 
b.  No full-time occupancy. 
c.  Advanced technology septic system. 
(Ord No. 2007-5, § 1, 4-9-2007) 
ARTICLE VII. - PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY 
DIVISION 1. - DECLARATION OF FINDINGS AND PURPOSE, SCOPE, DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 59-147. - Intent and purpose. 
The City of Fairburn, Georgia (the "city") is vitally concerned with the use, construction within, and occupancy of all rights-of-way in the city as such rights-of-way are a valuable and limited resource which must be utilized to promote the public health, safety, welfare, and economic development of the city and to protect public work infrastructure. Therefore, the city, under the authority of the Laws and Constitution of the State of Georgia, including but not limited to Article 9, Section 2, paragraphs 1, 2, and 3 of the Georgia Constitution, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2 and O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92, has adopted this article for the purpose of regulating public and private entities which use the city's rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-148. - Scope. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to all utilities and facilities occupying the rights-of-way as provided herein where such provisions are not already agreed upon through pole attachment agreement, joint use agreement, or other such separate contract between the utility and the city. If such provision is discussed and mutually agreed upon through such agreement, the provision of the agreement shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-149. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations have the meanings set forth herein. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and "may" is permissive. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. Defined terms remain defined terms whether or not capitalized. 
City means the City of Fairburn, Georgia. 
City administrator means the city administrator of the city, or his or her designee. 
City council means the legislative governing body of the city. 
Codified ordinances means the codified ordinances of the city. 
Construct means, but shall not be limited to, dig, bore, tunnel, trench, excavate, obstruct, install wires, install conduit, install pipes, install transmission lines, install poles, install or remove signs, or install or remove facilities, other than landscaping or ornamental plantings, in, on, above, within, over, below, under, or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construct shall also include the act of opening and/or cutting into the surface of any paved or improved surface that is any part of the right-of-way. 
Construction means, but shall not be limited to, the act or process of digging, boring, tunneling, trenching, excavating, obstructing, installing wires, installing conduit, installing pipes; installing transmission lines, installing poles, installing or removing signs, or installing or removing facilities, other than landscaping or ornamental plantings, in, on, above, within, over, below, under, or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construction shall also include the act of opening, boring and/or cutting into the surface of any part of the right-of-way. 
Emergency means a condition that poses a clear and immediate danger to life, health, or safety of a person, or of significant damage or loss of real or personal property. 
Excavation means any work in the surface or subsurface of the public right-of-way, including, but not limited to opening the public right-of-way, installing, servicing, repairing or modifying any facility in or under the surface or subsurface of the public right-of-way, and restoring the surface and subsurface of the public right-of-way. 
Facilities representative(s) means the specifically identified agent(s)/employee(s) of a utility who are authorized to direct field activities of that utility and serve as official notice agent(s) for facilities related information. 
Facility or facilities means any tangible thing, including but not limited to poles, wires, mains, towers, optical fibers, cables, electrical conductors, conduits, ducts, innerducts, pipes, subways, manholes, fixtures, traffic or other signals, appliances, other equipment, appurtenances and future technology of any utility in, on, along, over, or under any part of the rights-of-way within the city. 
FCC means the Federal Communications Commission or any successor thereto. 
Joint use means the occupancy, or reservation of space to the extent allowed by law, on a pole by both the owner and the utility. 
Licensee means a utility that has a valid service agreement issued by the city or state pursuant to law, or a utility that has entered into an agreement with the city that allows such utility to operate or provide service within the geographic limits of the city. 
Make-ready work means the work required to accommodate utility's attachments on a city-owned pole, including, but not limited to, rearrangement or transfer of existing attachments and the facilities of other entities, inspections, engineering work, tree trimming (other than tree trimming performed for normal maintenance purposes), and pole relocation and replacement. 
Permit means an authorization which grants permission to conduct specific regulated activities on, in, over, under, or within any public right-of-way, and which may be subject to conditions specified in a written agreement with the city or in a related provision of the City's Code of Ordinances. 
Registration means an authorization which grants permission to continue conducting specific regulated activities on, in, over, under, or within any public right-of-way, and which may be subject to conditions specified in this article, including those conditions related to right-of-way encroachment permits, conditions specified in a written service agreement with the city, or conditions specified in a related provision of this Code of Ordinances. 
Right(s)-of-way means the surface and space in, on, above, within, over, below, under, or through any real property in which the city has an interest in law or equity, whether held in fee, or other estate or interest, or as a trustee for the public, including, but not limited to any public street, boulevard, road, highway, freeway, lane, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, or any other place, area, or real property owned by or under the legal or equitable control of the city, now or hereafter, that consistent with the purposes for which it was dedicated, may be used for the purposes of constructing, operating, repairing, or replacing facilities. Rights-of-way shall not include buildings, parks, bridges, river, tunnel, viaduct, conduit, or other public property or easements that have not been dedicated to compatible uses, except to the extent the use or occupation of such property is specifically granted in a permit or by law. Rights-of-way shall not include private easements or public property, except to the extent the use or occupation of public property is specifically granted in a written approval of permit. 
Service(s) means the offering of any service by a utility for a fee directly to the public, or to such classes of users as to be effectively available directly to the public, or alternatively, the provision of any service by a utility between two or more points for a proprietary purpose to a class of users other than the general public. 
Service agreement means a valid license agreement, service agreement, franchise agreement, or operating agreement issued by the city or state pursuant to law and accepted by a utility, or entered into by and between the city and a utility, which allows such utility to operate or provide service within the geographic limits of the city. 
Street or streets means the surface of, as well as the spaces above and below, any and all the streets, alleys, avenues, roads, bridges, tunnels and public places of the city within the corporate limits of the city, as the same now exist or may be hereafter extended or altered, and any location thereon, thereover, or thereunder, and any portion thereof. 
Transfer means the disposal by the utility, directly or indirectly, by gift, assignment, sale, merger, consolidation, or otherwise, of more than 50 percent at one time of the ownership or controlling interest in the facilities, or more than 50 percent cumulatively over the term of a written approval of permit of such interests. 
Underground facilities means all lines, cables, conduits, pipes, posts, tanks, vaults, wires, and any other facilities which are located wholly or partially underneath rights-of-way. 
Unused facilities means facilities located in the rights-of-way which have remained unused for 12 months and for which the utility is unable to provide the city with a plan detailing the procedure by which the utility intends to begin actively using such facilities within the next 12 months, or that it has a potential purchaser or user of the facilities who will be actively using the facilities within the next 12 months, or, that the availability of such facilities is required by the utility to adequately and efficiently operate its facilities. 
Utility or utilities means any privately, publicly, or cooperatively owned systems for producing, transmitting, or distributing communication, data, information, telecommunication, cable television, video services, power, electricity, light, heat, gas, oil, crude products, water/sewer, steam, fire and police signals, traffic control devices, and street lighting systems, and housing or conduit for any of the foregoing, which directly or indirectly serve the public or any part thereof. The term "utility" may also be used to refer to the owner, operator, utility, servicer, contractor, sub-contractor, or any agent thereof, of any above-described utility or utility facility. 
Working day means any Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, or Friday, excluding legal holidays observed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
DIVISION 2. - RIGHTS-OF-WAY REGISTRATION 

Sec. 59-150. - Administration. 
The city administrator or his/her designee shall be the city official responsible for the administration of this article except as otherwise provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-151. - Occupancy registration and right-of-way use permit required. 
(a)  Each utility who occupies, uses, or has facilities in the rights-of-way at the time of passage of this article, including by lease, sublease, or assignment, to operate facilities located in the rights-of-way, unless specifically exempted by state or federal law, or these codified ordinances, shall file a registration statement with the city administrator within 90 days of the effective date of this article. 
(b)  A utility that is registering under this division for the first time shall pay a registration fee in the amount set by the city administrator. A fee schedule shall be available at the offices of the city administrator and the city clerk and open for public inspection. 
(c)  Following the effective date of this article, each utility who seeks to occupy, use, or have facilities located in any rights-of-way under the control of the city, unless specifically exempted by state or federal law, or these codified ordinances, shall notify the city of construction and obtain a right-of-way encroachment permit. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-152. - Registration procedure. 
The registration information provided by a utility to the city shall be on a form approved by the city and shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The name, legal status (i.e. partnership, corporation, etc.), street address, e-mail address, telephone and facsimile numbers, and the Utility Protection Center ID number of the utility filing the registration statement (the "registrant"). If the registrant is not the owner of the facility to be installed, maintained, or repaired in the right-of-way, the registration shall include the name, street address, e-mail address, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the owner; 
(2)  The name, street address, e-mail address, and telephone and facsimile numbers of one or more facilities representative(s). Current information regarding how to contact the facilities representative(s) in an emergency shall be provided at the time of filing a registration and shall be updated as necessary to assure accurate contact information is available to the city at all times; 
(3)  A copy, if requested, of the utility's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the Georgia Public Service Commission and/or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements; and 
(4)  A copy, if requested, of the service agreement, if applicable, or other legal instrument that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the right-of-way for the purpose described in the registration. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-153. - Incomplete registration. 
If a registration is incomplete, the city administrator shall notify the Registrant and shall provide a reasonable period of time in which to complete the registration. If a registration is complete, the city administrator shall so notify the utility in writing. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-154. - Acceptance of registration. 
Acceptance of the registration shall not convey title in the rights-of-way. Instead, acceptance is only the nonexclusive, limited right to occupy rights-of-way in the city for the limited purposes stated therein. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from obtaining permits required by city ordinances, or from obtaining appropriate access or pole attachment agreements before using the facilities of others, including those of the city. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from notifying the city of construction and obtaining a valid right-of-way encroachment permit as otherwise required herein. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-155. - Facilities in place without registration. 
Beginning one year after the effective date of this article, any facilities or part of a facility found in a right-of-way for which registration and/or a right-of-way encroachment permit is required but has not been obtained, unless specifically exempted by law, and for which no valid service agreement exists with the city, may be deemed to be a nuisance and an unauthorized use of the rights-of-way. The city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity, including, but not limited to: abating the nuisance; taking possession of the facilities; evicting the utility from the rights-of-way; prosecuting the violator; and/or any other remedy provided by city ordinance or otherwise allowed in law or in equity. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
DIVISION 3. - NOTIFICATION OF CONSTRUCTION AND RIGHT-OF-WAY ENCROACHMENT PERMITS 

Sec. 59-156. - Notification to city and permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any utility to excavate or to construct, install, maintain, renew, remove, or relocate facilities on, along, over, or under the rights-of-way in the city, or to perform any construction adjacent to the rights-of-way in the city that require tree trimming within the rights-of-way, unless the utility provides prior written notice to the city administrator and obtains a valid right-of-way encroachment permit from the city in accordance with the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-157. - Permit procedure. 
Right-of-way encroachment permits shall be obtained from the city administrator (or such other person as the city administrator may designate) according to the notification procedure set forth herein. The written notification, together with all applicable fees, shall be submitted on official forms prescribed by the city, and shall specifically include: 
(1)  The name and address of the utility; 
(2)  The nature, extent, and location of any work proposed to be done, along with satisfactory plans as attachments showing in detail the location of the proposed facility or operations as described in the permit application. The plans shall show the size or capacity of facilities to be installed, their relationship to street features such as right-of-way lines, pavement edge, structures, etc., horizontal and vertical clearance to critical elements of the roadway, and any other information necessary to evaluate the impact on the street and its operation; 
(3)  The name and address of the person or firm who is to perform such work; 
(4)  The name, street address, e-mail address, and telephone and facsimile numbers of one or more facilities representative(s); 
(5)  The projected dates for the work to be started and finished; 
(6)  The estimated cost of the project; 
(7)  An indemnity bond or other acceptable security in an amount to be set by the city to pay any damages to any part of the city road system or to any member of the public caused by work of the utility performed under authority of the permit issued; 
(8)  A copy, if requested, of the utility's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the Georgia Public Service Commission and/or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements; 
(9)  A copy, if requested, of the service agreement, if applicable, or other legal instrument that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the right-of-way for the purpose described in the registration; 
(10)  A permit application fee in the amount set by the city administrator. A fee schedule shall be available at the offices of the city administrator and the city clerk and open for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-158. - Permit to attach. 
Any utility desiring to attach to city-owned poles must submit a permit (Exhibit A) to the city specifying the type of existing and proposed facilities to be attached to city's poles. If the existing pole is insufficient for the existing and proposed new facilities, the city shall rebuild the pole/poles to accommodate utility's upgraded facilities. For a pole erected to replace such joint use pole solely because the existing pole is of insufficient height or strength to provide adequately for utility's requirements, and where such joint use pole at time of erection or by attachment thereto by utility had been previously pronounced satisfactory, then utility shall thereupon pay to the city the reasonable cost of the replacement pole, including transfers and rearrangements of the city and the cost of removal of the old pole, less salvage. Upon utility's request, city shall provide utility with documentation to support city's cost demand. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-159. - Permit fees. 
For utilities subject to an existing service agreement, permit or other fees may be established therein. Fees shall otherwise be set by the city administrator in accordance with the Georgia Department of Transportation's utility accommodation policy and standards, and any other applicable laws that exist now or may be enacted in the future, subject to approval by the city council. Annual fees for long distance and trunk communications cables (those cables not subject to local franchise fees) are hereby set in accordance with the applicable rules of the Georgia Department of Transportation at a rate equal to the maximum fees permitted under the applicable rule promulgated by the Georgia Department of Transportation. A fee schedule for all other fees shall be available at the offices of the city administrator and the city clerk and open for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-160. - Issuance of permit. 
If the city administrator, or the city administrator's designee, determines that the applicant has satisfied the following requirements, the city may issue a right-of-way encroachment permit: 
(1)  That the issuing of the permit will be consistent with the provisions of this article; 
(2)  That the applicant has submitted a complete permit application and has secured all necessary certificates and other authorizations required by law, if applicable, in order to construct facilities in the manner proposed by the applicant; and 
(3)  That the impact on safety, visual quality of the streets, traffic flow, and other users of the rights-of-way, and the difficulty and length of time of the project, construction, or maintenance is minimal or otherwise acceptable. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-161. - Emergency situations. 
(a)  Each utility shall, as soon as reasonably practicable, notify the city administrator of any event regarding its facilities which it considers to be an emergency. The utility may proceed to take whatever actions are necessary in order to adequately respond to the emergency. A utility who engages in an emergency excavation shall take all reasonable precautions to avoid and/or minimize damage to any existing facilities. 
(b)  In the event that the city becomes aware of an emergency regarding utility facilities, the city may attempt to contact the representative of the affected utility or facilities. The city may take whatever action it deems necessary in order to respond to the emergency, including cutting or moving any of the wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances, or other parts of the facilities. The city shall not incur any liability to the utility for such emergency actions, and the cost of such shall be paid by each utility affected by the emergency. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-162. - Make-ready construction. 
If make-ready work is required before a utility can place its attachments on a city-owned pole, the city shall provide an estimate of the cost of such work and the amount which the utility shall be responsible for. Upon utility's approval of the estimated cost of make-ready work, the city shall complete the make-ready work in a reasonable time and promptly notify the utility in writing or by electronic means when the make-ready work is completed. If a third party must move its attachments in order for utility to place its attachments on a pole, the utility shall pay the third party's reasonable transfer costs. Utility shall reimburse city for the actual costs of make-ready work. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-163. - Locate requests required. 
(a)  As provided in O.C.G.A § 25-9-6 (the "Georgia Utility Facility Protection Act") and other applicable state law currently in place or as amended, no utility shall commence, perform, or engage in blasting or in excavating with mechanized excavating facilities unless and until the utility that planning the blasting or excavating has given 48 hours' notice by submitting a locate request to the Utility Protection Center, beginning the next business day after such notice is provided, excluding hours during days other than business days. 
(b)  All utility work must conform to the latest versions of the National Electric Code and National Electric Safety Code, or more stringent standards generally applicable in the City or in a permit or agreement, as applicable. Vertical and horizontal clearances of utility facilities must comply with National Electric Safety Code standards, or more stringent standards generally applicable in the city or in a permit or agreement, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
DIVISION 4. - CONDITIONS OF STREET OCCUPANCY 
Failure to comply with the terms and conditions set forth in this article may result in revocation of registration and permits and the removal of facilities from the rights-of way. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 

Sec. 59-164. - Adoption of the Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards manual. 
The 2009 Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards manual, including all references contained therein to codes, rules, regulations, schedules, forms and appendix items, except Appendix B (Permit Forms and supporting Documents), promulgated by the State of Georgia Department of Transportation, as may be amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in this article as if fully set forth herein, subject to the amendments and modification contained in this article. A copy of the manual is available on line and is also available at the offices of the city administrator or his designee and open for public inspection. Any conflicts between the provisions of this article and the manual shall be resolved in favor of the manual. References to state personnel, agencies, and fees shall be interpreted, where required, as meaning the City of Fairburn municipal equivalents. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-165. - Maintenance of facilities 
Utility shall maintain its facilities in a neat and orderly fashion so as to eliminate unsightly and/or hazardous conditions. This shall include, but not be limited to, the elimination of hanging or dangling wire, wire or cable laid directly on the surface of the ground, open pedestals, cabinets or other fixtures containing wire or other facilities, or other conditions identified by the city and notified to the utility. Once notified of unacceptable conditions, the utility shall have 30 days to correct such conditions and bring them into compliance. Failure to do so shall constitute a violation and be subject to the remedies as described in section 59-185, Use restrictions; violations. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-166. - Protection of traffic and roadway. 
Unless specifically provided for in the permit, then in conformance with city policy, no utility may occupy the city rights-of-way unless sufficient space is available so that the free flow and safety of traffic and other capacity considerations are not unduly impaired, and the installation does not prevent the city from reasonably maintaining the streets, structures, traffic control devices, and other appurtenant facilities, and further provided that maintenance and operations of the facilities do not jeopardize the traffic, street structure, other users of the right-of-way, or the right-of-way itself. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-167. - Grading. 
If the grades or lines of any street within the city right-of-way are changed at any time during the term of the permit and this change involves an area in which the utility's facilities are located, then the utility shall, at its own cost and expense and upon the request of the city upon at least ten business days' notice, protect or promptly alter or relocate the facilities, or any part thereof, so as to conform with such new grades or lines. In the event the utility refuses or neglects to so protect, alter, or relocate all or part of the facilities, the city shall have the right to break through, remove, alter, or relocate all or any part of the facilities without any liability to the utility, and the utility shall pay to the city the costs incurred in connection with such breaking through, removal, alteration, or relocation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-168. - Installation of poles and other wireholding structures and relocation. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided in a valid service agreement, no placement of any pole or wireholding structure of the utility is to be considered a vested interest in the right-of-way, and such poles or structures are to be removed, relocated underground, or modified by the utility at its own expense whenever the city determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. The facilities shall be so located and installed as to cause minimum interference with the rights and convenience of property owners. 
(b)  Upon determination by the city that it is in the public interest to do so, the utility will be required to jointly use poles located within the public rights-of-way. Issuance of a permit may be dependent upon the cooperation of utility companies in the joint use of poles. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-169. - Indemnification. 
As a condition precedent for obtaining a permit, the utility shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless the city and its officers, employees, representatives, or agents against any and all claims, liabilities, losses damages, demands, actions, causes of action, costs, and expenses of whatever nature, which may result from any injury to, or the death of, any persons or from the loss of, or damage to, property of any kind or nature, when such injury, death, loss, or damage arises out of the construction, operation, maintenance, repair, removal, or relocation of the facilities covered by the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-170. - Consequential damages. 
As a condition precedent for obtaining a permit, the utility shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless the city and its officers, employees, representatives or agents against any and all claims or litigation arising from any construction activities within the public rights-of-way, including but not limited to vehicular damage caused by such disruption to the rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
DIVISION 5. - RESTORATION OF PROPERTY 

Sec. 59-171. - Generally. 
Each utility shall be responsible for the cost of repairing any facilities in the rights-of way and any adjoining property or other facilities that it or its facilities damage. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-172. - Required restoration of property; removal of abandoned facilities. 
(a)  A utility shall be liable, at its own cost and expense, to replace or repair, any street, facilities, or property or structure thereon, thereunder, thereover, or adjacent thereto that may become disturbed or damaged as a result of the construction or installation, operation, upgrade, repair, or removal of facilities to a condition as good as or better than its condition before the work performed by the utility that caused such disturbance or damage. If the utility does not commence such replacement or repair after 20 working days following written notice from the city, the city or the owner of the affected structure or property may make such replacement or repair and the utility shall pay the reasonable and actual cost of the same. 
(b)  Whenever it is necessary to replace or relocate a joint use pole: 
(1)  The city shall give reasonable notice thereof in writing (except in the case of an emergency, when verbal notice will be given and subsequently confirmed in writing) to the utility, specifying in such notice the time of such proposed replacement or relocation, and the utility shall at the time so specified transfer its attachments to the new or relocated joint pole; or 
(2)  In the alternative, the city shall give to the utility such reasonable notice as mutually agreed upon by the parties, specifying the time of such proposed replacement or relocation, and the utility shall at the time so specified transfer its attachments to the new or relocated joint pole. The electric notification system of pole transfer requests, provided by the National Joint Utilities Notification System (the "NJUNS"), may be used as the notification required by this article. As a prerequisite for use of this system, both parties shall have and utilize the necessary electronic equipment required by the NJUNS. 
(c)  Utility attachments shall be promptly transferred from abandoned poles to new poles and as required by applicable permits and agreements. In the event that a utility does not within 30 days following proper notification, either in writing or through the NJUNS, remove its abandoned facilities or transfer its attachments to a new pole, the city will have the following rights, in addition to any other rights and remedies available under this article: 
(1)  The city may perform the required work and the utility shall pay the costs of the same; or 
(2)  Should the city elect not to perform the work on behalf of the utility, the utility shall be charged a fee of $10.00 per month per pole or other equipment, beginning on the 61st day after the utility has been properly notified, and shall also be charged the costs incurred to return to the job site to remove the old pole. The monthly fee shall continue to be charged until the city has been given proper notification, in writing or through the NJUNS, that such transfer has been made. In the event the utility notifies the city that the transfer has been completed, and the city returns to the job site and discovers that the transfer has not been made, the utility shall pay the city's costs of the trip to and from the job site. The intent of this paragraph is to ensure timely transfers and minimize situations of two or more poles needlessly remaining at the same location for extended periods of time. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
DIVISION 6. - RENTAL 

Sec. 59-173. - General. 
The rental rate for 2016 shall be $25.00 per pole paid by the utility that is attached to city-owned poles. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-174. - Escalation. 
(a)  Beginning January 1, 2016, the effective rate to be charged shall be adjusted annually based on the percentage increase or decrease in the Handy Whitman Index for the category of Poles, Towers, and Fixtures for the South Atlantic Region (the "HWI") during the currently available previous 12-month period. 
(b)  Should, in the future, the Handy Whitman Index fail to be published, the rental rate for each year thereafter shall be adjusted by the amount of any increase in the Consumer Price Index for all Urban Consumers CPI-U (1982-1984 = 100), U.S. City Average All Items for the 12-month period ending September 30 of the year to which the rate adjustment is being made. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-175. - Pole inventory. 
(a)  For the purpose of computing the total annual rental fee due hereunder, the total fee shall be based upon the number of city-owned poles the utility is attached to, determined by the current physical pole inventory plus any additional poles brought under this article through permit request, or minus any poles deleted through proper notification. 
(b)  At intervals of not less than five years and at the written request of the city, an actual physical inventory of jointly used poles may be made. When a third-party is to perform the inventory, the city shall have sole discretion in the contractor selected for this work. The cost of such inventory shall be shared equally among the city and the utilities attached to city-owned poles. If any difference in the number of jointly used poles is found between the actual physical inventory and the previous inventory adjusted by any attachments added or attachments removed since the last inventory, the differential will be prorated as if the subject attachments were placed in equal numbers over the years that have elapsed since the prior inventory and shall be billed and paid at the then appropriate rate in effect. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
DIVISION 7. - INSPECTION 

Sec. 59-176. - Right to inspect; fees. 
(a)  The utility shall make the construction site available to the city administrator, or the city administrator's designee, and to all others as authorized by law for inspection at all reasonable times during the execution and upon completion of the construction. 
(b)  The utility shall pay to city a permit inspection fee, which fee shall be the cost of labor and materials incurred by the city in order to inspect the work as required in this division. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-177. - Stop work. 
At any time, including the time of inspection, the city administrator may order the immediate cessation of any work which poses a serious threat to the health, safety, or welfare of the public, violates any law, or which violates the terms and conditions of the permit and/or this article or issue an order to correct work which does not conform to the permit and/or applicable standards, conditions or codes. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-178. - Notification of completion. 
When the construction under any permit is completed, the utility shall notify the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
DIVISION 8. - DISCONTINUANCE OF OPERATIONS, ABANDONED AND UNUSED FACILITIES 

Sec. 59-179. - Procedure for the discontinuance of operations. 
If a utility has discontinued or is discontinuing operation of any facilities in the city, the utility shall: 
(1)  Provide information satisfactory to the city that the utility's obligations for its facilities in the rights-of-way under this article and any other provision in the codified ordinances or other laws have been lawfully assumed by another utility; or 
(2)  Submit a written proposal to re-use its facilities; or 
(3)  Submit a written proposal for abandonment of facilities. Said proposal must be approved by the city administrator; or 
(4)  Remove its entire facilities and transfer any joint use attachments within the time prescribed under this article and in a manner acceptable to the city; or 
(5)  Submit to the city, in good faith and within a reasonable amount of time, a proposal for transferring ownership of its facilities to the city. If a utility proceeds under this clause, the city may, at its option, do one or more of the following: 
a.  Purchase the facilities; 
b.  Accept donation of some or all facilities; or 
c.  Require the utility to post a bond in an amount sufficient to reimburse the city for its reasonably anticipated costs to be incurred in removing the facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-180. - Failure to follow procedure for discontinuance. 
Facilities of a utility that fail to comply with the above provision regarding the procedure for discontinuance shall be deemed to be abandoned. Abandoned facilities are deemed to be a nuisance. The city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity, including, but not limited to: abating the nuisance; taking possession of the facilities, evicting the utility from the rights-of-way; prosecuting the violator; and/or any other remedy provided by the codified ordinances, including without limitation the per month, per pole or other equipment charges prescribed under this article, and/or any other remedy otherwise available at law or in equity. Remedies may be applied cumulatively. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
DIVISION 9. - EFFECTIVE PERIOD FOR AND TERMINATION OF PERMITS 

Sec. 59-181. - Effective period of permit and events of default. 
(a)  Each right-of-way encroachment permit shall have a set commencement date based on information provided in the applicant's permit application. The permit shall remain in place for one year and shall renew each subsequent year automatically until construction is completed unless the utility is in default. 
(b)  The city may give written notice of default to a utility if it is determined that a utility has: 
(1)  Violated any provision or requirement of the issuance or acceptance of a permit application or any law of the city, state, or federal government; 
(2)  Attempted to evade any provision or requirement of this article; 
(3)  Practiced any fraud or deceit upon the city; 
(4)  Made a material misrepresentation of fact in its application; or 
(5)  Failed to pay any annual or otherwise applicable fee or fees. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-182. - Procedure for termination. 
If a utility fails to cure a default within 20 working days after such notice is provided to the utility by the city, then such default shall be a material breach and the city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity to terminate the permit. If the city administrator decides there is cause or reason to terminate, the following procedure shall be followed: 
(1)  The city shall serve a utility with a written notice of the reason or cause for proposed termination and shall allow the utility a minimum of 15 working days to cure its breach. 
(2)  If the utility fails to cure within 15 working days, the city may declare the permit terminated. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-183. - Automatic expiration of permit. 
If work is not begun within six months of the date of issuance, the permit will automatically expire. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
DIVISION 10. - UNAUTHORIZED USE OF PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 59-184. - Use restrictions; violations. 
(a)  No utility shall use the rights-of-way to operate any facility or facilities that have not been authorized by the city in accordance with the terms of this article, place or have placed any facility or facilities in, on, above, within, over, below, under, or through the rights-of-way, unless specifically allowed under this article, or otherwise fail to comply with the provisions of this article or any other provision of the codified ordinances. Each and every unauthorized use or placement or failure to comply shall be deemed to be a violation of this article and a distinct and separate offense. Each and every day any violation of this article continues shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(b)  Each utility convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine for each violation. The amount of the fine shall be equal to the maximum amount allowed by law. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation occurs shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. In addition to the fine(s) prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies at law or in equity such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, and revocation of licenses or permits. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
DIVISION 11. - OTHER PROVISIONS 

Sec. 59-185. - Other approvals, permits, and agreements. 
The utility shall obtain all construction, building, or other permits or approvals as required by city ordinance, state, or federal law. In addition, a utility shall comply with all requirements of laws, shall complete work in a way as to not cause any unnecessary or unauthorized obstructions of sidewalks, streets, waterways, or railways, and is responsible for all work done in the rights-of-way regardless of who performs the work. No rights-of-way obstruction or excavation may be performed when seasonally prohibited or when conditions are unreasonable for such work, except in the case of an emergency as outlined above. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-186. - Severability. 
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this article is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court or administrative agency of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-187. - Reservation of regulatory and police powers. 
The city, by issuing a written approval of registration or permit under this article, does not surrender or to any extent lose, waive, impair, or lessen the lawful powers and rights, which it has now or which may be hereafter vested in it under the Constitution and Laws of the United States, State of Georgia, and under the provisions of the city's codified ordinances to regulate the use of the rights-of-way. The utility, by applying for and being issued a written approval of registration or permit, is deemed to acknowledge that all lawful powers and rights, regulatory power, or police power, or otherwise as are or the same may be from time to time vested in or reserved to the city, shall be in full force and effect and subject to the exercise thereof by the city at any time. A utility is deemed to acknowledge and accept that its rights are subject to the regulatory and police powers of the city to adopt and enforce general ordinances necessary to the safety and welfare of the public and is deemed to agree to comply with all applicable general laws enacted by the city pursuant to such powers. In particular, all utilities shall comply with city zoning and other land use requirements pertaining to the placement and specifications of facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-188. - Compliance. 
No utility shall be relieved of its obligation to comply with any of the provisions of this article by reason of any failure of the city to enforce prompt compliance. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-189. - Notices. 
All notices, completed applications, or other information required to be provided to the city by this article shall be in writing and sent via certified mail to the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
Sec. 59-190. - Headings. 
All headings provided by this article are for convenience only and shall not be used to interpret any portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 10-12-2015) 
PART II - LAND DEVELOPMENT AND RELATED REGULATIONS 
Chapter 62 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Adoption of standard codes. 
(a)  Adoption by reference. The following codes, as adopted and amended by the state department of community affairs, along with the referenced appendices, are adopted by reference as though they were set forth fully herein: 
International Building Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Residential Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Plumbing Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Mechanical Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Fuel Gas Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Energy Conservation Code, 2009 Edition. 
National Electrical Code, 2014 Edition. 
International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 Edition. 
International Existing Building Code, 2012 Edition. 
National Green Building Standard, 2008 Edition. 
International Swimming Pool and Spa Code, 2012 Edition. 
(b)  Administration and enforcement. The procedures set forth in chapter 1 of the Standard Building Code adopted in this section, as amended in "Standard Building Code—Attachment A", on file at the city clerk's office, shall be the procedures that govern the administration, enforcement and penalties for the codes referenced in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Fees. The fees for permitting and inspection of the various code related activities shall be as shown on the city fee schedule as amended from time to time. 
(Code 1966, § 5-1; Ord. No. 96-29, 11-12-1996; Ord. No. 2013-24, § 1, 10-14-2013; Ord. No. 2014-06, 2-24-2014; Ord. No. 2015-21, § 1, 8-10-2015) 
Sec. 62-2. - Permits and inspections. 
(a)  Permit or license required. Except as provided herein, no persons shall begin building construction without a permit and/or a business license issued by the city as provided herein. 
(b)  Building additions. Any addition to a dwelling in the city shall require a building permit. The building inspector will make as many inspections as he feels necessary to ensure a satisfactory job. 
(c)  Building improvements. A building permit shall be required for any improvement on a dwelling other than painting, except an improvement costing $200.00 which shall not require a permit. The building inspector will make one inspection. 
(d)  Conversion to multiple-family building. If an existing single-family dwelling is converted to a multiple-family building, a building permit shall be required. The alteration shall carry the same requirements as new construction. 
(e)  Time for inspections. The city building inspector shall make inspections from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. (unless a special time is agreed upon) Monday through Friday. In the event the inspector cannot be reached within 48 hours of the time called, then inspection can be made by someone designated by the mayor. 
(f)  Failure to procure inspection. Anyone who fails to call for an inspection at the proper stage of construction and continues on with the construction shall be subject to a fine. 
(g)  Verification of business licenses. The building inspector shall have the responsibility and authority to check that anyone doing business in the construction field within the city limits possesses a city business license. 
(Code 1966, § 5-1.1; Ord. No. 67-20, 11-27-1967) 
Secs. 62-3—62-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING PERMITS AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 62-23. - As-built surveys. 
In addition to the other regulations established by the city, no certificate of occupancy for any structure shall be issued until the property owner, developer, or builder submits a survey with a registered land surveyor's certificate verifying compliance with all setbacks. The survey shall show the following: 
(1)  Names and addresses of the owner of record and the applicant. 
(2)  Boundary lines of the tract by lengths and bearings, streets adjoining the property, total area of the tract, north point, graphic scale, and date. 
(3)  All existing setback lines. 
(4)  Location of buildings, structures, and foundations thereof. 
(5)  Locations of all utility lines. 
(6)  Limits of land disturbance, clearing, grading, and trenching. 
(Ord. No. 2002-26, § 1, 12-9-2002) 
Secs. 62-24—62-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PLUMBING PERMITS AND REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 62-50. - Plumbers required to be licensed; conformance to plumbing code. 
No plumbing of any kind shall be installed within the city unless the same shall be done by a plumber holding a license issued by either the City of Atlanta or the county and unless the materials used in such plumbing and the mode and manner of installation conform to the plumbing code as adopted in section 62-1. 
(Code 1941, § 1001; Code 1966, § 18-1; Ord. No. 92-02, § 4, 2-24-1992) 
Sec. 62-51. - Committee on health and sanitation; plumbing inspector. 
The health and sanitation committee of the council shall have general supervision over the enforcement of the plumbing code and shall appoint a plumbing inspector to perform the duties of plumbing inspector as set out in the plumbing code of the county, so far as the same can apply to the city. 
(Code 1941, § 1003; Code 1966, § 18-2) 
Sec. 62-52. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to install any plumbing of any kind in the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city clerk. 
(Code 1941, § 1004; Code 1966, § 18-3) 
Sec. 62-53. - Purpose. 
It is the purpose of this article to require the use of ultra-low-flow plumbing fixtures in all new construction, or when replacing plumbing fixtures during renovation or remodeling of existing buildings for the purpose of conserving water to maintain the integrity of drinking water supplies and reduce wastewater flows. 
(Code 1966, § 18-31; Ord. No. 91-02, § 1, 3-11-1991) 
Sec. 62-54. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial means any type of building other than residential. 
Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building, and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. 
Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling, but shall not include a hotel or motel. 
(Code 1966, § 18-32; Ord. No. 91-02, § 2, 3-11-1991) 
Sec. 62-55. - No construction for buildings in which certain conditions exist. 
No construction may be initiated within the city for any building of any type which: 
(1)  Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve, or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average 1.6 gallons of water per flush; provided, however, this subsection shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992; 
(2)  Employs a shower head that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; 
(3)  Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of 1.0 gallon of water per flush; 
(4)  Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.0 gallons of water per minute; or 
(5)  Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. 
(Code 1966, § 18-33; Ord. No. 91-02, § 3, 3-11-1991) 
Sec. 62-56. - Exemptions. 
New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of section 62-55 when: 
(1)  The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; 
(2)  When such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design, or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this article were installed; 
(3)  Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or 
(4)  Units to be installed are: 
a.  Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; 
b.  Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal or correctional institution; or 
c.  Toilets for juveniles. 
(Code 1966, § 18-36; Ord. No. 91-02, § 6, 3-11-1991) 
Sec. 62-57. - Enforcement; penalty. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the office of the building inspector of the city. Citations for violations may be issued by the chief building inspector of the city. 
(b)  Any person, corporation, partnership or other entity violating this article shall be tried before the municipal court of the city. Upon conviction, a violation of this article may be punished by: 
(1)  Imposition of the penalties set forth in section 1-15; and 
(2)  In the case of contractors, plumbers, plumbing contractors or developers, suspension of the business license of said violator for a period of up to 90 days. 
(Code 1966, § 18-37; Ord. No. 91-02, § 7, 3-11-1991) 
Secs. 62-58—62-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER FLOW REQUIREMENTS: PLUMBING FIXTURES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-08, § 1, adopted July 23, 2008, amended the Code by adding provisions numbered as § 62-58. In order to better conform to the format of the Code and to reserve sections for future use, the editor has renumbered the provisions added by Ord. No. 2012-08 as herein set out. 

Sec. 62-61. - Purpose. 
(a)  To promote greater efficiency in residential and commercial water use and preserve the natural resources of the service area of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Water and Sewer Authority; 
(b)  To reduce consumer water and energy costs by reducing indoor water use, reducing the need for new water supplies and treatment facilities, lowering operation and maintenance costs for water and sewer utilities, and reducing the amount of energy used to heat, treat, and transport water; and 
(c)  To generate consumer awareness of the need to save water and of the savings that can result from the use of efficient plumbing products. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 1, 7-23-2012) 
Sec. 62-62. - Definitions. 
[The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this division, unless otherwise specifically stated:] 
Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. 
Lavatory faucet means a faucet that discharges into a lavatory basin in a domestic or commercial installation. 
Plumbing fixture means a device that receives water, waste, or both and discharges the water, waste, or both into a drainage system. The term includes a kitchen sink, utility sink, lavatory, bidet, bathtub, shower, urinal, toilet, water closet, or drinking water fountain. 
Plumbing fixture fitting means a device that controls and directs the flow of water. The term includes a sink faucet, lavatory faucet, showerhead, or bath filler. 
Pressurized flushing device means a device that contains a valve that: 
(1)  Is attached to a pressurized water supply pipe that is of sufficient size to deliver water at the necessary rate of flow to ensure flushing when the valve is open; and 
(2)  Opens on actuation to allow water to flow into the fixture at a rate and in a quantity necessary for the operation of the fixture and gradually closes to avoid water hammer. 
Toilet means a water closet. 
Water closet means a fixture with a water-containing receptor that receives liquid and solid body waste and on actuation conveys the waste through an exposed integral trap into a drainage system and which is also referred to as a toilet. 
WaterSense™ means a voluntary program of the United States Environmental Protection Agency designed to identify and promote water efficient products and practices. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 1, 7-23-2012) 
Sec. 62-63. - Minimum standards. 
The following standards related to high-efficiency plumbing fixtures are minimum standards to be utilized in construction. These standards include without limitation, the following: 
(1)  A water closet or toilet that: 
a.  Is a dual flush water closet that meets the following standards: 
2.  The average flush volume of two reduced flushes and one full flush may not exceed 1.28 gallons; 
2.  The toilet meets the performance, testing, and labeling requirements prescribed by the following standards, as applicable: 
(i)  American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.2-2008; and 
(ii)  American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.14-2006 "Six-Liter Water Closets Equipped with a Dual Flushing Device"; and 
3.  Is listed to the WaterSense™ Tank-Type High Efficiency Toilet Specifications; or 
b.  Is a single-flush water closet, including gravity, pressure assisted, and electro-hydraulic tank types, that meets the following standards: 
1.  The average flush volume may not exceed 1.28 gallons; 
2.  The toilet must meet the performance, testing, and labeling requirements prescribed by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.192/CSA B45.1 or A112.19.14; and 
3.  The toilet must be listed to the WaterSense™ Tank-Type High Efficiency Toilet Specification; 
(2)  A shower head that allows a flow of no more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; 
(3)  A urinal and associated flush valve that: 
a.  Uses no more than 0.5 gallons of water per flush; 
b.  Meets the performance, testing, and labeling requirements prescribed by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.2/CSA B45.1; 
c.  For flushing urinals, meets all WaterSense™ specifications for flushing urinals; and 
d.  Where nonwater urinals are employed, complies with American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.3/CSA B45.4 or American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.19/CSA B45.4. Nonwater urinals shall be cleaned and maintained in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions after installation. Where nonwater urinals are installed they shall have a water distribution line roughed-in to the urinal location at a minimum height of 56 inches (1,422 mm) to allow for the installation of an approved backflow prevention device in the event of a retrofit. Such water distribution lines shall be installed with shut-off valves located as close as possible to the distributing main to prevent the creation of dead ends. Where nonwater urinals are installed, a minimum of one water supplied fixture rated at a minimum of one water supply fixture unit shall be installed upstream on the same drain line to facilitate drain line flow and rinsing; 
(4)  A lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of no more than 1.5 gallons of water per minute at a pressure of 60 pounds per square inch in accordance with American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.18.1/CSA B.125.1 and listed to the WaterSense™ High-Efficiency Lavatory Faucet Specification; and 
(5)  A kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of no more than 2.0 gallons of water per minute. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 1, 7-23-2012) 
Sec. 62-64. - Exemptions. 
The following shall be exempt from the above requirements under the following conditions: 
(1)  When the repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets, or shower heads within such existing building; 
(2)  When such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design, or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets, or shower heads required by this part were installed; 
(3)  When such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or 
(d)  When units to be installed are: 
a.  Specifically designed for use by persons with disabilities; 
b.  Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or 
c.  Toilets for juveniles. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 1, 7-23-2012) 
Sec. 62-65. - Applications for exemptions. 
The owner, or his agent, of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation and entitled to an exemption as specified in section 62-64 above, shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the building official for the city. A fee shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. The fee shall be as stated on the Schedule of Fees located in the office of the building official for the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 1, 7-23-2012) 
Sec. 62-66. - Violations. 
Any person who installs any toilet, faucet, urinal, or shower head in violation of this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 1, 7-23-2012) 
Secs. 62-67—62-87. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL PERMITS AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 62-88. - Electrical code to govern. 
The provisions of the electrical code adopted by the city as set forth in section 62-1 shall govern the installation and repair of all electrical wiring, installations and all things electric within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 9-1; Ord. No. 92-02, § 2, 2-24-1992) 
Sec. 62-89. - Electrical installations by licensed electrician.
