ARTICLE IX. - STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 71-241—71-258. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GRASSING 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 71-259. - Summary. 
(a)  The extent of grassing consists of those areas, which are disturbed by operations of the contractor and are not covered over by improvements, except where specifically noted otherwise, together with any additional areas shown on the drawings in article X of this chapter or authorized by the city. 
(b)  Types of work required include the following: 
(1)  Fine grading and preparing of lawn areas. 
(2)  Furnishing and applying new topsoil. 
(3)  Furnishing and applying soil amendments. 
(4)  Furnishing and applying fertilizers. 
(5)  Seeding new lawn areas. 
(6)  Sodding new lawn areas. 
(7)  Planting new lawn areas with sprigs. 
(8)  Planting new lawn areas with plugs. 
(9)  Reconditioning existing lawn areas. 
(10)  Replanting unsatisfactory or damaged lawns. 
(c)  Refer to earthwork sections in this division for requirements of general excavation, filling, and grading in areas to receive grassing. 
(d)  Topsoil has (or will be) stockpiled for reuse in grassing. If quantity of stockpiled topsoil is insufficient, additional topsoil to complete grassing shall be provided. 
(e)  Topsoil for grassing is not available at site. Topsoil as specified under section 71-284 shall be furnished. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt.1), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-260. - Job conditions. 
(a)  Planting time. Lawn seed shall be sown only during normal planting seasons for each type of lawn work required. Planting shall be correlated with specified maintenance periods to provide required maintenance from date of substantial completion. 
(b)  Specified work is minimum required, and any and all necessary materials and operations, including reworking, must be performed to obtain specified results. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt.1), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-261—71-283. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Products 

Sec. 71-284. - New topsoil. 
(a)  Topsoil shall be provided that is fertile, friable, naturally loamy, surface soil; reasonably free of subsoil, clay lumps, brush, weeds, and other litter; and free of roots, stumps, stones larger than two inches in any dimension, and other extraneous or toxic matter harmful to plant growth. 
(b)  Topsoil shall be obtained from local sources or from areas having similar soil characteristics to that found at site of work. Obtain topsoil from naturally well-drained sites where topsoil occurs at least four inches deep; do not obtain from bogs or marshes. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-285. - Soil amendments. 
(a)  Lime. 
(1)  Natural limestone containing at least 85 percent of total carbonates, ground to such fineness that at least 90 percent passes a ten-mesh sieve and at least 50 percent passes a 100-mesh sieve. 
(2)  Provide lime in the form of dolomitic limestone. 
(b)  Fertilizer shall be standard commercial grade fertilizer conforming to the standards of the Association of Official Agricultural Chemists. Provide either grade 4-12-12, 6-12-12 or 5-10-15 at contractor's option. 
(c)  Nitrogen shall be standard commercial grade nitrogen conforming to state fertilizer laws. Provide in either granular or liquid form at contractor's option. 
(d)  Peat humus shall be finely divided or granular texture and with pH of 6.0 to 7.5 composed of moss peat (other than spagnum), or peat humus, or reed-sedge peat. 
(e)  Sawdust or ground bark. Types of sawdust or ground bark shall be provided that is nontoxic to plants, of uniform texture, and subject to slow decomposition when mixed with soil. Nitrogen-treated sawdust or ground bark shall be provided, or untreated sawdust or ground bark shall be provided and mixed at site with at least 0.15 pounds of ammonium nitrate or 0.25 pounds of ammonium sulfate per cubic foot of loose sawdust or ground bark. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390. pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-286. - Grass materials. 
(a)  Grass seed. Fresh, clean, new crop grass seed complying with the tolerance for purity and germination established by the Official Seed Analysts of North America shall be provided. Seed of the grass species, proportions and minimum percentages of purity, germination, and maximum percentage of weed seed, as specified in the following table, shall be provided: 
_____ 

 
_____
(b)  Sod. Machine-cut, strongly rooted, certified turfgrass sod at least two years old and free of weeds and undesirable native grasses shall be provided. Sod capable of vigorous growth and development shall be provided. 
(1)  Type of sod used shall be: 
a.  Bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon). 
b.  Centipedegrass (Eremochloa ophiuroides). 
(2)  Sod pad size shall be uniform thickness of five-eighths inch, plus or minus one-quarter inch, measured at time of cutting and excluding top growth and thatch. Sod pads shall be provided in supplier's standard size of uniform length and width with maximum five percent allowable deviation in either length or width. Broken or torn pads with uneven ends are not acceptable. 
(3)  Sod strength. Sod pads shall be provided that are capable of supporting their own weight and retaining size and shape when supplier's standard size pad is suspended vertically from a firm grasp on upper ten percent of the pad. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-287. - Mulch and water. 
(a)  Antierosion mulch. Antierosion mulch shall be provided that is clean, seed-free, salt hay or threshed straw of wheat, rye, oats, or barley. 
(b)  Seed mulch. Peat moss shall be provided that is in natural, shredded, or granulated form, of fine texture, with a pH of 4.0 to 6.0 and a water-absorbing capacity of 1,100 to 2,000 percent. 
(c)  Water. Water used to produce grass is to be free of excess and harmful chemicals, acids, alkalies and all other substances, which are harmful to plant growth. 
(d)  Asphalt. Homogeneous emulsified asphalt meeting ASTM D 977 which contains no agents harmful or toxic to plant growth shall be used. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-288—71-307. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Execution 

Sec. 71-308. - General regulations. 
(a)  Minimum operations. This subdivision sets forth minimum operations and material applications, which are acceptable. However, a satisfactory stand of grass must be obtained by using supplemental methods and/or materials as may be required. 
(b)  Grassing by private property. Where grassing is required between curbs and sidewalks or behind sidewalks in areas adjacent to private residential or commercial property, the city may change the type of grassing specified to match any type of grass, which may be planted, and growing on the adjacent lawn. No modifications of the contract unit price will be made for this substitution. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-309. - Soil preparation. 
The following process and regulations shall be used for soil preparation: 
(1)  Preparation shall be limited to areas that will be planted in the immediate future. 
(2)  Subgrade shall be loosened to a minimum depth of four inches. Remove stones bigger than 1½ inches in any dimension and sticks, roots, rubbish, and other extraneous matter. 
(3)  Topsoil shall be cleaned of roots, plants, sods, stones, clay lumps, and other extraneous materials harmful to toxic to plant growth. 
(4)  Soil amendments and fertilizers shall be mixed with topsoil at rates specified. Mixing of fertilizer shall be delayed if planting will not follow placing of topsoil mixture within a few days. Soil should be mixed before spreading or soil amendments should be applied on surface of spread topsoil and mix thoroughly into top four inches of topsoil before planting. 
a.  Lime shall be mixed with dry soil before mixing in fertilizer. 
b.  Phosphoric acid fertilizer (other than that constituting a portion of complete fertilizers) shall be applied directly to subgrade before tilling. 
(5)  Topsoil mixture shall be spread to depth required to meet thickness, grades, and elevations shown, after light rolling and natural settlement. Do not spread if material or subgrade is frozen. Place approximately one-half of total amount of topsoil mixture required. Work into top of loosened subgrade to create a transition layer, and then place remainder of topsoil mixture. Allow for sod thickness in areas to be sodded. 
(6)  Preparation of unchanged grades. Unchanged grades shall be prepared as follows: 
a.  Where lawns are to be planted in areas that have not been altered or disturbed by excavating, grading, or stripping operations, soil for lawn and grass planting shall be prepared as follows: soil shall be tilled to a depth of at least six inches. Soil amendments and initial fertilizers shall be applied as specified and mixed thoroughly into top four inches of soil. High areas shall be removed and depressions filled in; soil shall be tilled to a homogenous mixture of fine texture, and shall be free of lumps, clods, stones, roots, and other extraneous matter. 
b.  Before unchanged areas are prepared, existing grass, vegetation, and turf shall be removed. Such material shall be disposed of outside of the city's property; soil being prepared for lawns shall not be turned over. 
(7)  Lawn and grass areas shall be graded to a smooth, even surface with loose, uniformly fine texture. Roll and rake, remove ridges, and fill depressions to meet finish grades. Fine grading shall be limited to areas that can be planted within immediate future. Remove trash, debris, stones larger than 1½ inches diameter, and other objects that may interfere with planting or maintenance operations shall be removed. 
(8)  Prepared lawn areas shall be moistened before planting if soil is dry. Prepared lawn areas shall be watered thoroughly and the surface allowed to dry off before the lawns are planted. Muddy soil shall not be created. 
(9)  Prepared areas shall be restored to specified condition if eroded or otherwise disturbed after fine grading and before planting. 
(10)  Lime and fertilizer application. Lime and fertilizer shall be applied as follows: 
a.  Lime shall be spread uniformly over the ground surface at the following rate: 1,500 pounds per acre. 
b.  Fertilizer shall be spread uniformly over the ground surface at the following rate: 1,000 pounds per acre. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390. pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-310. - Seeding new lawns. 
New lawns shall be seeded in compliance with the following process: 
(1)  Seed shall be sown with a spreader or a seeding machine. Do not seed when wind velocity exceeds five miles per hour. Distribute seed evenly over entire area by sowing equal quantity in two directions at right angles to each other. 
a.  Wet seed or seed that is moldy or otherwise damaged in transmit or storage shall not be used. 
b.  No less than the quantity of seed specified shall be sown. 
(2)  Seed shall be raked lightly into top one-eighth inch of soil, roll lightly, and water with fine spray. 
(3)  Seeded slopes shall be protected against erosion with jute mesh erosion netting or other similar coverings acceptable to the city. 
(4)  Mulch. Seeded areas shall be protected against erosion by spreading specified lawn mulch after completion of seeding operations. Mulch shall be spread uniformly to form a continuous blanket at least 1½ inches loose measurement over seeded areas. Mulch shall be spread by hand, blower, or other suitable equipment. Mulch shall be anchored by spraying with asphalt emulsion at the rate of ten to 13 gallons per 1,000 square feet. Precautions shall be taken to prevent damage or staining of structures or other plantings adjacent to mulched areas. Such areas where damage occurs shall be immediately cleaned. 
(5)  Seeded areas shall be protected against hot, dry weather or drying winds by applying specified mulch within 24 hours after completion of seeding operations. Mulch shall be presoaked and scattered evenly to a depth of one-eighth inches to 3/16 inches thick and roll to a smooth surface. Mulch shall not be mounded. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-311. - Hydroseeding new lawns. 
Hydroseed new lawns according to the following process: 
(1)  Specified seed, fertilizer, and pulverized mulch shall be mixed in water, using equipment specifically designed for hydroseed application. Continue mixing until uniformly blended into homogenous slurry suitable for hydraulic application. 
(2)  Slurry shall be applied uniformly to all areas to be seeded. Rate of application as required to obtain specified seed sowing rate. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-312. - Sodding new lawns. 
The following procedure shall be followed for sodding new lawns: 
(1)  Sod shall be laid within 24 hours of stripping. Do not lay dormant sod or if ground is frozen. 
(2)  Sod shall be laid to form solid mass with tightly fitting joints. Butt ends and sides of sod strips; do not overlap. Stagger strips to offset joints in adjacent courses. Work from boards to avoid damage to subgrade or sod. Tamp or roll lightly to ensure contact with subgrade. Work sifted soil into minor cracks between pieces of sod; remove excess to avoid smothering adjacent grass. Anchor sod on slopes with wood pegs as required to prevent slippage. 
(3)  Sod shall be watered with fine spray immediately after planting. During the first week, water daily or more frequently as necessary to maintain moist soil to depth of four inches. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-313. - Reconditioning lawns. 
The following procedure shall be followed for reconditioning lawns: 
(1)  Existing lawn areas that were damaged by the contractor's operations, including storage of materials or equipment and movement of vehicles, shall be reconditioned. Lawn areas where settlement or washouts occur or where minor regrading is required shall also be reconditioned. 
(2)  Fertilizer, seed or sod, and soil amendments as specified for new lawns and as required to provide satisfactorily reconditioned lawn shall be provided. New planting soil shall be provided as required to fill low spots and meet new finish grades. 
(3)  Bare and compacted areas shall be cultivated thoroughly to provide a good, deep planting bed. 
(4)  Diseased or unsatisfactory lawn areas shall be removed; such areas shall not be buried into soil. Topsoil containing foreign materials resulting from the contractor's operations, including oil drippings, stone, gravel, and other construction materials, shall be removed and replaced with new topsoil. 
(5)  Where substantial lawn remains (but is thin), it shall be mowed, raked, aerate dif compacted, low spots shall be filled, humps shall be removed, soil shall be cultivated, fertilized, and seeded. Weeds shall be removed before seeding. If weeds are extensive, selective chemical weed killers shall be applied as required. A seedbed mulch shall be applied, if required, to maintain moist condition. 
(6)  Newly planted areas shall be watered and kept moist until new grass is established. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-314. - Application of nitrogen. 
The following procedure shall be followed for nitrogen application: 
(1)  Two applications of nitrogen shall be made to all grassed areas using mechanical spreading equipment. Apply at a uniform rate of not less than 70 pounds per acre per application. Make both applications only when weather conditions will permit uniform and even distribution and when moisture conditions will not cause harm to grass. 
(2)  The first application of nitrogen shall be placed when young grass reaches a height of at least one inch. The second application of nitrogen shall be made between 30 and 45 days after the first application. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-315. - Protection. 
Barricades and warning signs shall be erected as required to protect newly planted areas from traffic. Barricades shall be maintained throughout the maintenance period until the lawn is established. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-316. - Maintenance. 
The following procedure shall be followed for lawn maintenance: 
(1)  Lawns shall be maintained by watering, fertilizing, weeding, mowing, trimming, and other operations such as rolling, regrading, replanting as required to establish a smooth, acceptable lawn, free of eroded or bare areas. 
(2)  Areas where mulch has been disturbed by wind or maintenance operations sufficiently to nullify its purpose shall be remulched with new mulch. Anchor as required to prevent displacement. 
(3)  Bare areas shall be replanted with the same materials specified for lawns. 
(4)  Watering. Temporary piping, hoses and lawn watering equipment shall be provided and maintained to convey water from sources and to keep lawn areas uniformly moist as required for proper growth. 
(5)  A temporary lawn watering system shall be laid out and a watering schedule shall be arranged to prevent puddling, water erosion, and displacement of seed or mulch, if any. The temporary watering system shall be laid out to avoid the necessity of walking over muddy or newly seeded areas. 
(6)  Lawns shall be mowed as soon as there is enough top growth to cut with the mower set at specified height for principal species planted. Mowing shall be repeated as required to maintain specified height. No more than 40 percent of grass leaf growth shall be removed in initial or subsequent mowings. Mowing shall not be delayed until grass blades bend over and become matted. Wet grass shall not be mowed. Initial and subsequent mowings shall be timed to maintain the following grass height: 1½ inches to two inches high. Grass less than 1½ inches shall not be mowed. 
(7)  The second fertilizer application shall be applied after the first mowing and when grass is dry. Fertilizer shall be used that will provide at least 1.0 pound of actual nitrogen per 1,000 square feet of lawn area. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-317. - Required coverage. 
Grassed areas will be considered acceptable when a viable stand of grass covers at least 98 percent of the total area with no bare spots exceeding one square foot and the ground surface is fully stabilized against erosion. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-318. - Acceptance. 
(a)  When work is substantially completed, including maintenance, the city will, upon request, make an inspection to determine acceptability. Lawn work may be inspected for acceptance in parts agreeable to the city, provided work offered for inspection is complete, including maintenance. 
(b)  Rejected work shall be replanted and specified maintenance shall be continued until reinspected by the city and found to be acceptable. 
(c)  Seeded lawns will be acceptable provided requirements, including maintenance and coverage, have been met and healthy, uniform close stand of specified grass is established free of weeds, bare spots, and surface irregularities. 
(d)  Sodded lawns will be acceptable provided requirements, including maintenance and coverage, have been met and required number of plugs are established as well-rooted, viable patches of grass and areas between plugs are free of weeds and other undesirable vegetation. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-319. - Cleanup. 
Soil and debris created by lawn work shall be promptly removed from paved areas. Wheels of vehicles shall be cleaned before leaving the site to avoid tracking soil onto the surface of roads, walks, or other paved areas. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02390, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-320—71-341. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRAINAGE STRUCTURES AND ACCESSORIES 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 71-342. - Description of work. 
(a)  The extent of drainage structures is shown on the drawings in article X of this chapter. 
(b)  Related work specified elsewhere in this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  Trenching and backfilling, division 8 of this article. 
(2)  Sanitary sewer system, division 5 of this article. 
(3)  Storm sewer system, division 4 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02776, pt. 1), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-343—71-372. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Products 

Sec. 71-373. - Materials. 
The following material shall be used for drainage structures and accessories: 
(1)  Clay brick. ASTM C 32, Grade MS or ASTM C 32 sewer and manhole brick or ASTM C 216 facing brick, Grade MW or SW, of nominal size 8 x 2¼ x 3¾ inches. Color and texture as selected by the contractor. 
(2)  Concrete brick. ASTM C 55, Grade P-II, of nominal size 8 x 2¼ x 3¾ inches; gray-white concrete color with smooth formed natural texture. 
(3)  Rubble stone. Provide stone not less than six inches thick or 12 inches wide, and of proper shape to bring masonry structures to true lines, shapes, and elevations; smaller stones may be used to fill the interior of walls. Provide stone, free of rounded, worn, weathered and scarred surfaces, and also free of segregation, seams, cracks, pyrite intrusions and other defects tending to reduce weather resistance. Select stone having not less than 65 percent wear in accordance with AASHTO T 96, and having a loss not exceeding 15 percent after five cycles of the magnesium sulfate soundness test in accordance with AASHTO T 104. 
(4)  Precast concrete drainage structures. 
a.  Concrete drainage structures, including precast concrete pipe sections, flared end sections, adjustment rings, tapered sections, drop inlets, manholes, and other related products, and which conform to the requirements of ASTM C 478 and/or C 789 shall be used. Structures having a minimum wall thickness of four inches or 1/12 the interior diameter, whichever is greater, shall be furnished. Openings shall be accurately cast to meet specific project requirements. 
b.  Drainage structure steps. 
1.  Steps conforming with applicable government safety regulations and the requirements stated below shall be used. 
2.  Individual steps shall be provided and mortared or cast into walls and conical tops of all manholes and similar structures. Steps shall be aligned so as to form a continuous ladder with steps equally spaced vertically, no more than 16 inches apart, using steps having a minimum length of ten inches and which project a minimum clear distance of four inches from the wall. Steps designed to prevent the foot from sliding off the end, and the exposed parts of which are free of any hazardous sharp edges, burrs or projections shall be used. 
3.  Steps, fastenings and installation must be capable of supporting a single concentrated load of 300 pounds. Use designs based on imposed loads being concentrated at such points as will cause maximum stresses in the structural element being considered. 
4.  Plastic-coated steel meeting requirements of ASTM C 478, D 2146 and A 615 grade 60 shall be used. 
(5)  Metal castings. 
a.  Castings shall be provided that are of uniform quality, free from blowholes, porosity, hard spots, shrinkage, distortion or other significant defects, and have smooth surfaces free of casting sand, fins and burrs. Component parts shall be used which fit together uniformly, in a secure fashion. Where castings have lids or covers, provisions shall be made for non-rocking fit. 
b.  One of the following casting materials shall be used: 
1.  Ductile iron castings: ASTM A 536, Grade 50-40-18. 
2.  Gray iron castings: ASTM A 48, Class 30. 
(6)  Mortar. 
a.  Materials. 
1.  Cement: Portland Cement ASTM C 150, Type I or II. 
2.  Sand: ASTM C 144, well screened, clean, hard sharp, siliceous, free from loam, silt and other impurities. The following grain size distribution shall be provided: 
(i)  No. 10 sieve, passing 95—100 percent. 
(ii)  No. 50 sieve, passing 15—40 percent. 
(iii)  No. 100 sieve, passing 0—10 percent. 
(iv)  Removal by decantation 0—5 percent. 
3.  Water: Clean, fresh, free from oil, acid, organic matter and other deleterious substances. 
b.  Mortar mix proportions. Mortar shall be provided that is mixed in the proportion of one part cement to three parts sand with only enough water to allow good workability of the mix. Hydrated lime may be added in amounts not exceeding ten percent of the cement weight. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02776, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-374—71-404. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Execution 

Sec. 71-405. - General regulations. 
(a)  Excavation and backfill. Excavation and backfill shall conform with applicable provisions of division 8 of this article, pertaining to trenching and backfilling. 
(b)  Precast concrete units. 
(1)  Precast units shall be set plumb and to exact grade on approximately three-inch thickness of compacted sand bedding. 
(2)  In the event field conditions necessitate additional pipe connections for which no holes have been cast, necessary holes shall be neatly chipped, being careful not to crack portions of unit to remain. Any units excessively damaged as a result of field modification shall be replaced. 
(3)  For storm sewer units constructed of more than one precast element, all joints shall be filled solidly with mortar. Mortar or concrete shall be used to seal joints between units and connecting pipe. 
(4)  For sanitary sewer manholes, joints shall be filled between sections with butyl based sealant especially formulated for sewer service. Mortar or concrete shall be used to seal joints between units and connecting pipe. Connecting joints shall be supplemented with manufactured water stops or seals when recommended by pipe manufacturer or necessary to minimize leakage. 
(c)  Masonry structures. 
(1)  Cement and lime shall be stored in a dry place. Masonry units shall be stored above ground on level platforms, which allow air circulation around and under stacked masonry units. 
(2)  Masonry units shall be handled and stored so as to avoid damage. 
(3)  Masonry units shall be examined before installation and all units which are cracked, damaged, or in any way fail to meet this specification shall be rejected. 
(4)  Only clean masonry units which are free of dirt and debris which would adversely affect mortar bond shall be used. Frozen materials, or materials mixed or coated with ice or frost shall not be used. 
(5)  Masonry units shall be set in full mortar bed, carefully fitting units around pipe openings, etc., so as to fill all voids; any remaining voids shall be completely filled with mortar. Mortar which has been mixed more than 45 minutes or which has been retempered shall not be used. 
(6)  When using multi-wythe construction, every fifth coarse shall be made a header coarse. 
(7)  Masonry shall not be installed when air temperature is below 40 degrees Fahrenheit and falling. 
(8)  Masonry structures shall not be backfilled until they are at least seven days old. In cold weather, backfilling shall be delayed for a longer time to allow additional curing time for mortar. 
(d)  Metal castings. 
(1)  Each casting shall be examined before installation, and all castings which are cracked, damaged or in any other way fail to meet the specifications shall be rejected. 
(2)  Castings shall be cleaned of dirt, mud and grease before installation. 
(3)  Castings shall be set according to location and arrangement shown on the drawings in article X of this chapter; rigidly support castings to maintain true alignment and elevation. Where castings are located in concrete or mortar construction, thoroughly work concrete or mortar around the casting so as to eliminate voids and provide solid bearing surfaces and rigid construction. 
(4)  Frames shall be made, subject to traffic, firm and stable under actual traffic conditions. When constructed in paved areas, frames shall be set to conform with exact pavement surface including tilting frame where necessary to match pavement surface. 
(e)  Sanitary sewer manholes. 
(1)  Inverts and channels shall be shaped neatly so as to permit smooth hydraulic flow. 
(2)  The outside wall of each manhole shall be saturated with water, and plastered with a smooth, one-half inch thick minimum coat of mortar as specified under subdivision II of this division, except that the mortar shall be mixed with one part cement to two parts sand. Hydrated lime shall not be added to plaster mortar. 
(3)  Contractors shall use whatever care, materials and construction technique may be required to achieve permanent watertight joints and connections. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02776, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-406. - Field quality control. 
(a)  General leakage requirements. 
(1)  All manholes shall be made as near watertight as practicable. All visible points of groundwater infiltration shall be eliminated as well as any other significant points of leakage which can be located regardless of test results obtained as hereinafter required. 
(2)  Upon completion of manhole installation and prior to acceptance and payment for completed work, a manhole vacuum acceptance test shall be performed for each newly installed precast concrete manhole. 
(b)  Sanitary sewer manhole vacuum testing. 
(1)  Where adjustment to grade using bricks and mortar is required, manholes shall be tested prior to placement of final elevation adjustment and castings. 
(2)  Manhole vacuum tests shall be performed using the following general procedures: 
a.  All lift holes shall be plugged with a non-shrink grout. 
b.  All pipes entering the manhole shall be temporarily plugged and each plug shall be securely braced to prevent them from being pulled into the manhole. 
c.  The vacuum testing equipment test head shall be placed at the top of the manhole in accordance with the testing equipment manufacturers recommendations. 
d.  A vacuum of ten inches of mercury on the manhole shall be drawn and the valve on the vacuum line of the testing equipment shall be closed and shot off the vacuum pump. The time for the vacuum to drop to nine inches of mercury shall be measured. 
(3)  The manhole shall pass if the time for the vacuum reading to drop from ten inches of mercury to nine inches of mercury meets or exceeds the values indicated in the following table: 

 
(4)  If the manhole fails the initial test, excessive leakage determined by manhole vacuum testing shall be permanently corrected and the vacuum test shall be repeated until the city witnesses a successful test. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02776, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-407—71-425. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - STORM SEWER SYSTEM 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 71-426. - Description of work. 
(a)  The extent of the storm sewer system is shown on the drawings in article X of this chapter. 
(b)  The storm sewer system work includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Foundation preparation. 
(2)  Furnishing and laying gravity sewer pipe. 
(3)  Furnishing and/or constructing drainage structures and appurtenances. 
(4)  Cleaning constructed work. 
(c)  Related work specified elsewhere shall be as follows: 
(1)  Route clearing, division 9 of this article. 
(2)  Trenching and backfilling, division 8 of this article. 
(3)  Tunneling, division 7 of this article. 
(4)  Drainage structures and accessories, division 3 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 1), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-427. - Job conditions. 
(a)  Traffic control. Work shall be scheduled and conducted in a manner which will minimize inconvenience to vehicular and pedestrian traffic. Flaggers, barricades, warning signs, warning lights, and other warning means shall be provided as appropriate. Traffic shall be maintained on all roads and streets, which must be crossed by storm sewer lines. All traffic controls during construction must conform to the Manual for Uniform Traffic Control Devices Guidelines. 
(b)  Weather limitations. All operations shall be conducted during weather conditions appropriate to the work being performed. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 1), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-428. - Quality assurance. 
(a)  Manufacturer experience. Manufactured products shall be furnished which are produced by firms generally recognized as engaged in the manufacture of products suitable for the applications of this project, as determined by the city and which have a minimum of five years experience in the production of products proposed for this project. 
(b)  Imperfections. Regardless of tolerances permitted by industry standards specified herein, the city may reject pipe or precast structures at the manufacturing plant or project site, which have cracks, chips, blisters, lack of smooth interior or exterior surface, evidence of structural weakness, porosity, joint defect, significant variation from theoretical shape, or other imperfection which might, in the opinion of the city, contribute to a reduced functional capability, accelerated deterioration, or reduced structural strength. 
(c)  Repairs. Patched or repaired pipe shall not be used unless each individual length or element has been approved and marked for repair by the city at the manufacturing plant. Repairs, other than at the manufacturing plant, are not permitted. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 1), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-429—71-454. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Products 

Sec. 71-455. - Concrete pipe (RCP). 
The following regulations shall apply to concrete pipe (RCP): 
(1)  Basic specification, nominal 15-inch size and over. ASTM C 76, reinforced sewer pipe furnished in not less than eight-foot lengths. 
(2)  Identification. Each length or joint of concrete pipe shall be stamped at the plant of manufacture, showing strength or reinforcement class, wall thickness designation, date of manufacture, and manufacturer symbol. 
(3)  Joints. At contractor option, one of the following jointing systems shall be used. Once a system is selected, such system shall be utilized for the entire project unless specified or authorized otherwise. 
a.  Cement grout type, which results in entire joint annular space being filled with grout and inside of each joint being wiped smooth. Use grout mixture consisting of not more than five gallons of water per sack of cement. Utilize cement conforming to AASHTO M85 or M150. 
b.  AWWA C 302 O-ring rubber gasket style in which the completed joint confines the O-ring on four sides with nominal clearance not to exceed 1/16 inch between smooth, accurately formed, bell and spigot surfaces. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-456. - Elliptical concrete pipe (ECPD). 
The following regulations shall apply to elliptical concrete pipe (ECPD): 
(1)  Basic specification. ASTM C 507, reinforced elliptical sewer pipe furnished in not less than eight-foot lengths. 
(2)  Additional specification requirements. Maximum absorption by standard ASTM test may not exceed 7.0 percent, and pipe must age at the manufacturing plant for not less than five days. 
(3)  Identification. Each length or joint of concrete elliptical pipe shall be stamped at the plant of manufacture, showing strength or reinforcement class, wall thickness designation, date of manufacture, manufacturer's symbol and quadrant reinforcing symbol. 
(4)  Joints. At contractor option, one of the following jointing systems shall be used. Once a system is selected, such system shall be for the entire project unless specified or authorized otherwise. 
a.  Cement grout type, which results in entire joint annular space being filled with grout and inside of each joint being wiped smooth. Grout mixture consisting of not more than five gallons of water per sack of cement shall be used. Cement conforming to AASHTO M85 or M150 shall be utilized. 
b.  Preformed flexible pipe joint compound shall be confined in the tongue and groove joint, meet Federal Specification SS-S-00210. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-457. - Corrugated plastic pipe (CPPD). 
(a)  Corrugated flexible conduit with slip-on joints made of polyethylene conforming with ASTM F 405 and F 449. 
(b)  Subject to compliance with requirements, firms offering products, which may be incorporated in the work, include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  ADS, Inc. 
(2)  Hancor, Inc. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-458. - Bituminous coated corrugated aluminum pipe (BCCAP). 
(a)  Basic specification. AASHTO M 196 with full uniform bituminous coating having minimum thickness of 0.05 inch and conforming with AASHTO M 190. 
(b)  Joints. Fully bituminous coated coupling bands manufactured from base metal as pipe. Utilized bands of same manufacturer as pipe. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-459. - Pipe fittings. 
Standard, factory-fabricated adapters, wyes, tees, and other necessary fittings comparable to pipe with which connected shall be used. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-460. - Coarse granular material for pipe bedding. 
Crushed stone, crushed gravel, natural gravel, or crushed shell meeting ASTM C 33, and having No. 67 gradation (three-quarter inch to No. 4 sieve) shall be used. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-461. - Fine granular material for pipe bedding. 
Uniformly graded natural or manufactured sand composed of hard, durable particles with 100 percent passing a No. 4 sieve, not more than 25 percent passing a No. 100 sieve, and containing no more than 25 percent total of silt and clay shall be used. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-462. - Storm sewer system structures. 
Storm sewer system structures shall conform with applicable provisions of division 3 of this article, pertaining to drainage structures and accessories. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-463—71-492. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Execution 

Sec. 71-493. - Pipe foundation. 
(a)  Concrete pipe foundation. For concrete pipe foundation, unless otherwise indicated, pipe shall be laid in trenches and on foundations prepared as selected by the contractor in conformance with the bedding class, trench width and depth, and pipe size tabulated below: 
_____ 

 
_____
(b)  Arch pipe foundation. For arch pipe foundation, unless otherwise indicated, pipe shall be laid in trenches and on foundations prepared as selected by the contractor in conformance with the bedding class, trench width and depth, as recommended by the manufacturer's published data. 
(c)  Definition of pipe foundation terms. Pipe foundation terms are defined as follows: 
Class B bedding may be achieved by either of the following two construction methods: 
(1)  Shaped bottom with tamped backfill. The bottom of trench excavation shall be shaped to conform to a cylindrical surface with a radius at least two inches greater than the radius to the outside of the pipe and with a width sufficient to allow six-tenths of the width of the pipe barrel to be bedded in fine granular material fill placed in the shaped excavation. Place and compact backfill shall be placed and compacted at sides of pipe to a thickness of at least 12 inches above top of pipe. Use of this bedding method shall be limited to trenches with firm bottom and sides. 
(2)  Compacted coarse granular bedding with a tamped backfill. Pipe shall be bedded in compacted coarse granular material placed on a flat trench bottom. The thickness of granular bedding must be at least one-fourth the outside pipe diameter, but not less than four inches thick under pipe barrel, and extend at least halfway up the pipe barrel at the sides. Compacted backfill shall be carefully placed above the granular material up a minimum depth of 12 inches over the top of pipe. 
Class C bedding may be achieved by either of the following two construction methods: 
(1)  Shaped bottom. Pipe shall be bedded with ordinary care in an earth foundation formed in the trench bottom by a shaped excavation which fits the pipe barrel with reasonable closeness for a width of at least 50 percent of the outside pipe diameter. Place compacted fill to a minimum depth of six inches above top of pipe. 
(2)  Compacted coarse granular bedding with a tamped backfill. Pipe shall be bedded in compacted granular material placed on a flat trench bottom. Thickness of granular material must be at least four inches under the barrel and must extend one-tenth to one-sixth of the outside diameter up the pipe barrel at the sides. Compacted backfill shall be placed above the granular material to a minimum depth of six inches over top of pipe. 
Trench depth means the vertical distance from pipe invert or flow line to finished ground surface. 
Trench width means the horizontal distance between trench walls at any point from one foot above top of pipe to trench bottom. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-494. - Pipe laying. 
(a)  When either bituminous coated corrugated aluminum or corrugated plastic pipe is used, pipe installation must be observed by a state-registered professional engineer engaged by the contractor or developer. Upon completion of the pipe installation and prior to acceptance by the city, the observing engineer is to furnish to the city a certification that the storm drainage pipe has been installed in accordance with the approved plans and these specifications. Acceptance by the city will not be considered without the engineer's certification. 
(b)  The interior of the pipe and all joints shall be cleaned before laying. When pipe laying activity is not in actual progress, open ends of the sewer shall be tightly covered. The contractor shall avoid permitting mud or other material from entering the sewer at all times. 
(c)  Contractors shall avoid damage or shock in handling pipe and accessories. Each length of pipe shall be inspected and any defective piece shall be rejected. Pipe in place shall be carefully protected from damage or displacement until backfilling operations are complete. 
(d)  Pipe shall be laid and jointed in strict conformance with the manufacturer's written recommendations as submitted to and approved by the city. Where cement joints are used, wet burlap or earth protective cover shall be provided for joints immediately after initial grout set. The protective cover shall be maintained until the joint is covered by backfilling. All pipe shall be laid upgrade with spigots pointing downgrade. 
(e)  The geometric position of pipe shall be controlled as necessary to ensure that pipe and fittings accurately conform with required grade and alignment after the sewer is completed. 
(f)  Water shall be prevented from accumulating or running in the trench during pipe laying operations, and until the trench or excavation has been backfilled. 
(g)  Any length of pipe which does not accurately conform with required line or grade, is crushed, or is excessively deflected shall be removed and re-laid. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-495. - Pipe connections. 
(a)  All pipe connections shall be made with standard fittings, or special construction detailed on drawings in article X of this chapter. 
(b)  At manholes and structures, all connecting pipe shall be neatly cut flush with the inside surface, and provide flexible pipe joint within 18 inches of outer surface. Pipe connections shall be made to manholes and structures by laying pipe in mortar bed or concrete. Supplemental materials and techniques shall be used as required to obtain watertightness. 
(c)  Contractors shall not connect any flow to new work until authorized by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-496. - Conformance of sewer structures. 
Sewer structures shall conform with applicable provisions of division 3 of this article, pertaining to drainage structures and accessories. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-497. - Line cleaning. 
When cleaning lines, contractors shall avoid permitting dirt, rubbish, surplus construction material, and other foreign matter to enter structures or pipe during construction. Contractors may use whatever means may be necessary to obtain a clean and internally smooth sewer system prior to final acceptance. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-498. - Sewer leakage. 
The entire sewer line system shall be made as near watertight as practicable. All visible points of groundwater infiltration and any other significant points of leakage which can be located shall be eliminated. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02770, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-499—71-519. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 71-520. - Description of work. 
(a)  The extent of the sanitary sewer system is shown on the drawings in article X of this chapter. 
(b)  Sanitary sewer system work includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Foundation preparation. 
(2)  Furnishing and laying gravity sewer pipe. 
(3)  Furnishing and/or constructing drainage structures and appurtenances. 
(4)  Cleaning constructed work. 
(5)  Testing constructed work. 
(c)  Related work specified elsewhere in this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  Route clearing, division 9 of this article. 
(2)  Trenching and backfilling, division 8 of this article. 
(3)  Tunneling, division 7 of this article. 
(4)  Drainage structures and accessories, division 3 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt.1), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-521. - Job conditions. 
(a)  Traffic control. Work shall be scheduled and conducted in a manner which will minimize inconvenience to vehicular and pedestrian traffic. Flaggers, barricades, warning signs, warning lights, and other warning means shall be provided as appropriate. Traffic shall be maintained on all roads and streets, which must be crossed by sewer lines. 
(b)  Weather limitations. All operations shall be conducted during weather conditions appropriate to the work being performed. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt.1), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-522. - Quality assurance. 
(a)  Manufacturer experience. Manufactured products shall be furnished which are produced by firms generally recognized as engaged in the manufacture of products suitable for the applications of this project, as determined by the city and which have a minimum of five years experience in the production of products proposed for this project. 
(b)  Imperfections. Regardless of tolerances permitted by industry standards specified herein, the city may reject pipe or precast structures at the manufacturing plant or project site, which have cracks, chips, blisters, lack of smooth interior or exterior surface, evidence of structural weakness, porosity, joint defect, significant variation from theoretical shape, or other imperfection which might, in the opinion of the city, contribute to a reduced functional capability, accelerated deterioration, or reduced structural strength. 
(c)  Repairs. Patched or repaired pipe or precast structures shall not be used unless each individual length or element has been approved and marked for repair by the city at the manufacturing plant. Repairs, other than at the manufacturing plant, are not permitted. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 1), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-523—71-552. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Products 

Sec. 71-553. - Concrete pipe (CPS). 
The following regulations shall apply to concrete pipe (CPS): 
(1)  Basic specification, nominal 18-inch size and larger. ASTM C 76, reinforced sewer pipe furnished in not less than eight-foot lengths with thickness class as determined from embedment tables for bedding class and trench width and depth for actual installation. 
(2)  Identification. Each length or joint of concrete pipe shall be stamped at the plant of manufacture, showing strength or reinforcement class, wall thickness designation, date of manufacture, and manufacturer symbol. 
(3)  Joints. Joints shall be ASTM C 361 O-ring rubber gasket style suitable for 25 feet hydrostatic pressure head above pipe centerline with smooth and accurately formed, concrete bell and spigot surfaces. 
(4)  Interior wall lining. Contractors shall apply factory coating of heavy duty, chemically resistant epoxy resin, suitable for sewer service, over barrel and joints of pipe. Contractors shall apply lining in at least three coats to a total minimum thickness of 20 mils, over concrete surfaces, which have been thoroughly prepared by either sand blasting or etching with acid. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-554. - Plastic solid wall pipe type 1 (PVCS). 
The following regulations shall apply to plastic solid wall pipe type 1 (PVCS): 
(1)  Basic specification for pipe diameters less than 18 inches. Contractors shall use ASTM D 3034 type PSM or ASTM D 3033 type PSP PVC bell and spigot sewer pipe with ratio of barrel outside diameter to wall thickness (SDR) no greater than 35, with pipe material meeting ASTM D 1784 12454 B or C and pipe stiffness at five percent deflection per ASTM D 2412, no less than 46 psi. 
(2)  Basic specification for pipe diameters 18 inches through 30 inches. Contractors shall provide ASTM F 679 PVC bell and spigot sewer pipe with T-1 wall thickness and pipe stiffness at five percent deflection per ASTM D 2412, no less than 46 psi. 
(3)  For sewer depths greater than 15 feet, contractors shall use ductile iron pipe (DIPS), and accomplish pipe material change at manholes where the depth along the length is greater than 15 feet. 
(4)  Couplings and adaptors. Contractors shall provide standard couplings and adaptors specifically designed to connect the PVC pipe to manholes or to other pipe materials. Manhole adaptors must provide a positive bond between the piping system and the mortar or concrete of the manhole structure. Protect all couplings and adaptors by fully encasing in concrete. 
(5)  Joints. ASTM D 3212 elastomeric gasket system comprised of material suitable for use with domestic sewage and conforming to ASTM F 477 shall be used. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-555. - Ductile iron pipe (DIPS). 
The following regulations shall apply to ductile iron pipe (DIPS): 
(1)  Basic specification. For pipe with push-on joints or mechanical joints, contractors shall provide ANSI/AWWA C 151/A 21.51 ductile iron pipe having pressure class as determined from embedment tables for bedding class and trench depth for actual installation. For pipe with flanged joints or grooved joints, provide ANSI/AWWA C 115/A 21.15 ductile iron pipe having minimum thickness class 53. 
(2)  Coatings. Contractors shall use cement mortar lining per ANSI/AWWA C 104/A 21.4 with standard asphaltic coating over lining and pipe exterior. 
(3)  Joints. Contractors shall use rubber push-on type (ANSI/AWWA C 111/A 21.11) except where mechanical joint (ANSI/AWWA C 110/A 21.10 and C 111/A 21.11) with corrosion-resistant alloy bolts, or flanged (ANSI/AWWA C 115/A 21.15 and ANSI B16.1, Class 125) with corrosion-resistant alloy bolts and red rubber gasket joints are indicated. 
(4)  Fittings. Fittings shall be the same design strength, lining, coating and joint as connecting ductile iron pipe. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-556. - Pipe fittings. 
For pipe fittings, contractors shall use standard, factory-fabricated adapters, wyes, tees, and other necessary fittings comparable to pipe with which connected. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-557. - Coarse granular material for pipe bedding. 
Crushed stone, crushed gravel, natural gravel, or crushed shell meeting ASTM D 448, and having No. 67 gradation (three-quarter inch to No. 4 sieve) shall be coarse granular material used for pipe bedding. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-558. - Fine granular material for pipe bedding. 
Uniformly graded natural or manufactured sand composed of hard, durable particles with 100 percent passing a No. 4 sieve, not more than 25 percent passing a No. 100 sieve, and containing no more than 25 percent total of silt and clay shall be fine granular material used for pipe bedding. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-559. - Select backfill materials. 
Satisfactory soil materials complying with ASTM D 2487 soil classification groups GW, GP, SW, SP and free of clay lumps, rock or other material larger than 1½ inches in any dimension (one-half-inch maximum size for six-inch and smaller pipe), debris, organic material, waste, frozen materials, vegetable and other deleterious matter and not more than five percent passing No. 200 sieve shall be used as backfill materials. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-560. - Conformance of sewer system structures. 
Sewer system structures shall conform with applicable provisions of division 3 of this article, pertaining to drainage structures and accessories. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 2), 4-25-2005)

(d)  Definition of pipe foundation terms. Definitions of pipe foundation terms are as follows: 
Class B bedding consists of the following construction method: Pipe shall be bedded in compacted coarse granular material placed on a flat trench bottom. Thickness of granular bedding must be at least one-eighth the outside pipe diameter, but not less than four inches thick under pipe barrel, and extend at least halfway up the pipe barrel at the sides. Compacted select backfill material or coarse granular material shall be carefully placed above the coarse granular material up a minimum depth of 12 inches over top of pipe. Not less than 85 percent of maximum dry density per ASTM D 698 (Standard Proctor) for all material shall be achieved. 
Class C bedding consists of the following construction method: Pipe shall be bedded in compacted granular material placed on a flat trench bottom. Thickness of granular material must be at least one-eighth the outside pipe diameter, but not less than four inches under the pipe barrel and must extend one-sixth of the outside diameter up the pipe barrel at the sides. Compacted select backfill material or coarse granular material shall be placed above the coarse granular material to a minimum depth of six inches over top of pipe. Not less than 85 percent of maximum dry density per ASTM D 698 (Standard Proctor) for all material shall be achieved. 
Trench depth means the vertical distance from pipe invert or flow line to finished ground surface. 
Trench width means the horizontal distance between trench walls at any point from one foot above top of pipe to trench bottom. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-585. - Pipe laying. 
The following procedure shall apply when laying pipe: 
(1)  Contractors shall clean the interior of the pipe and all joints before laying. When pipe laying activity is not in actual progress, open ends of the sewer shall be tightly covered. Contractors shall avoid permitting mud or other material from entering the sewer at all times. 
(2)  Contractors shall avoid damage or shock in handling pipe and accessories. Each length of pipe shall be inspected, and any defective piece shall be rejected. Contractors shall carefully protect pipe in place from damage or displacement until backfilling operations are complete. 
(3)  Contractors shall lay and join pipe in strict conformance with the manufacturer's written recommendations as submitted to and approved by the city. All pipe shall be laid upgrade with spigots pointing downgrade. 
(4)  Contractors shall control geometric position of pipe as necessary to ensure that pipe and fittings accurately conform with required grade and alignment after sewer is completed. 
(5)  Contractors shall prevent water from accumulating or running in trench during pipe laying operations, and until the trench or excavation has been backfilled. 
(6)  Contractors shall remove and re-lay any length of pipe, which does not accurately conform with required line or grade, is crushed, or is excessively deflected. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-586. - Pipe connections. 
(a)  All pipe connections shall be made with standard fittings, manholes, structures, or special construction detailed on drawings in article X of this chapter. Contractors shall locate building services and connect thereto with standard fittings as authorized. 
(b)  At manholes and structures, all connecting pipe shall be neatly cut flush with inside surface, and provide flexible pipe joint within 18 inches of outer surface. Pipe connections to manholes and structures shall be made by laying pipe in mortar bed or concrete. Contractors shall use supplemental materials and techniques as required to obtain watertightness. 
(c)  Contractors shall not connect any sewage flow to new work until authorized by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-587. - Installing sanitary sewer in tunnel liner. 
The following procedures shall apply for installing sanitary sewer in tunnel liners: 
(1)  Tunnel liner—12 inches to 42 inches. For tunnel liners 12 inches to 42 inches, contractors shall: 
a.  Insert sewer pipe concentrically into the tunnel liner by securing casing spacers radially around sewer pipe at no more than ten foot longitudinal intervals. 
b.  Blow sand into annular space between the sewer pipe and tunnel liner starting at the longitudinal center and proceeding outward to each end. Use techniques, which assure complete filling of all voids. 
(2)  Same—48 inches and larger. For tunnel liners 48 inches and larger, contractors shall use the following procedure for installing sewer pipe in the tunnel when adequate working room is available, otherwise contractors shall follow same procedures as specified for tunnel liner, six inches to 42 inches: 
a.  Insert sewer pipe into the tunnel liner after having grouted the bottom of the tunnel to exact grade required to support pipe in proper position. 
b.  Permanently secure sewer pipe in position by blocking each pipe length at top and sides with brick and mortar, followed by bedding sewer pipe to a depth equal to one-fourth the pipe outside diameter, with concrete. 
c.  Plug ends of tunnel with 12-inch thickness of masonry, leaving weep holes at the lower end of tunnel. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-588. - Conformance of sewer structures. 
Sewer structures shall conform with applicable provisions of division 3 of this article, pertaining to drainage structures and accessories. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-589. - Wyes, tees and services. 
For wyes, tees and services, contractors shall do the following: 
(1)  Provide wyes and/or service tees at points indicated on drawings in article X of this chapter, specified herein, and as requested by the city. If wyes or service extensions are not to be connected to a building sewer under this work, close the end of pipe with removable factory-fabricated plug or stopper. 
(2)  When replacing an existing sewer, connect all existing service lines to the new sewer. 
(3)  Service lines, unless otherwise shown on the drawings or requested by the city, are to be run to suit field conditions at a minimum grade of two percent and with a minimum pipe cover of 30 inches. 
(4)  Provide cleanouts in service lines at not more than 75-foot intervals and where pipe horizontal deflection exceeds 45 degrees. Unless noted otherwise, furnish cleanouts consisting of wye and 45-degree fittings, vertical pipe and threaded brass or plastic removal plug. Arrange cleanout to permit cleaning in the direction of flow. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-590. - Line cleaning. 
Contractors shall avoid permitting dirt, rubbish, surplus construction material, and other foreign matter to enter structures or pipe during construction. Contractors shall use whatever means may be necessary to obtain a clean and internally smooth sewer system prior to final acceptance. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-591. - Field quality control. 
(a)  General leakage requirements. To conform to general leakage requirements, contractors shall do the following: 
(1)  Make the entire sewer line system as near watertight as practicable. Eliminate all visible points of groundwater infiltration, and any other significant points of leakage which can be located, regardless of test results obtained as hereinafter required. 
(2)  Upon completion of pipe installation and trench backfilling to within one foot of finished grade, perform system installation acceptance tests using infiltration or exfiltration testing, or piping or joint low pressure air testing for all work constructed. Conduct final acceptance test witnessed by the city. 
(3)  Installation acceptance testing is required on all new sewer line segments extending completely from manhole to manhole unless waived by the city due to unreasonable service shutdown demands. 
(4)  An acceptable low pressure air test is interpreted as an installation acceptance test in lieu of infiltration or exfiltration testing of pipelines. 
(5)  Take whatever action may be necessary to permanently reduce infiltration from all water sources to less than the maximum allowable leakage limits established below for all constructed work. 
(b)  System exfiltration or infiltration acceptance testing. Infiltration testing is only applicable if the groundwater table is at least two feet above the crown of the new sewer pipeline being tested. Exfiltration testing will be used when the groundwater table is less than two feet above the crown of the new sewer. Contractors shall perform infiltration or exfiltration acceptance testing only as permitted by the city. 
(c)  System exfiltration testing. Contractors shall perform system exfiltration acceptance testing in accordance with ASTM C 1091 or ASTM C 969 guidelines for new sewers. The maximum allowable leakage is 50 gallons/(inch of internal diameter)(mile of sewer)(day) when the average head of the test section is three feet or less. When the average head on the test section is greater than three feet, the allowable leakage shall be multiplied by the ratio of the square root of the average test head over the square foot of the base head of three feet. 
(d)  System infiltration testing. Contractors shall perform system infiltration testing in accordance with ASTM C 1091 or ASTM C 969 guidelines for new sewers. The maximum allowable leakage limit is 50 gallons/(inch of internal diameter)(mile of sewer)(day) when the average head on the test section is six feet or less. When the average groundwater head on the test section is greater than six feet, the allowable leakage shall be increased in proportion to the ratio of the square root of the average groundwater head over the square root of the base head of six feet. 
(e)  Air testing. Air testing regulations shall be as follows: 
(1)  For nominal four-inch to 24-inch pipe: 
a.  After completing backfill of a sewer line section, contractors shall conduct a low pressure air test depending on pipe material in accordance with ASTM C 924, ASTM C 828, ASTM F 1417, or UNI-B-6 guidelines for installation acceptance. Ductile iron pipelines shall be tested in accordance with ASTM F 1417 or UNI-B-6 requirements. Contractors shall perform such tests using the following general procedures: 
1.  Temporarily plug line segment between two manholes using plugs having airtight fittings through which low pressure air can be introduced into the pipe segment being tested. 
2.  Introduce low-pressure air into the test pipe segment until the internal air pressure reaches 4.0 psig above groundwater pressure, if any. 
3.  Wait at least two minutes for air temperature in the test segment to stabilize while internal air pressure remains no less than 3.5 psig above groundwater pressure. 
4.  Accurately determine the elapsed time for internal pressure to drop 1.0 psig. 
b.  The air test is acceptable if elapsed time for an internal pressure drop of 1.0 psig is no less than shown in the following tables: 
1.  For concrete sewer lines: 

 
Air leakage time is based on the pipe being damp. If pipe and joints are dry, dampen the line if helpful in meeting air test time requirement. 
2.  For thermoplastic or ductile iron sewer lines: 

 
(2)  For nominal 27-inch and larger pipe: 
a.  After completing backfill of a sewer line section, contractors shall conduct a low pressure air test on each pipe joint in the section in accordance with ASTM C 1103 for concrete pipe sewer lines or by using methods and devices acceptable to the city. Perform such tests using the following general procedures: 
1.  Properly position and completely secure the test unit over the pipe joint being tested. 
2.  Introduce low-pressure air into the pipe joint test area until the internal air pressure reaches 3.5 psig above groundwater pressure, if any. 
3.  The joint air test is acceptable if the internal pressure drops less than 2.0 psi in ten seconds. 
b.  At each manhole constructed where groundwater is known to exist, contractors shall install a small diameter pipe nipple through the manhole wall at the time that the sewer pipe is installed. Locate the nipple immediately above the lowest connecting sewer pipe, and grout the nipple in place concurrently with grouting the sewer pipe. Prior to placing the nipple, wrap it with a continuous length of heavy nylon chord, which can be pulled out, thus permitting removal of the nipple after test work is complete. Just before commencing the air test, attach a clear plastic tube to the nipple, and hold the tube end vertically upward. After the groundwater has stopped rising in the plastic tube, measure the vertical distance from water level to pipe invert in feet. Average this distance observed at manholes on each end of the test segment, and divide the average distance in feet by 2.3 to obtain the groundwater pressure to be used in computing required test air pressure. 
c.  Contractors shall permanently correct excessive leakage determined by air testing, and repeat operations until the city witnesses a successful test on each line segment or joint; then remove the nipple through the manhole wall without disturbing adjacent grout. Permanently caulk the resulting hole watertight. 
(f)  Deflection testing. 
(1)  Contractors shall conduct internal deflection testing on all installed gravity sewer lines six-inch size and larger, no sooner than 15 days after completion of trench backfilling. Repair or replace all defective pipe found during mandrel testing and conduct another deflection test to determine the extent and necessary repair of any additional deficiencies. After repairing all defects, perform successful mandrel testing in the presence of the owner or the city. Mandrel testing is successful when the mandrel device can be pulled through the pipe between manholes in a continuous operation, without interruption. 
(2)  Contractors shall furnish mandrel test gauges sized and constructed as tabulated below: 
FIVE PERCENT DEFLECTION MANDREL  (ASTM D 2412) 

 
_____ 
(3)  Upon request by the city, contractors shall certify the accuracy of the mandrel test gauges by sliding proving rings to an accuracy of 0.05 inches over the mandrel. Use proving rings complying with ASTM F 679 and ASTM D 3034. 
(g)  Internal television inspection. Contractors shall conduct an internal television inspection on all installed gravity sewer lines eight-inch size and larger, after trench backfilling to within one foot of finished grade. Contractors shall repair or replace all visible defects found and conduct another internal television inspection to determine the extent and necessary repair of any additional deficiencies. Contractors shall repeat the inspection and correction process until the entire work shall be free from any visible defects. After repairing all visible defects, contractors shall perform a successful air test on each sewer segment before conducting final television inspection for the record. Contractors shall provide the owner with color DVD format video record and supporting written location records of the final condition of each completed and tested sewer segment. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02720, pt. 3), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-592—71-615. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - WATER SYSTEM 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 71-616. - Description of work. 
(a)  The extent of the water system is shown on the drawings in article X of this chapter. 
(b)  Water system work includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Foundation preparation. 
(2)  Furnishing and laying water pipe. 
(3)  Furnishing and installing water line appurtenances. 
(4)  Furnishing and laying services and accessories. 
(5)  Cleaning and sterilizing constructed work. 
(6)  Testing constructed work. 
(c)  Related work specified elsewhere shall be as follows: 
(1)  Route clearing, division 9 of this article. 
(2)  Trenching and backfilling, division 8 of this article. 
(3)  Tunneling, division 7 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02710, pt. 1), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-617. - Job conditions. 
(a)  Traffic control. Contractors shall schedule and conduct work in a manner which will minimize inconvenience to vehicular and pedestrian traffic. Flaggers, barricades, warning signs, warning lights, and other warning means shall be provided as appropriate. Contractors shall maintain traffic on all roads and streets which must be crossed by water lines and making two separate cuts so that at least one traffic lane is open at all times. All traffic controls during construction must conform to Part VI of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, ANSI D6.1e. 
(b)  Connection to existing pipe work. Where it is required that connection be made to existing pipe work, contractors shall expose existing piping and determine the exact fittings and/or other appurtenances necessary to make the connection. Connections to existing pipe work indicated on drawings, if any, are shown only for the purpose of illustrating the general type of connection desired, and no assurance exists that such illustration can be followed precisely. 
(c)  Weather limitations. All operations shall be conducted during weather conditions appropriate to the work being performed. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02710, pt. 1), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-618. - Quality assurance. 
(a)  Manufacturer experience. Contractors shall furnish manufactured items, fittings, valves, and service components from manufacturers having regularly produced such items as specified herein which have proven satisfactory in actual service, over at least a two-year period, as determined by the city. 
(b)  Imperfections. Irregardless of tolerances permitted by industry standards specified herein, the city may reject pipe or appurtenances at the manufacturing plant or project site, which have cracks, chips, blisters, lack of smooth interior or exterior surface, evidence of structural weakness, porosity, joint defect, significant variation from theoretical shape, or other imperfection which might, in the opinion of the city, contribute to a reduced functional capability, accelerated deterioration, or reduced structural strength. 
(c)  Repairs. Contractors shall not use patched or repaired pipe or appurtenances. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02710, pt. 1), 4-25-2005) 
Secs. 71-619—71-639. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Products 

Sec. 71-640. - Materials. 
Contractors shall provide all materials, products and accessories required for a complete, properly functioning system. Contractors shall use only those pipe, fitting and accessory materials that are free of qualities which impart taste, odor or toxicity to potable water. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02710, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-641. - Ductile iron piping systems. 
The following regulations apply to ductile iron piping system type 1 (DIPW-1), sizes six-inch and larger: 
(1)  Pipe. For pipe with push-on joints or mechanical joints, contractors shall provide ductile cast iron pipe conforming with ANSI/AWWA C 151/A 21.51 for pressure class not less than required by Table 51.3 for minimum 250 psig-rated working pressure, laying condition 2, and depth of cover for actual installation. For pipe with flanged joints or grooved joints, contractors shall provide ductile iron cast pipe conforming with ANSI/AWWA C 115/A 21.15 for thickness class 53 in Table 15.1 for minimum 250 psig-rated working pressure. 
(2)  Pipe lining. Contractors shall provide standard cement mortar pipe lining complying with ANSI/AWWA C 104/A 21.4, and standard asphaltic coating over lining and pipe exterior. Do not use any material which imparts taste or odor to potable water, or which is toxic to humans. 
(3)  Fittings. Contractors shall use gray or ductile iron fittings complying with ANSI/AWWA C 110/A 21.10 and C 111/A 21.11 for minimum 250 psig working pressure rating, lined and coated same as connecting pipe. At the contractor's option, ductile iron compact fittings complying with ANSI/AWWA C 153/A 21.53 for a minimum 350 psi working pressure rating, lined and coated same as connecting pipe may be used for pipe with push-on joints or mechanical joint. 
(4)  Joints. For pipe, fittings and valves, contractors shall use the following joint types indicated for the specified locations, unless otherwise specified or shown: 
a.  Flanged joint (FJ). ANSI/AWWA C 115/A 21.15 ductile iron flanged joint complying with ANSI B 16.1 for class 125 pound drilling, unless class 250 pound drilling is indicated on drawings or is required for connecting valves. Use corrosion-resistant alloy steel bolts and nuts, and rubber gaskets complying with Appendix A to ANSI/AWWA C 115/A 21.15. Provide flanged joints for normally visible piping, unless noted otherwise. 
b.  Mechanical joint (MJ). Mechanical joint complying with ANSI/AWWA C 111/A 21.11. Use corrosion-resistant alloy steel bolts and nuts. Provide mechanical joints for direct burial piping or concealed piping within structures, for piping installed in tunnel liner, or, at the contractor option, for direct burial piping outside structures. 
c.  Push-on joint (POJ). Push-on type joint complying with ANSI/AWWA C 111/A 21.11. Provide push-on joints for direct burial piping outside structures. 
d.  Restrained joint (RJ). Factory-fabricated joint restraint system to resist pressurized pipe thrust forces. For push-on type joint, use boltless system of rubber gasket embedded with equally spaced stainless steel segments to grip the pipe, with allowance for joint deflection, and rated for 250 psi working pressure. For mechanical joint, use assembly of ductile iron retainer gland and corrosion-resistant alloy steel bolts and nuts having a minimum 250 psi working pressure rating and permitting joint deflection. Provide restrained joints where indicated on the drawings and, at the contractor's option, for direct burial piping thrust restraint in lieu of concrete and metal tie rods and bands. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02710, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-642. - Copper piping systems. 
Copper tubing systems (CuTW) shall comply with the following regulations: 
(1)  Tubing. Contractors shall use copper tubing complying with ASTM B 88, Type K suitable for working pressures up to 200 psig at 200 F water temperature. For underground direct burial installations, use soft annealed or hard drawn tubing and for all other installation use hard drawn tubing. 
(2)  Fittings. For hard drawn tubing, contractors shall use solder or brazing type wrought copper or cast bronze pressure fittings complying with ANSI B 16.22 or B 16.18. For soft annealed tubing use solder or brazing type wrought copper or cast bronze pressure fittings complying with ANSI B 16.22 or B 16.18 or flare type cast bronze fittings complying with ANSI B 16.26. 
(3)  Joints. Joints shall be soldered, silver brazed or flared as appropriate and suitable for the following conditions: 
a.  Maximum working pressure: 150 psig. 
b.  Service temperature: 100 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02710, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-643. - Nonmetallic piping systems. 
(a)  Polyvinyl chloride piping system type 1 (PVCPW-1) (2½-inch to four-inch diameters only). 
(1)  Pipe. Pipe shall be nontoxic, polyvinyl chloride compound meeting ASTM D 1784, class 12454-A or B material specification, and further meeting requirements of the National Sanitation Foundation. Must conform with requirements of ASTM D 2241 for pressure rated pipe of class 200 (SDR 21). Contractors shall furnish pipe with each section continuously and permanently marked with the following identifying data: 
1.  Nominal size and outside diameter. 
2.  Material code designation. 
3.  Dimension ratio number (SDR or DR). 
4.  Pressure class. 
5.  ASTM or AWWA specification designation. 
6.  Manufacturer's name or trademark and production record code. 
7.  National Sanitation Foundation Seal (NSF) verifying suitability of pipe material for potable water service. 
(2)  Fittings (PVC). PVC fittings shall be manufactured from same material compound as pipe, and in such configuration as necessary to achieve long-term water pressure rating not less than the connecting pipe nor less than 160 psi at 73 F with a safety factor of 2.5:1. 
(3)  Fittings, gray or ductile iron. Fittings shall be gray or ductile iron fittings complying with ANSI A 21.10 or A 21.11 for minimum 250 psi pressure rating. At the contractor's option, ductile iron compact fittings complying with ANSI A 21.53 for minimum 350 psig pressure rating may be used. Provide cement mortar interior lining complying with ANSI A 21.4, and manufacturer's standard bituminous coating over lining and fitting exterior. Contractors shall not use any lining or coating which imparts taste or odor to potable water, or which is toxic to humans. 
(4)  Joints (PVC pipe). Unless otherwise required, contractors shall use flexible elastomeric seals conforming to ASTM D 3139 and ASTM F 477. Provide compatible gaskets or adapters as required when joining to different type pipe material. 
(5)  Joints (PVC fittings). Unless otherwise required, contractors shall use flexible elastomeric seals conforming to ASTM D 3139 and ASTM F 477. 
(6)  Joints (gray or ductile iron fittings). Joints for gray or ductile iron fittings shall comply with ANSI A 21.11 and unless otherwise required, use at the contractor's option push-on type joint or mechanical joint utilizing corrosion resistant alloy bolts. Contractors shall provide gaskets or adapters compatible with connecting pipe as required. 
(b)  Polyethylene or polybutylene tubing system type 1 (PETW-1). 
(1)  Tubing. 
a.  Tubing shall be flexible polybutylene or polybutylene tubing complying with AWWA C 902, suitable for working pressures up to 160 psig at 73 F water temperature and having a SDR not greater than 13. 
b.  Furnish tubing continuously and permanently marked with the following identifying data: 
1.  Nominal size and outside diameter. 
2.  Material code designation. 
3.  Dimension ratio number (SDR or DR). 
4.  Pressure class. 
5.  ASTM or AWWA specification designation. 
6.  Manufacturer's name or trademark and production record code. 
7.  National Sanitation Foundation Seal (NSF) verifying suitability of pipe material for potable water service. 
(2)  Fittings and adapters. Fittings and adapters shall be brass or bronze, and of the type and size required by the installation. 
(3)  Joints, metal to plastic tubing. Joints shall be metal to plastic tubing-compression type with stainless steel insert. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, app. B(02710, pt. 2), 4-25-2005) 
Sec. 71-644. - Valves. 
(a)  Gate valves. 
(1)  Gate valve type 1 (GVW-1).
